Author: ALDANOV, A. D.
Title: 25 years work of Saratov Central Station of plant-breeding and genetics.
Abstract Note: Among the achievements of the station in wheat breeding one of the most outstanding referred to is the production of the spring wheat Lutescens 062 by individual plant selection. This variety has yielded an average of 14.3 c. per ha. over a period of nineteen years and on account of its drought resistance has outyielded the local " Poltavka " in the seven worst drought years by 34.2 per cent. Various other varieties both of T. vulgare and T. durum have been produced by the same method, e.g.-Erythrospermum 0341 and T. durum hordeiforme 0432. By interspecific crossing the famous varieties Sarrubra and Sarrosa have been obtained from crosses of T. vulgare (Poltavka) and T. durum (Beloturka). These varieties are distinguished by their high drought resistance; in yield they have surpassed the two parents by 25.4 and 32.1 per cent respectively and are more or less equal to Lutescens 062, which they distinctly excel in milling and baking quality. Sarrubra is free from shedding when standing in the field and is suitable for combine harvesting; the area under this variety is constantly increasing. Other promising hybrids have been produced from later crosses of the same combination of species. Among these is an awnless T. durum equal to the standards in yield and earlier in maturity. Promising results have also been obtained from interracial crosses in T. vulgare and certain varieties resistant to smut and leaf rust have been produced. In winter wheat equally successful results have been obtained. The variety Lutescens 0329 is characterized by exceptional cold resistance, and is closely followed by Lutescens 1060/10; these two varieties have made possible a considerable extension of wheat cultivation in the lower Volga basin. Various newer hybrids are equally, if not more, promising. Many of the hybrids with rye are highly promising in respect of cold and drought resistance, yield and grain quality. The main characteristics of the forms that have proved most popular in cultivation are described. Some of them are equal to rye in earliness of maturity and exceed the standard wheat varieties in yield. They are being further crossed among themselves and with winter wheat and the amphidiploids obtained are also being used in crossing. Perennial rye is also being crossed with winter wheats in the attempt to produce perennial wheats. The same object is pursued in the crosses between Agropyrum and wheat. Some of these hybrids are at the same time possessed of great winter-hardiness and resistance both to drought and to many fungous diseases, and are also tolerant of very unfavourable growth conditions. The hybrids of A. elongaium contain the highest proportion of perennial plants in the later generations. Valuable hardy lines of both annual and perennial type have been isolated and some of these are now in the stage of variety testing. Sunflowers resistant to Orobanche and also to moth and drought have been produced by selection. A valuable new form, No. 169, possesses in addition to these characters, high yielding ability and ripens in 95-104 days, giving also a satisfactory oil content. An early variety ripening in 78 days, also resistant to Orobanche and moth has been selected, and various interesting lines have been obtained by inbreeding. One of these, No. 137 is superior both in yield and oil content and is at the same time rust-resistant. Sunflower crosses have been made, including one between the variety No. 169 and the perennial wild species Helianthus divaricatus; the hybrids are resistant to drought, rust and other fungous diseases, and include a perennial oil form which is receiving attention. Improved strains of rye have been selected and constant lines have been obtained by inbreeding which exceed the standard in yield by 6 to 60 per cent. Crosses have been effected also between rye and Agropyrum Cristatum. Millet has been subjected to selection and improved lines produced, including one No. 853, which is drought-resistant, uniform in ripening, free from shedding, good in grain quality, and unusually high in yield.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: RJAZAXOV, JA I.
Title: A brief summary of the results and problems in the research work of the Institute of Grain Husbandry in the South-East of the U.S.S.R.
Abstract Note: The overriding consideration in plant breeding for the South-Eastern regions of the U.S.S.R. is drought. Comparative analyses have been made of the meteorological conditions over a period of years and of the yields of winter rye and spring wheat, and it has been possible to define those conditions which lead to the best yields in each. The influence of various cultural measures, rotations and other operations on moisture conservation has been studied by the Saratov institute. A number of new and improved varieties suitable for these conditions have been produced and are described The spring wheat Lutescens 15/12 is a product of complex hybridization, characterized by rapid development of the root system and rapid gain in dry weight in the developing grain; it is free from shedding, high in grain quality and exceeds Sarrubra in yield by up to 5 c. per ha. The spring wheat Albidum 43, the most drought resistant yet produced, is also a product of complex hybridization, and has a high rate of development of the primary and secondary roots, rapid filling of the grain and very uniform grain; it is free from shedding and has exceeded the standard by 2-2.5 c. per ha. in yield New spring wheats for irrigated land are Lutescens 605 and 758, and the best winter wheat yet produced is the rye-wheat hybrid Lutescens 230, distinguished by its winter hardiness, standing capacity, and large vitreous grains of high baking quality. Good results have been obtained with new varieties of other crops, such as Volzanka No. 7 winter rye; sunflowers with improved oil content such as Saratov No. 19, P-10, P4 and P-27, the last being a very early variety maturing in 77 days; and the millet Saratov Cream 311, characterized by a high extraction rate of 85%. Five perennial wheat selections from Triticum * Agropyron hybrids are under observation.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Afsana, Nadira; Islam, Zahirul
Title: Abundance of ladybird beetles in irrigated rice environment in Bangladesh, diurnal activity pattern of Micraspis discolor (Fab.) and its influence on rice grain sterility.
Abstract Note: Five species of ladybird beetles viz., Micraspis discolor (Fab.), M. crocea Mulsant, Coccinella transversalis Fab., C. septempunctata Linn. and Brumoides suturalts (Fab.) (Coccinellidae: Coleoptera) were found in irrigated rice fields at Gazipur in Bangladesh. Among them Micraspis discolor was the most dominant species comprising about 92.9% of the total ladybird beetle populations. Their relative abundance was highest in the rice fields with ponding water (37.73 %), followed by rice fields without ponding water (22.05%), rice seedbed (12.50%), grassy fallow fields (10.23%), fields with rice ratoons (7.95%), grassy road-sides (6.59%), and the least on rice bunds with grasses (2.95%). Micraspis discolor appeared to prefer rice than grasses, and rice fields with water than without water. At the flowering stage, adult M. discolor remained active on the rice panicle throughout the day but its abundance was influenced by some physical factors. It appeared that temperature and sunlight had positive influence, and rainfall and relative humidity had negative influence on the abundance of adult M. discolor on rice panicles. Observations indicated that sampling of M. discolor on emerging rice panicles can be done at any time of the day except during rain. At the flowering stage they fed on rice pollen, but their feeding even by high populations (20 adults/hill) did not cause grain sterility.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Lin, S.-C.; Chang, T.-K.; Huang, W.-D.; Lur, H.-S.; Shyu, G.-S.
Title: Accumulation of arsenic in rice plant: a study of an arsenic-contaminated site in Taiwan
Abstract Note: A study conducted in 2006 showed that over 100 ha of rice paddies in Beitou, Taiwan, irrigated over the years using water mixed with hot spring, was heavily polluted by arsenic. Thus, the objective of the present study is to measure arsenic content in different parts of rice and paddy soils, and eventually explain the arsenic distribution in ratoon rice, including its relationship to the soil. Arsenic levels of rice in grains, straws, roots, and soils were obtained from 15 rice paddies, selected based on different arsenic soil concentrations ranging from 67 to 438 mg kg(-1) (n = 15). The mean arsenic content in grains was measured at 0.20 mg kg(-1) (n = 60) and the highest grain arsenic of the survey was at 1.183 mg kg(-1). Meanwhile, the mean total arsenic levels were 244 mg kg(-1) (n = 28) in root and 4.4 mg kg(-1) (n = 28) in straw. In comparison, regression of topsoil arsenic levels with rice grains (r (2) = 0.00) and straws (r (2) = 0.56) were less significant compared to that with rice roots (r (2) = 0.93), and the mean arsenic level in rice from root to grain was also shown to have a decreasing trend. Though concentrations of arsenic in compositive rice grain each field did not exceed food hygiene concentration limit, arsenic level in root strongly depended on arsenic concentrations of soil suggesting that the high arsenic concentration may have the potential for translocation from root to grain which ultimately effects on the human health.

Author: Acharya, S.N.; Mir, Z.; Moyer, J.R.
Title: ACE-1 perennial cereal rye
Abstract Note: ACE-1 perennial cereal rye (PC rye) (Secale cereale) was developed by the Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada Research Centre, Lethbridge, Alberta. This cultivar, tested as LRC 96-1 in western Canada, was developed for silage and greenfeed. ACE-1 is easy to establish, competes well with weeds, grows early in spring, produces more biomass than barley and fall rye under dryland and irrigated conditions, but produces less seed than high yielding fall rye cultivars. Forage quality of ACE-1 was found to be similar to barley.

Author: CICIN, N. V.
Title: Achievements and tasks of Soviet plant breeding.
Abstract Note: In 1966, there were 225 approved cultivars of wheat, the most outstanding of which are described. Other achievements are sunflowers with high oil content and immunity to a number of diseases and pests, resulting from interspecific crosses. Of the 30 promising maize hybrids, a number are derived from male-sterile parents and corresponding wheat hybrids show yield increases of 30-40%; all the Triticum-Agropyron hybrids excel the standards in standing capacity and recent ones such as PPG391 and PPG56 yield over 40 c. per ha. without lodging; PPG172 is also resistant to drought, shedding and brown and yellow rust, yielding up to 55.4 c. per ha. under irrigation. The advantages of polyploidy are exemplified by triploid sugar beets, tetraploid rye and rye-wheat amphidiploids; three perennial Triticum-Agropyron hybrids give 2-3 yields without resowing and are resistant to frost and disease, though yielding less grain than the common wheat cultivars; a description is given of 1345, which, when sown in autumn, gives three crops of hay with a protein content of 12-14%, the total yield of which is 90-100 c., after which it can be grazed; other Triticum-Agropyron hybrids, with branching ears, contain over 100 grains per ear. A perennial rye, Pervenec [Firstborn], gives a crop in three successive years almost equal to that from normal rye. Incompatibility has been overcome in interspecific tobacco crosses by polyploidy, in crosses of cabbage with radish by grafting, which also induces flowering in the first year; an interspecific potato hybrid contains 23-5% starch and 3% protein; successful cultivars of pea and French bean have been produced by interspecific hybridization and others by crossing between ecotypes.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Chang, Jen-Hu
Title: A climatological analysis of yield difference between the first and second rice crop in Taiwan
Abstract Note: Temperature, solar radiation and daylength exert different effects on the growth of rice during successive stages of development and consequently the four yield components which add up to the final yield. In this study stepwise correlation between these climatic parameters during the three phases of rice development and the first and second rice crop yields in four regions in Taiwan has been analyzed. The result indicates that solar radiation during the reproductive and ripening phases is the major factor determining rice yield. The much lower yield of the second rice crop than the first one is primarily caused by the extremely low solar radiation during the second season, particularly in northern and eastern Taiwan.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: SOULIER, E. J.
Title: A composite perennial Elymus-wheat-Agropyrum hybrid.
Abstract Note: Descriptions are given of two hybrid plants obtained by pollinating a sterile F 4 perennial Triticum x Agropyron hybrid with pollen from Elymus giganteus. The two hybrids resembled E. giganteus. in general plant habit, rhythm of development, the creeping habit of the root system, and in leaf and stem structure. The chromosome number of the maternal hybrid was 2n = 48, while that of the hybrid was 2n = 52. Since 2n = 28 in Elymus giganteus, it is inferred that an unreduced gamete of this species took part in the fertilization.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: HIZNJAK, V. A.
Title: A cyto-genetical study of Triticum X Agropyron hybrids and the trend in breeding perennial wheat. Preliminary communication.
Abstract Note: Sterility of the F 1 hybrids between Triticum and Agropyron is due to (1) frequent anomalies in pre-meiotic and mitotic divisions of the pollen mother-cells, (2) incomplete and casual conjugation of chromosomes, the number of bivalents varying from 0 to 2 ( T. durum X 28 chromo- some A. intermedium) to 19 to 23 ( T. vulgare x A. elongatum) and (3) irregular pollen-grain division. The degree of self-fertility varies however with parental forms; all hybrids between Triticum and A. intermedium are self-sterile, as are the hybrids between hard wheat and A.-elongatum, but a part of the hybrids between soft wheat and A. elongatum are self-fertile. The triple hybrids are relatively easily obtained by crossing F 1 to one of the parents. The data on the second generation concern chiefly the hybrids between wheat and A. intermedium, the majority of which were obtained by fusion of the male gametes with unreduced gametes of the F 1. Among sesquidiploids a forty-two chromosome plant was obtained, and among triple hybrids (F 1 X T. vulgare) forty-six and fifty-four chromosome plants were found; these plants resemble wheat, but they are perennial, Among F 2 plants (chiefly the triple hybrids) some lethal specimens with deficient chlorophyll were found. Both wheat sesquidiploids and those of couch grass are perennial and partly fertile. In reduction division of triple hybrids between T. dumm x 48 chromosome A. intermedium and A. vulgare, fourteen to twenty-one bivalents were counted and in the triple hybrid between T. durum X 48 chromosome A. intermedium and A. elongatum the number of bivalents was twenty-one. This suggests that the genomes A, B and D of wheats are homologous, though modified, with the respective Agropyron genomes. The Agropyron genomes X 1 and X 2 are not found in wheat; their relation to those of Aegilops has not yet been shown. The main trend of obtaining perennial wheat is thought to be through producing sesquidiploids which contain a haploid set of wheat and some Agropyron chromosomes. Fusion of these gametes will give plants with a diploid set of Triticum and Agropyron and a haploid set of Agropyron chromosomes; in these plants some of the Agropyron chromosomes will be univalents; selection of forms without univalents will give constant fertile forms. Triple hybrids might also give valuable forms, and finally obtaining amphidiploids by crossing wheat sesquidi-ploids with those of Agropyron should produce valuable forage plants.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: CAUDERON, M. Y.
Title: A cyto-genetic study of a trigeneric hybrid involving T. dicoccum Schrank, A., intermedium Host. P.B. and S. cereale L.
Abstract Note: Attempts were made to cross the two amphi-diploids, T. timopheevi x A. intermedium, and T. dicoccum x A. intermedium with diploid S. secale used as the pollen parent. In the former case, six seeds were obtained from the 104 flowers pollinated but no progeny was raised. Five seeds were gained from 288 pollinations in the second case; five hybrids were raised. These plants had chromosome numbers of 2n = 42, 14 chromosomes having been obtained from Triticum, 21 from Agropyron and seven from Secale. Root-tip nuclei at interphase showed the chromocentric structure characteristic of Secale. Meiotic behaviour was studied in one hybrid; the average metaphase configurations of 100 cells were 34.26 I + (2.95 IId + 0.08 IIa) + 0.56 III. There were 0.56 chiasmata per conjugated chromosome. These results were compared with those of the F 1 of T. dicoccum x A. intermedium; in this case the average configurations were 24.37 r + (3.87 IId + 0.25 IIa) + 77 III + 0.02 iv. There was no apparent pairing between the chromosomes of Secale and those of the other two species; most of the chromosome associations arose from auto-syndesis of the Agropyron chromosomes. It was often possible to distinguish the Secale chromosomes amongst the univalents. Other aberrations typical of intergeneric hybrids were also observed.The hybrids were completely sterile even under conditions of open pollination. They showed great vigour; in their habit the hybrids resembled Agropyron from which they also inherited certain characteristics of the glume and the property of being perennial. From Secale the hybrids had inherited the hairy collar of the ear. In their late ripening, they resembled both Triticum and Agropyron. In other ear characters the hybrids were intermediate between the parent forms.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: Mruthunjaya, M.; Wali, C.; Mahadevappa, M.; Kulkarni, R. S.; Muralikrishna, S.
Title: Additive and Non Additive Gene Effects for Ratooning Ability in Eighteen Crosses of Rice (Oryza sativa L.)
Abstract Note: Dominance gene effects were predominant for ratooning ability, though additive gene effects were also  important. Intermating of selects followed by visual selection in early segregating generations would bring improvement  in the trait. In majority of crosses duplicate type of epistasis was observed. The results suggest the complex nature of inheritance of ratooning ability in rice.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: CICIN, N.
Title: Advancement of winter forms in the eastern regions of the U.S.S.R, and breeding of new varieties of winter crops.
Abstract Note: The history of cultivation of winter cereals in Siberia and the present and ultimate participation of winter forms in grain production are discussed in relation to the need for extending the acreage under cereals to 17, 865, 000 ha. in 1941 and 18, 830, 000 ha. in 1942. Heavy depletion of winter sowings occurring yearly is the chief limiting factor in extension of the acreage sown with winter forms. With good management, the existing varieties will ensure a good crop; among agronomical measures, protection of sowings with snow is particularly important; it has been shown that under 50 cm. deep snow, temperatures at the depth of the tillering node do not fall below-2.4degreesC. when the surface temperature is about-22.6degreesC. Another important aspect is manuring which tends to increase carbohydrate content and thus the resistance of the plants, as well as regeneration of the parts damaged during winter. There is need for production of special Siberian varieties, in the breeding of which the vast resources in local peasant strains must be utilized; the method of training must also be used. The most promising trend, however, is distant hybridization. Extensive work has been done to this end at the Siberian Research Institute of Grain Husbandry, Omsk: large numbers of hybrids are now available; among them

Author: ZuDe, Zhang; NengPu, Shi
Title: A fixed-site study on a multiple cropping model for tobacco-producing fields in a red soil area.
Publication Title: Journal of Fujian Academy of Agricultural Sciences
Abstract Note: A fixed-site experiment was conducted in Yongding county, the main tobacco-producing area in Fujian Province, China to study 9 multiple cropping systems. The best systems were spring tobacco-rice-early autumn maize-vegetables and spring tobacco-rice-ratooned rice. The effects of these systems on yield and quality of tobacco and soil properties and resource utilization were also considered.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Anonymous
Title: Again about distant hybridization and the wheat- Agropyron hybrids.
Abstract Note: The minutes are published of a conference of the Scientific Council of the Institute of Grain Farming of the Non-Black-Earth Belt held on 8 March 1948. The meeting was held as a protest against an article on N. V. Cicin's work by G. Andreev (cf. Abst, 1518). The editorial commentary on the dispute lends its support to Andreev. The resolution, which is signed by 20 members of the Scientific Council, may be summarized as follows. (1) The article by G. Andreev should be declared as libellous and misleading. (2) Accusations of Cicin and his colleagues of an anti-Micurinite direction in biology is due to misrepresentation. (3) Hybridization between cultivated and wild plants at the Institute has given new forms and varieties during a shorter period of time than ordinary breeding methods would have done. (4) Cicin and his colleagues have obtained by distant hybrid-ization, for the first time in history, a perennial wheat and several useful annual spring and winter wheat- Agropyron hybrids. These have either been released commercially or are undergoing State commercial tests. (5) The first form of perennial wheat, No. 34085, was obtained by Cicin in. 1935. Commercial tests in Kazahstan and Kirgizia have shown that the wheat can yield 2-3 harvests in succession without resowing. At the Kirgiz State Breeding Station, for instance, during the two growth periods, 1942 and 1943, four harvests were collected totalling 55.2 c.per ha. The wheat was discarded because of certain uneconomic characters. It has been replaced by new perennial wheats lacking the disadvantages of the original form. Among the best of these is wheat No. 2, which has been bred in the Moscow province. (6) A spring wheat-Agropyron hybrid, variety Flora -5, and a winter variety No. 599 are undergoing state tests. The winter variety No. 599 is superior in yields to standard varieties of the Novgorod, Leningrad, Tula and Kaluga provinces. (7) The Agropyron-wheat varieties 22850 and 23021 have been highly productive in commercial fanning. The promising spring Agropyron-wheat varieties Flora 6 and 7 and the winter hybrid varieties Nos 186, 4871, 64/45 and the squarehead No. 1/P have been submitted for testing. (8) The winter hybrids No. 599 and E-2493 are resistant to lodging and smut and their grain has good baking properties. (9) In the course of developing distant hybridization, the institute has made advances in the problems of polyploids, in rapprochment by grafting of intergeneric and other plants, and in methods of artificial preservation of hybrid embryos resulting from difficult distant crosses. It discovered the presence of gluten in the grain of barley, rye and other cereals and the application of the fact to breeding cereals. (10) The research institute has obtained new wheat, rye and barley hybrids with Elymus, Agropyron-rye hybrids, and the trigeneric hybrids, wheat x Agropyron x Elymus, wheat x Agropyron x rye, and wheat x rye x Elymus. (11) Some shortcomings of the work at the institute, mostly of an administrative nature, are pointed out. The attention is drawn of the Minister of Agriculture of the USSR, I. A. Benediktov, to Andreev's article. This has nothing in common with Soviet self criticism, but instead runs down outstanding discoveries of Soviet breeding and misleads the Soviet public. The main points of the editorial criticisms of Cicin and his colleagues are lack of practical results during 20 years of activity, due to formalism, Morganism and metaphysical conceptions; the absence of a perennial wheat in commercial production; misinterpretation of Micurin to suit formalist theories; and the use of colchicine methods and other "chance" methods of orthodox geneticists.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: GORGIDZE, A. D.
Title: A genetic study of wheat-rye hybrids.
Abstract Note: A wheat-rye amphidiploid (2 n = 42) was obtained which is highly fertile and combines the features and properties of Triticum palaeocolchicum (2 n = 28) and perennial rye (2 n = 14). This hybrid is biennial, self fertile, high yielding and resistant to fungal diseases.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: Pastor-Pastor, Alejandro; González-Paleo, Luciana; Vilela, Alejandra; Ravetta, Damián
Title: Age-related changes in nitrogen resorption and use efficiency in the perennial new crop Physaria mendocina (Brassicaceae)
Abstract Note: Domestication of desert-adapted species and their development into perennial crops has been proposed as an alternative to increase cropping intensity in arid lands, while reducing nitrogen inputs and losses. Among traits involved in nitrogen conservation much attention has been drawn to resorption patterns. However, understanding of intra-population variability in resorption and nitrogen use efficiency is required prior to the development of new crops. Here we evaluate age-related changes in resorption patterns and nitrogen use efficiency (NUE) within a wild population of Physaria mendocina (Brassicaceae). We generated a relative age index, based on morphological traits, and we use it as an independent variable to regress nitrogen concentrations in roots and leaves (green and senesced), nitrogen resorption efficiency and use efficiency. Nitrogen in green and senesced leaves decrease with age, resorption efficiency did not change, and nitrogen use efficiency increased. The lower nitrogen concentration in green leaves and higher proficiency (lower nitrogen concentrations in senesced leaves) of older plants might be due to a decrease in acquisition capacity. Constant efficiency is explained by the lack of differences in concentration in green and senesced leaves slopes. Higher proficiency in older plants resulted in higher NUE; this relationship would be modulated by nitrogen concentration in green leaves, which, in turn, is controlled by nitrogen availability and acquisition. These findings have implications in the domestication process, since in perennial species biomass production and internal plant nitrogen turnover over multiple seasons, are central key to physiological functions such as plant re-growth and winter survival. We identified a few questions as directions for future research.

Author: DeHaan, Lee R.; Weisberg, Sanford; Tilman, David; Fornara, Dario
Title: Agricultural and biofuel implications of a species diversity experiment with native perennial grassland plants
Abstract Note: Two primary approaches to perennial biofuel crop production studied so far are fertilized grass monocultures and low-input high-diversity grasslands. While high-yielding perennial grass varieties are being developed in fertilized monocultures, breeding for yield in low-input high-diversity systems would be difficult. Before initiating breeding for low-input systems, it is therefore important to know the minimum number of functional groups and species required for maximum biomass harvest from low-input grasslands. We controlled the number of perennial grassland species in 168 plots in Minnesota, USA. Species were selected at random from a pool of 18, and 1, 2, 4, 8, or 16 were planted in each plot. Aboveground biomass was measured annually, and the plots were burned each spring. We found a strongly positive log-linear relationship between average annual aboveground biomass and planted species number, but a large proportion of plot-to-plot variability remained unexplained. We performed a conditional analysis of the aboveground biomass data to determine whether considering species identity would reduce the minimum number of species necessary in order to achieve yields similar to the highest diversity treatments. A model that accounted for the presence of legumes in general, and for the presence of the legume species Lupinus perennis in particular, showed no increase in biomass yield with increased species number. Over 11 years, average yields of L. perennis/C4 grass bicultures were similar to those of 16-species (maximum diversity) plots, and both were >200% greater than the average of monocultures. Thus, under low-input conditions, the choice of the appropriate few perennial plant species for each location might result in systems with biomass yields similar to those from high-diversity systems. Because breeding biofuel crops in diverse mixtures would introduce complexity that is unwarranted in terms of maximum biomass yield, the first biofuel crop breeding programs for low-input systems are likely to accelerate progress by focusing on grass–legume bicultures.
Manual Tags: aboveground biomass; agricultural development; Agriculture; ALL(perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE(ar); Biofuel; Biomass; Crop production; Crop yield; full text added; Grassland; legume; Lupinus perennis; Minnesota; Perennial; perennial plant; perennial W/1 grain; Plant breeding; relevant; ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.grain; Species diversity; SPV; United States

Author: Akgun, I.; Tosun, M.
Title: Agricultural and cytological characteristics of M 1 perennial rye ( Secale montanum Guss.) as effected by the application of different doses of gamma rays.
Abstract Note: Perennial rye seeds were exposed to different doses of gamma rays (cobalt-60), i.e. 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, 20, 25 and 30 krad, and grown under field and greenhouse conditions in Turkey. The higher gamma ray doses decreased seed emerging rate, seedling height, spike length, spikelet number and seed set. The lethal dose (LD 50) was 18-20 krad and growth reduction dose (GR 50) was 12 krad. In the M 1 generation, as doses of gamma rays increased, the frequency of metaphase I with univalent and the frequency of irregular anaphase I cells increased. In the M 1 plants, anaphase I irregularities were especially seen as chromatin bridge. However, the frequency of anaphase I cells with laggards was higher than anaphase I cells with bridge at 20 and 25 krad doses of gamma rays.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: Jaikumar, N.S.; Snapp, S.S.; Murphy, K.; Jones, S.S.
Title: Agronomic assessment of perennial wheat and perennial rye as cereal crops
Abstract Note: Perennial wheat (Triticum aestivum L. × Thinopyrum spp.) and perennial rye (Secale cereale L. × S. montanum) are novel hybrid species under development as alternatives to annual cereal crops. We conducted a 2-yr field study with a split plot design to evaluate agronomic performance including yield phenology and biomass production of perennial accessions of wheat and rye along with annual analogs. This is one of the first studies to rigorously compare agronomic performance of 2-yr-old plants to 1-yr-old plants in perennial cereals. Perennial wheat produced 1.0 to 1.6 Mg ha-1 grain yield 50% of annual wheat (2.7 Mg ha-1) while perennial rye produced 1.3 Mg ha-1 73% of annual rye (1.8 Mg ha-1). Modest yields from perennials relative to annuals reflected lower harvest index lower yield per tiller and less kernel mass. One-year-old and 2-yr-old perennial plants had similar seed yields yield components and biomass production indicating that plant age had little effect on these parameters and older plants maintained yield potential. In contrast phenology did vary with plant age and showed a shift toward earlier spring growth and later flowering dates in older perennial plants. This illustrates an expanded vegetative period for regrowing plants of these perennial cereals. There appears to be potential for producing an early season forage crop from these cereals although biomass yields were not high at this site and regrowth was not always reliable. Overall performance of perennial rye was consistent with a viable new cereal crop. On the other hand perennial wheat requires further selection for allocation of biomass to grain and vigorous regrowth.
Manual Tags: ALL(perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE(ar); ALL(perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); relevant; Scopus; search.grain; search.rye; search.wheat; Secale cereale; SPV; Thinopyrum; Triticum aestivum; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Costa, E. G. de C.; Santos, A. B. dos; Zimmermann, F. J. P.
Title: Agronomic characteristics of irrigated rice in the main crop and in the ratoon.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted during 1995-96 in Goias, Brazil to evaluate the agronomic characteristics correlated to rice grain yield in both main and ratoon crops and to establish criteria for genotype selection in irrigated rice. The number of panicles/m 2 was the main component in the determination of grain yield in the ratoon crop. The growth duration periods and the number of grains per panicle were greater in the main crop. The average 100-grain weight was approximately 2.5 g in both crops. Plant height and harvest index were highly correlated to grain yield of the main crop, whereas number of panicles/m 2 and number of tillers/m 2 were highly correlated on yield of the ratoon crop. Milling ability, evaluated by total head rice recovery and percentage of whole kernels, was similar on both ratoon and main crops. The agronomic characters of the main crop were correlated to grain yield, but these correlations were not significant for the ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Ahmed, N. U.
Title: Agronomic measurement and comparative performance of short duration post-rainy season pigeonpea in rice-based cropping patterns.
Publication Title: Dissertation Abstracts International, B (Sciences and Engineering)
Abstract Note: In field trials in the Philippines with Cajanus cajan (preceding crop rice), highest main crop seed yields were obtained with 50 plants/m in rows 30 cm apart, but ratoon crop yields were unaffected by plant density or spatial arrangement. Vigna radiata was poor for intercropping with C. cajan in upland soil; V. unguiculata performed better but suppressed growth of C. cajan. Ratooning C. cajan delayed flowering because of vegetative regrowth and it reduced seed yields compared with those of plants not ratooned. In studies with rice, recommended management gave higher or equal grain yields and better profitability but lower net return per dollar of weeding and transplanting costs than farmers' normal management. Transplanting in rows was unacceptable because of the high labour requirement. In the better environments C. cajan was recommended grown alone or intercropped with V. unguiculata or V. radiata and in poorer environments C. cajan was of use when grown for fodder or firewood.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Wade, L. J.; Douglas, A. C. L.; Foreman, J. W.
Title: Agronomic measures to minimise limitations to grain yield of irrigated and ratooned grain sorghum.
Abstract Note: In several field trials at 9 locations in central Queensland, up to 12 sorghum cultivars were ratooned, and irrigation was applied 8 times to the plant crop and 3 times to the ratoon according to cumulative pan evaporation (full irrigation), 5 times to the plant crop and twice to the ratoon at chosen growth stages (optimum irrigation) or 3 times to the plant crop and once to the ratoon at critical growth stages (supplementary irrigation). Fertilizer was applied in various combinations, with N at 0-300 kg/ha and P at 0-60 kg/ha. Plant density was 50 000-250 000 plants/ha with row spacings of 40-100 cm. At 4 sites at Dawson and Callide, the average plant crop grain yields for Goldrush II, Texas 610SR, Pride, Hylan 4X8, DK55+ and E57+ were 6.69, 7.13, 6.51, 6.59, 6.82 and 6.37 t/ha, respectively, with corresponding ratoon crop yields of 4.24, 3.48, 4.08, 4.75, 4.19 and 3.60 t/ha for row spacings of 90-100 cm. At Emerald, where 12 cultivars were grown, yields obtained with double rows spaced 40 cm apart, in 1-m beds were 40% higher than obtained with single rows 1 m apart. Yields declined with delay in optimum sowing time in early Sep. In the irrigation trial, the optimum irrigation strategy yielded 6.35 t/ha, whereas full irrigation and supplementary irrigation yielded 4.93 and 4.11 t/ha, respectively. N application of 100 kg/ha increased yield of the ratoon crop at one site from 1.50 t/ha (no fertilizer) to 1.76 t/ha. The trials showed that grain yields varied widely; the highest obtained was 9.58 t/ha. It is concluded that higher sorghum yields in central Queensland are commercially achievable with good management practices.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: SUDNOV, P.
Title: Agrotechnique of cultivation of perennial wheats.
Abstract Note: In the number of tillers, growth rate, time of flowering and aftermath formation, early autumn sowings were superior to late autumn sowings, particularly in a dry season. The yield in the first year of growth increased with increasing seeding rate; however, too great rates of seeding (120 kg. per ha. and higher) depressed the plants. In dense sowings the length of stems was increased, but the length of leaves and ear was curtailed. At the same rate of seeding, sowings in furrows were superior to broadcast sowings. Among the methods of additional nutrition, fractional application of fertilizers during tillering, at the jointing phase and in the beginning of flowering, proved to be most effective. Wild NPK, potassium increased the 1, 000-grain weight as compared with other variants, but decreased total seed yield, the highest seed yield being obtained with NP. Chemical analyses showed that the straw of the first cut of perennial rye-wheat hybrids contained 5.19 per cent proteins, 1.60 per cent fat, and 39.48 per cent fibre; still better chemical composition was found in the hay of the second cut, containing 10.25 per cent proteins, 2.31 per cent fat and 27.28 per cent fibre.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: PETROV, O. I.
Title: A. I. Derzavin's sorghum-Johnson grass hybrids as initial material for perennial sorghum.
Publication Title: Trud. Stavropol', nauc. -issled. Inst. sel'sk. Hoz. (Trans. Stavropol'   sci. -res. Inst. Agric.)
Abstract Note: Aimed at producing a new perennial crop for cultivation on sandy soil in drought areas, crosses were made between Sorghum vulgare[Sorghum bicolor] and S. halepense. Some clones of perennial habit were resistant to shedding.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: González-Paleo, L.; Ravetta, D.A.
Title: Allocation patterns and phenology in wild and selected accessions of annual and perennial Physaria (Lesquerella, Brassicaceae)
Abstract Note: Two processes that determine a good performance of plants in arid environments are phenology and resource allocation patterns. With a longer growing season and larger allocation to root, perennials achieve better access to resources and are more resilient to stresses than annuals. In traditional agricultural systems selection for optimal soil nutrient uptake has been a secondary breeding objective, because crops receive subsidies of water and fertilizers. However in arid lands, caution is required during domestication, to avoid changes in structural traits which may be the basis for sustainable production. Due to inherent differences in hierarchy among annual and perennial species, we propose that the changes in phenology and allocation brought about by selection will depend on the life cycle. We performed field studies comparing wild and selected accessions of annual and perennial species of Physaria. Life cycle determined the functional basis of seed yield. In annuals, selection resulted in early anthesis (1 week earlier), a lower allocation to roots and leaves (twofold lower), and an increase in harvest index (an increase of 62%). Selected perennials had higher biomass at maturity (45% higher), linked to a longer reproductive period (3 weeks longer) than their wild relatives. The vegetative allocation found in wild perennials remained unchanged after selection. While annuals selected for seed yield could compromise the capacity for acquisition of resources, selection in perennials did not modify the allocation strategy responsible for their positive adjustment to low resource environments. We found a trade off between seed yield potential and yield stability that resulted in lower performance of selected accessions in low quality environments in relation to their wild relatives.
Manual Tags: ALL(perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE(ar); Anthesis; Arid lands; Brassicaceae; Harvest index; Physaria (angiosperm); relevant; Root; Scopus; search.grain; Selection; SPV; Yield stability

Author: Becker, R.; Meyer, D.; Wagoner, P.; Saunders, R.M.
Title: Alternative crops for sustainable agricultural systems
Abstract Note: The lack of suitable and appropriate crops has been a poorly recognized obstacle to the application of sound agroecological practices in some temperate and tropical regions. Cultivation of traditional hybrid crops in inherently hostile environments forces increased managerial and economic expenditures. Selection of ecologically harmonious crops exploits, rather than opposes natural forces. Based in part on US-AID funded research, we have identified three crops suitable for temperate/tropical cultivation. Amaranthus is recognized in Asia and Central and South America as a food crop that can be grown as a leafy vegetable or as a seed grain in mixed croppings. It does well under a wide variety of conditions using established cultural methods. It is nutritious and highly palatable and, in many areas, is well recognized in the market place. Prosopis species (mesquite) leguminous trees occur worldwide in arid and semi-arid areas. As phreatophytes, they are resistant to drought and high temperature extremes and produce abundant yields of edible beanlike pods. Using the beans from the tree, a variety of attractive, marketable food products have been prepared. We have also identified intermediate wheat-grass, a perennial relative of wheat, as an ecologically and economically attractive alternate crop. It is already a well-established range crop; grown for seed, it becomes a useful grain intercrop. The wholegrain or endosperm mill fractions make excellent tasting, appetizing and attractive baked products. Ongoing agronomic studies indicate it is especially suitable for balancing ecologically unstable areas.
Manual Tags: ALL(perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE(ar); Asia; Drought resistance; full text added; Latin America; mesquite; perennial W/1 grain; relevant; ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.grain; SPV; Sustainable agriculture; wheatgrass

Author: GRIGOR'EVA, N. M.; KUZ'MIN, Z. E.; LANINA, A. V.
Title: An All-Union meeting on distant hybridization in plants and animals.
Abstract Note: At a recent meeting in Moscow, N. V. Cicin named some of the successful cultivars that have arisen from crosses of wheat with rye, with Agropyron and with other Triticum species, discussed methods of overcoming sterility and explained the value of aneuploids. D. D. Breznev described the world collections and the use that had been made of them, leading to the production of over 500 new cultivars of various crop plants. Ja. S. Nesterov outlined the wide crosses that have been made in fruits and some of the problems associated with them. A. S. Jablokov stressed the importance of distant crosses in inducing heterosis in forest trees. A. F. Sulyndin reviewed work on wide crosses in cereals, and mentioned winter forms of Triticum durum and valuable segregates from crosses between different amphidiploid wheat hybrids, some of which have large ears, short straw, high tillering capacity and resistance to lodging and diseases. I. D. Mustafaev discussed the interrelationships between species of Triticum, Aegilops and SEcale and the natural hybrids frequently found in Azerbaijan. Several speakers referred to the Triticum-Agropyron hybrids of N. V. Cicin and described the most successful, some of which give three crops of green matter and excelled all other forage plants in hay yields, while others show a wide range in gluten contents and other factors determining baking quality and in resistance to frost and diseases; some are hardier than standard wheat cultivars such as Ul'janovka or Lutescens 329; P. P. Bereznoj reported on mutations induced in the amphidiploids, the proportion, which varied from 0.90 to 10.82%, being greatest after treatment of the octoploids; monosomics produced in back crosses with wheat were described by G. L. Jacevskij and meiotic irregularities in the hybrids by F. M. Skutina and I. N. Golubov-skaja. Forms resembling T. durum arising in crosses between octoploid and hexaploid Trificale, and described by M. A. Mahalin and E. D. Gruzdeva, proved resistant to frost and fungal diseases, bore 70-90 large grains per ear and had a protein content of 17-18%; hybrids of rye with A. glaucum were also described. V. V. Hvostova stated that none of the 56-chromosome Triticum-Agropyron or Triticale hybrids is fertile enough to be approved as a cultivar. Several speakers referred to Triticum-Agropyron hybrids that persist for 2-4 years and others to a successful perennial rye. Promising new wheats with high yields arising from back crosses of T. aestivum x T. durum to T. aestivum were described by A. M. Gabbasov. M. A. Ali-Zade and R. T. Alieva reported that interspecific wheat hybrids were intermediate between the parents in RNA content but did not differ from them in DNA. A spontaneous pea x vetch hybrid described by N. A. Sobolev and V. P. Bugrij was said to cross with both parents. B. S. Moskov and G. A. Makarova produced Raphanobrassica hybrids from cabbage grafts on radish; the F 1 displayed heterosis and various meiotic irregularities, the F 2 contained triploids, aneuploids and amphidiploids, the last being vigourous, frost resistant and high in vitamin C [ascorbic acid]; the diploids contained some forms that bred true and contained up to 130 mg. % vitamin C [ascorbic acid] in the leaves while having a root like a radish. S. M. Bukasov mentioned several hundred potato cultivars bred by interspecific crossing and analysed compatibility relationships between different series of section TUberarium in the genus Solanum. A. Ja. Kameraz outlined the use made in the Soviet Union of the primitive and wild potato species of Latin America, which contain resistance to Phytophthora, the aggressive races of Synchytrium endobioticum, nematodes and other diseases and to frost. E. I. Mamedov and others discussed interspecific crosses in cotton and the successful use of gibberellin and vitamin B 1K. A. Vysockij described a trispecific hybrid involving Hibiscus esculentus[Abelmoschus esculentus]; it combined the long lint of Gossypium barbadense with bolls weighing 8.5 g., earliness and high yield derived from 108F; other hybrids had double flowers, wilt resistance, glabrous seed and other properties from the Hibiscus, mallow and other plants participating as pollinators; a constant hybrid with marked heterosis has been obtained from crosses of Hibiscus species with n = 36 and n = 16. G. I. Belova described meiotic irregularities leading to sterility in distant hybrids in cotton. G. V. Pustovojt gave details of the resistance to diseases and pests in 24 wild sunflower species. M. F. Ternovskij referred to a large collection of Nicotiana species, various methods of overcoming their incompatibility with N. tabacum and N. rustica and the production from them of cultivars resistant to Peronospora tabacina and Erysiphe cichoracearum and to tobacco mosaic; N. didebia, resistant also to Thielaviopsis basicola, was also described. Various other speakers gave reports on interspecific hybrids of tobacco, one of those from N. rustica being resistant to tip chlorosis. G. S. Voskresenskaja referred to an amphidiploid Brassica juncea exceeding the control by 2.75 c. in seed yield and by 108 kg. in oil yield per ha. ; crossing B. juncea with winter rape gave a new crop, winter mustard, equal to winter rape in hardiness but higher in yield and described by V. I. Spota. Several speakers referred to interspecific hybrids of mint, lavender and tomato, some of the last being resistant to virus diseases. Several speakers mentioned a number of fruit cultivars bred by interspecific or intergeneric crossing, which included vines with high yields and quality derived from Vitis amurensis; others referred to wide crosses in nuts and in forest trees. T. S. Kantor reported the use of chemical mutagens on interspecific Fragaria hybrids and V. I. Ostapenko the application of high-frequency radioactive rays in overcoming incompatibility in fruit crosses.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: TianJu, Ren; JingYong, Li; XiaoChun, Zhang; PeiHua, Wang; GuangPing, Yu; Yao, Lu
Title: Analysis of combining ability and heritability of ratooning qualities in hybrid rice F 1.
Publication Title: Southwest China Journal of Agricultural Sciences
Abstract Note: To accelerate the breeding procedure of strong ratooning quality combinations, the combining ability and heritability of ratooning quality of hybrid F 1 rice were analysed by NC II design using 6 cytoplasmic male sterile (CMS) lines and 6 restorer lines for 3 times. The results showed that the general (GCA) and specific combining ability (SCA) of ratooning quality of hybrid rice F 1 were all significant, which were controlled by the additive and non-additive gene effects. The additive effect was predominant with higher narrow-sense heritability, which was affected by the environment and planting technique. The contribution rate of CMS lines and restorer lines to GCA depended on mean squares size. The relation between SCA and phenotypic value was positively significant. If SCA of cross was higher, GCA of one parent at least was also higher, showing that the parents with higher GCA could be used to breed hybrid combination with higher SCA. The CMS lines Fu 76A, G46A, 182A and II-32A, which had significant GCA, and the restorer lines 130, Minghui 63 and Duoxi 1 could be used as parents to breed combinations with strong ratooning quality.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: TianJu, Ren; XiaoChun, Zhang; PeiHua, Wang; JingYong, Li
Title: Analysis of combining ability effect and the dominant characteristics of crosses with high yields in twice of hybrid mid-season and ratooning rice.
Publication Title: Southwest China Journal of Agricultural Sciences
Abstract Note: Using 6 CMS lines and 6 restorer lines for 3 times, a NC II model was designed to form 108 hybrid crosses. Among them, 12 hybrid crosses were selected whose yields in one season or total yield in two seasons were significantly higher that of the control Shanyou 63. Compared with Shanyou 63, these crosses showed earlier maturity, larger green canopy, more efficient transfer of photosynthetic production, higher grain-to-straw ratio, plant height and bearing rate, stronger resistance to lodging, and longer ratooning duration. Both general (GCA) and specific combining ability (SCA) effects significantly influenced the yields of the main crop and ratooning rice, and its total yields in two seasons, but GCA effect was dominant. There was significantly positive relationship among the value of GCA, SCA and total combining ability (TCA) to grain weight per plant. Therefore, the crosses with higher total yields in two seasons had larger value of TCA. The results showed that TCA value can be used as one of the indexes to select high yielding crosses in both mid-season and ratooning rice.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Haffke, S.; Kusterer, B.; Fromme, F.J.; Roux, S.; Hackauf, B.; Miedaner, T.
Title: Analysis of Covariation of Grain Yield and Dry Matter Yield for Breeding Dual Use Hybrid Rye
Abstract Note: Winter rye (Secale cereale L.) is becoming increasingly important as substrate for biogas production in Central Europe. Dry matter yield has evolved as a breeding goal comparably important to the traditional grain yield. We analyzed the covariation between both traits and tested other agronomic traits for their correlation to dry matter yield that could be used for prediction of biomass yield. A set of 258 experimental hybrids were tested for dry matter yield harvested at late milk stage and grain yield harvested at full ripening at three to four locations in Germany in 2011 and 2012. We observed a wide range of dry matter yield (10-24 Mg ha-1) and grain yield (6-15 Mg ha-1) among testcross progenies. Genetic variances were significantly (P < 0.01) different from zero for all traits. High entry-mean heritabilities (0.92-0.94) were found for plant height measurements and moderate heritabilities for grain and dry matter yield (0.52 and 0.49, respectively). Relative efficiencies for selection of dry matter yield estimated by second (EC 51-55) and third (EC 73) measurements of plant height were 1.24 and 0.98 respectively, compared to 0.52 for grain yield. Indirect selection for high dry matter yield using late plant height measurements should be successful. Using grain yield for indirect selection was less effective. The observed broad genetic variation for biomass yield in elite hybrid rye gives good prospects for the use as a resource of renewable energy. Plant height is a good predictor of dry matter yield but should be selected together with improved lodging resistance.
Manual Tags: ALL(perennial W/1 (rye OR secale) AND NOT ("rye grass" OR "rye-grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE(ar); Biogas production; Biomass; Correlation; Correlation methods; dry matter yield; Genes; Indirect selection; Lodging resistance; Relative efficiency; relevant; Renewable energies; Rye; Scopus; search.rye; Secale cereale; SPV; Substrates

Author: Zhang, Ting; Li, Lijuan; Hu, Fengyi; Zhao, Xiuqin; Fu, Binying; Yang, Daichang
Title: Analysis of ESTs from a Normalized cDNA Library of the Rhizome Tip of Oryza longistaminata
Abstract Note: Oryza longistaminata, a perennial wild rice species with an AA genome, is characterized by the presence of rhizomatous stems. The rhizomatous trait in rice was previously shown to be quantitatively controlled by many genes, but the molecular mechanism related to rhizome development is still unknown. In the present study, expressed sequence tags (ESTs) generated from rhizome tips of O. longistaminata were collected and analyzed. A total of 10,283 complimentary deoxyribunucleic acid clones were randomly sequenced, which generated 10,136 raw sequences, and finally, 4,419 unisequences with diverse functional categories were generated. These unisequences were mapped onto the Oryza sativa genome, which revealed that 4,285 (96.97%) and 4,151 (93.94%) of the unisequences were alignable to the japonica and indica genomic sequences, respectively, with > 80% sequence identity. Additionally, 41 unisequences showed four typical types of alternative splicing patterns. More than 600 simple sequence repeats were identified in these unisequences. A subset of unisequences were physically colocalized onto rhizome-related quantitative trait locus intervals in rice and sorghum, and one gene, OLRR1, was further confirmed to be enriched in the rhizome tip and young leaf by real-time polymerase chain reaction and in situ hybridization. Unisequences reported in this study provide valuable data for molecular dissection of the rhizomatous growth habit in O. longistaminata.
Manual Tags: ALL(perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE(ar); Expressed sequence tags; japonica; Oryza; Oryza longistaminata; Oryza sativa; relevant; Rhizome; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); Unisequence; Web of Science; Zizania

Author: YuHong, Hou; GuoFeng, Hou; Hua, Qi; ChuanYong, Chen; XiangLing, Li; Ming, Zhao; ShuTing, Dong
Title: Analysis of photothermic resource use efficiency and potential increases in crop yields in high-yielding regions of eastern Asia.
Abstract Note: In agronomic management, photothermic resources will play an increasingly important role in boosting crop yields to meet growing demands. This study explored photothermic resource use efficiency and predicted the highest theoretical yield of four crop types (maize, rice, ratoon rice and wheat) in the high-yielding regions of the Northeast plain, Huai Hai Lyrics valley and Yangtze River valley of China spanning a latitudinal range from N25.48° to N45.32°. The radiation production potential (RPP) and thermal production potential (TPP) of the four crop types were analyzed, using indexes of radiation production potential equivalence (RPPE) and thermal production potential equivalence (TPPE). The results showed that RPPE and TPPE varied with crop type, harvest zone and high-yielding areas. For the different crop types, the RPPE and TPPE of ratoon rice (0.7406, 0.7848) were the highest, while the RPPE of winter wheat (0.3041) and TPPE of rice (0.4955) were the lowest. The theoretical yield of maize (15,408.2 kg hm -2) was the highest while that of winter wheat (10,273.4 kg hm -2) was the lowest, and the theoretical yield of ratoon rice (12,245.2 kg hm -2) was higher than that of rice (11,117.7 kg hm -2). By harvest zone, the RPPE of the double harvest zone (0.5105) and TPPE of the single harvest zone (0.7015) were the highest, while the RPPE and TPPE of the triple harvest zone (0.4688, 0.5607) were the lowest. By area, the RPPE of Youxi (0.7406) and TPPE of Huadian (0.9089) were the highest, while the RPPE of Lianyungang (0.3607) and TPPE of Changsha (0.4702) were the lowest. Environmental parameters also impacted crop yield, where fewer hours of solar radiation caused a decline in RPP, while higher air temperatures increased TPP. Radiation was the limiting factor for summer maize, late rice and ratoon rice, while temperature was the limiting factor for winter wheat, spring maize and early rice; radiation was the limiting factor for the triple harvest zone, while temperature was the limiting factor for single and double harvest zones; finally, radiation was the limiting factor for Youxi, Changsha, Jiangsu, Wuxue and Haicheng, while temperature was the limiting factor for Harbin, Huadian, Laizhou, Xinxiang, Wuqiao and Lianyungang. Agricultural techniques also affected yield, where the optimum cultivation models were found to be high density double-planting for summer maize, cultivation in earth furrows for winter wheat, simultaneous optimization of the use of radiation and heat by ratoon rice and boosting of sink capacity and source capacity for rice. In conclusion, latitudinal differences in photothermic resources are poorly utilized, even in high-yielding regions, meaning that all regions including those that already meet their annual targets have the potential to further improve yields. Therefore, crops should be sown early to improve heat use efficiency in areas of low latitude while suitable sowing and harvesting dates should be chosen for high latitudes to improve radiation use efficiency. At the same time, the highest-yielding cultivation mode should be matched to the latitude, such as spring maize planting in Huadian, winter-wheat planting in Laizhou and ratoon rice planting in Youxi.
Manual Tags: Agriculture; ALL(ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); China; Crop; Photothermic resource use efficiency; Radiation production potential; Radiation production potential equivalence; relevant; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; Thermal production potential; Thermal production potential equivalence; Triticum aestivum; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science; yield; Zea mays

Author: Bassani, Tiago Packer; Breda, Luciani
Title: Analysis of production costs, productivity and profitability on three technologies of cultivation of irrigated rice on the farm Sao Sebastiao, Querencia do Norte, PR
Abstract Note: This study aims to verify and analyze the technical and economic viability of irrigated rice in face of three technology models of cultivation: a) first planting, b) second planting c) ratoon, describing and distinguishing the technology models and analyzing and comparing production costs. The study was conduct in the farm "Sao Sebastiao", municipality of "Querencia do Norte". First, were described the technologies and later the production costs per hectare (ha) for each technology adopted. Among the three technological models, which the highest cost of production is the first planting, along with the most revenue. But as the study seeks to determine which of the two other technologies (second planting and ratoon) is the more viable, it's observed that the ratoon technology has the lowest cost of production and most profitability, moreover, is the ratoon cultivation there is lower wear and tear of machinery and equipment. So, conclude that the more viable technology both in production conditions, financial and procedural, is the ratoon technology. In the conditions presented this technology is the most appropriate and profitable to be adopted after the crop of the first planting technology.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Jian-fu, Zhang; Yong-sheng, Zhu; Qiu-hua, Cai; Chuan-ying, Zhuo; Shang-shou, Zhang; Rong-he, Zheng; Hua-an, Xie
Title: Analysis on Correlationship of Net Photosynthetic Rate with Yield and Its Components of Ratooning Rice
Abstract Note: The net photosynthetic rate of flag leaf was measured at the filling stage and maturity stage of ratooning rice with thirteen hybrid rice combinations as materials. The net photosynthetic rate at the filling stage of ratooning rice was significantly higher than that at the maturity stage, and the difference in the photosynthetic rate at the filling stage was more than that at the maturity stage among all the combinations, and the net photosynthetic rate was significantly different at the same stage among different combinations. The net photoynthetic rate at the filling stage was positively correlated with the yield of ratooning rice, and that at the maturity stage was significantly and negatively correlated with the yield of ratooning rice. In addition, the net photosynthetic rate at the filling stage was significantly and positively correlated with the seed setting rate.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: RuiYu, Lin; HongFei, Chen; JiaYao, Deng; YiYuan, Liang; KangJing, Liang; WenXiong, Lin
Title: Analysis on energy accumulation and calorific value of early-season rice and its ratooning rice under different cultivation models.
Abstract Note: A new rice hybrid, Youhang I, was used to analyse accumulated dry weight, energy fixation and calorific value in early-season rice and its ratooning rice under super high-yield cultivation (SHC) and conventional cultivation (CC) models. The results showed that accumulated dry weight in the plants at mature stage under SHC was 2220.04 and 1697.62 g/m 2 for early-season and ratooning rice, respectively, being 1.26- and 1.29-fold higher than that under CC. Calorific value in leaves, grains, sheaths and culms of the plants were 14 848.7-18 494.9, 15 810.3-17 438.0, 14 029.1-17 039.6 and 14 405.4-17 576.5 J/g under SHC, respectively. The calorific values in leaves and grains were significantly higher than those in culm and sheath, but no significant difference was found under the 2 cultivation models. The accumulated energy in the plants at mature stage was 35.71 and 26.24 MJ/m 2 under SHC for early season and ratooning rice, respectively, being 27.4 and 29.6% higher than that under CC. The ratio of accumulated energy partitioned into grains was 52.7% for early-season rice under SHC, which was 1.2% higher than that under CC, and for ratooning rice (51.5%), there was no significant difference between the 2 models. During grain filling, the ratio of energy remobilized from leaves, culms and sheaths was 39.7% for early-season rice under SHC, being significantly higher than that under CC (23.1%), and the value was 16.9% for ratooning rice, which was also higher than that under CC (14.7%). It implied that the energy flow in rice under SHC was much more smooth than that under CC. In addition, at yellow mature stage, the energy exportation ratio of the root was 7.9% under SHC, being obviously lower than that of CC, it was ensured for grain filling and regeneration of ratooning rice, and the energy of grains remobilized from the stubble of ratooning rice was 25.9%, indicating that the grain yield under SHC relied less on the photosynthate in the period of grain filling, which was beneficial to steady and high yield of ratooning rice.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Li, J.X.; Yu, S.B.; Xu, C.G.; Tan, Y.F.; Gao, Y.J.; Li, X.H.; Zhang, Q.
Title: Analyzing quantitative trait loci for yield using a vegetatively replicated F2 population from a cross between the parents of an elite rice hybrid
Abstract Note: Although F2s are the most informative populations for genetic analysis, it has been difficult to use F2 populations directly for QTL analysis because it is usually difficult to assess the reliability of the data, due to an inability to estimate the experimental errors. In this study, we performed a QTL analysis for yield and yield-component traits of an F2 population based on data from replicated field trials over 2 years using vegetative shoots of ratooned plants, making use of the ratooning habit of rice. The objective of this study was to explore the possibility of conducting QTL analyses directly based on an F2 population by means of ratooning plants. The experimental population was from a cross between 'Zhenshan 97' and 'Minghui 63', the parents of 'Shanyou 63', an elite rice hybrid widely grown in China. A genetic linkage map containing 151 molecular markers was constructed for QTL mapping. A total of 20 distinct QTLs were detected; eight of these were detected in both years and remaining 12 in only 1 year. Compared with the results of our previous analysis of the F(2:3) families from the same cross, it was shown that most of the QTLs detected in the ratooned F2 population were also detected in the F(2:3) population. However, the estimates of both additive and dominant types of genetic effects for many of the QTLs based on F2 ratoons were substantially larger than those based on F(2:3) families. The results indicate that vegetatively ratooned F2 populations may have considerable utility in the mapping of QTLs, especially if dominant types of gene actions are of concern, although there were certain technical limitations in making use of such populations in the experiments.

Author: JOHNSON, L. P. V.; MCLENNAN, H. A.
Title: An attempt to hybridize annual and perennial Avena species.
Abstract Note: Success in hybridizing annual Triticum and perennial Agropyron species, and the interest in the production of new perennial forage crops prompted attempts to hybridize annual and perennial Avena species. Results were negative.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: MALYGIN, JU N.
Title: An enthusiast for distant hybridization.
Abstract Note: An outline of the work of N. V. Cicin mentions his Triticum-Agropyron hybrids, which include successful winter and spring cultivars and some perennial wheats giving crops for two to four successive years; various other cereal hybrids, including Triticum * Elymus, Secale * Agropyron and Triticale; and interspecific Nicotiana hybrids resistant to tip chlorosis.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: MIHAILOVSKII, V.
Title: A new cultivated plant, perennial sorghum.
Abstract Note: Hybridization of Sorghum halepense (L.) Pers. has been carried out since 1936 with a large number of cultivated varieties of S. technicum (Koern.) Roshev., S. vulgare (L.) Pers., S. saccharatum (L.), Pers., S. japonicum (Hack) Roshev., S. durra Stapf and S. Caffrorum Beauv. Only combinations involving S annual and f S. halepense were successful. The hybrid origin was definitely established only in the combination S. halepense * S. saccharatum (two varieties). The F 2 generation developed slowly, but in growth vigour the hybrids exceeded the parent plant. In F 2, forms with cultivated panicles were found. In the height of plants and forage yield, 40-chromosome hybrids (a part of No. 110 * S. halepense) were inferior to 30-chromosome hybrids (all " Orange " * S. halepense and some of the other combinations), but they produced larger amounts of seeds. Vigorous halepense roots dominated in F 2, but several forms with shorter and less vigourous roots could be selected; only the latter could be regarded as desirable.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: EDWARDS, D. C.
Title: A new fodder crop : perennial Kavirondo sorghum.
Abstract Note: The species, grown experimentally during the last 5 years, results from a natural hybrid between a native cultivated grain sorghum and Sorghum verticilliflorum, a widely distributed wild sorghum of Kenya. Trials have shown that the plant is a perennial of considerable duration, that a heavy seed crop is produced and establishment from seed is exceptionally easy. Information is supplied on yields and chemical composition and use of the crop in drier, mixed farming areas, as a highly productive fodder and in a temporary ley, is notable. The species does not seem prone to develop cyanogenetic properties.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: GORGIDZE, A. D.; NAZAROVA, E. A.
Title: A new original form of wheat-rye hybrid.
Publication Title: Rec. Georg. bot. Soc. Acad. Sci. Georg. SSR
Abstract Note: On crossing the Colchis wheat Triticum palaeo-colchicum var. chvamlicum with Derzavin's perennial rye, a self-fertile, stable hybrid was obtained which combines the morphological characters of both parents. It has a two-year developmental cycle and is amphidiploid (2n = 42).

Author: JAKOVLEV, A. V.
Title: An experiment on growing perennial wheat in southern Kazahstan.
Abstract Note: The perennial wheat variety 2, obtained by crossing the winter wheat Lutescens 329 with Agropyron glaucum[Elymus hispidus], proved productive when grown for forage on irrigated land at Alma-Ata. It yielded up to 141 c. forage per ha. and was hardy, notably in the first year. It showed resistance to lodging, rusts, bunt and smut.

Author: LiYun, Chen; YingHui, Xiao; WenBang, Tang; DaiMiao, Liu
Title: An ideal planting pattern for the adjustment of grain yield structure - middle season rice and its ratoon rice.
Abstract Note: Two-line rice hybrid Peiliangyou 500 was ratooned after growing as a middle-season crop. Total yield of the main and ratoon crop was 12.08 t/ha, which was 37.5% higher than yield of the control cultivar Shanyou 63. Grain quality was also better in the hybrid rice.

Abstract Note: The above conversion was induced in the winter wheat S2, a hybrid of the perennial wheat M2 x Triticum aestivum 'Vetvistyj slfaat' [Branch-eared Slfaat] x T. aestivum 'Karmir Slfaat', as follows. Unvernalized seed of
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Liu, B. G.; Zhang, X. Q.; Wang, G. M.; Wan, Z. L.; Huang, Y. Q.; Ren, C. F.
Title: An investigation of the distribution of photosynthates during the ripening stage of the main crop and the ratooning period of rice cultivar Shanyou 63.
Abstract Note: In a experiment with rice cv. Shanyou 63 using 14C tracer techniques, it was shown that more than half of the photosynthates produced during the ripening stage of the main crop were transported to the panicles while the rest (39-49%) remained in the vegetative organs, chiefly in the stems and leaves. 8.2-10.6% was eventually transferred to the panicles of the ratoon crop, mostly to those from the 2nd and 3rd nodes. The photosynthetic products formed by the ratoon crop were largely delivered to the panicles, with those from the 2nd, 3rd and 4th nodes from the bottom as the major recipients.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Sakagami, J.-I.; Isoda, A.; Nojima, H.; Takasaki, Y.
Title: Annuality and perenniality characteristics and variation in Oryza sativa L. and O. glaberrima steud
Abstract Note: The growth and survival after maturity of 26 cultivars of japonica, 37 cultivars of indica, and 41 cultivars of O. glaberrima were examined to clarify the annuality and perenniality of two cultivated species. These cultivars were grown in pots and under light of natural day length with a suitable temperature regime. They were left uncut till 225 days after maturity, approximately one year after seeding. The number of new tillers appearing from maturity to 225 days after maturity was greatest in japonica and lowest in O. glabmima. The number of living tillers increased with time for a short while after maturity and then decreased, although in japonica, it increased again 120 days after maturity and thereafter. The survival duration of cultivars after maturity was clearly longer for O. sativa than for O. glaberrima. In japonica, all of the Japanese cultivars and all of the foreign cultivars except two survived longer than 225 days after maturity. In indica, most cultivars survived longer than 225 days after maturity, but several cultivars died in the early stage after maturity. In O. glaberrima, all the cultivars except one died before 225 days after maturity. From these results, it was concluded that O. sativa included both annual and perennial cultivars, whereas O. glaberrima was monocarpic annual. It was inferred that O. sativa inherited its genetical characteristics from O. rufipogon, which was thought to be the ancestor of O. sativa and included both annuals and perennials, and O. glaberrima inherited its characteristics from O. barthii, which was annual.

Author: Pimentel, David; Cerasale, David; Stanley, Rose C.; Perlman, Rachel; Newman, Elise M.; Brent, Lincoln C.; Mullan, Amanda; Chang, Debbie Tai-I
Title: Annual vs. perennial grain production
Abstract Note: Annual grain crops are planted on about 70% of the world's cropland and provide 80% of the world's food. Currently annual grains dominate grain production. Perennial grains offer many important opportunities to produce grains in a more environmentally, economically, and energetically sound manner. Thus, major research efforts are needed to develop perennial grains to help feed the growing and malnourished world population. These grains would also aid in diversifying agriculture.

Author: A, AGUIAR P. A.
Title: ANNUAL YIELD POTENTIAL OF GRAIN SORGHUM SORGHUM-BICOLOR UNDER IRRIGATED CONDITIONS
Abstract Note: The annual sorthum (S. bicolor L. Moench) grain production potential of 8 commercial hybrids and 2 varieties was evaluated under irrigated conditions in the Sao Francisco Valley [Brazil]. A double row system spaced 40 cm apart in beds of 70 cm width, with approximately 15 plants/m in each row. The hybrids tested were more productive than the varieties. A gradual decrease in the average yield was obtained from the 1st harvest to the 1st and 2nd ratoon cropping, with 9313, 6476 and 3602 kg/ha, respectively. The total average yield from the 3 harvests reached 19,391 kg/ha, indicating the technical viability of exploring grain sorghum under irrigated conditions.

Title: A note on differential behaviour in the ratooning ability of some photoperiod insensitive rice genotypes.

Author: PAL, M.; KAUSHIK, S. K.
Title: A note on ratoon-ing of sorghum in Northern India.
Abstract Note: Sorghum cv. CSH-1 and Swarna sown in early May and harvested 74-80 days later, yielded approximately 500hkg fresh fodder/ha. The ratoon crops of CSH-1 and Swarna yielded 61 and 60 hkg grain/ha, respectively, compared with 43.2 and 22.2 hkg when sown as late crops. The increased yields in ratoon crops were attributed to an increase in tillers/plant.

Author: Palchamy, A.
Title: A note on the yield and duration of ratooned rice varieties.
Abstract Note: Rice cv. Bhavani and Vaigai sown in end June matured in 133 and 107 days and gave paddy yields of 8.00 and 6.54 t/ha, resp. their ratoon crops matured in 76 and 70 days and gave yields of 4.85 and 3.29 t, resp.

Author: TUMANJAN, M. G.
Title: A perennial seed-cultivated rye in Armenia.
Abstract Note: A new form was found at an elevation of 1700-1800 m. which differed in several, chiefly cultivated, characters from the usual forms of Secale montanum. It may have arisen either through natural hybridization, but is more probably a remnant of the perennial rye cultivated in Armenia before the war. This form is described by the author as S. Daralagesi sp. n.
