Author: SOPRANIS Y PENASCO, F. S. de
Title: A perennial wheat appears to have been obtained in Russia.
Abstract Note: An account is given of a hybrid of Agropyron elongatum[Elymus elongatus] and wheat, produced by N. V. Cicin at Omsk, Siberia. The new form of wheat thus produced is said to persist for 5 years in the same field, to be resistant to drought and rust although as yet insufficiently resistant to frost, and to give extremely satisfactory yields. Information is quoted from N. E. Hansen, North Dakota Agric. Exp. Sta. (reference not given).
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: ShuE, Huang; YingChun, Li; JianMin, Yin
Title: Application of "3S" technology in climatic feasibility study of ratooning paddy growing in Jiangxi Province.
Abstract Note: Remote sensing, geographic information system and global positioning system were used to study the climatic feasibility of ratooning paddy in Jiangxi Province, China. This paper presents a synthetic climatic division of ratooning rice production and provides scientific bases for the extension and development of ratooning rice.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Ichii, Masahiko; Kuwata, Hikaru
Title: Application of Ratoon to a Test of Agronomic Characters in Rice Breeding. I. Variation in Ratoon Ability and Its Relation to Agronomic Characters of Mother Plant
Abstract Note: 30 cultivars of paddy were growh in a randomized block design with 4 replications. The rice plants were cut at 5cm above the ground at 4 different growth stages, i, e. 10, 20, 30 and 40 days after headingf. Ratoon weight, ratoon height and percentage of ratoon tillers to that of mother plant, were recorded 40 days after cutting. With respect to the 3 ratoon characteristics a significant decrease was observed to occur when the cutting time was delayed from 10 to 20 days after heading. The increase in the subsequent cutting was less marked. Analysis of variance suggests that ratoon weight, ratoon height and percentage of ratton tillers are heritable. In cuttings made 10 and 20 days after heading, there was a positive and highly significant phenotypic correlation between percentage of ripened grains of mother plant and these ratoon traits. Heritabilities in the broad sense for the ratoon traits became higher in the order, ratoon weight, ratoon height, percen-tage of ratoon tillers. Moreover, the heritability of percentage of ratoon tillers was nearly equal to that of culm length and panicle length. These facts show that ripening ability of rice plant may be tested by observing the ratoon, especially percentage of ratoon tillers.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: ChangMin, Zheng
Title: A preliminary study of growth and development of ratooned rice and its yield components.
Abstract Note: The growth characteristics of ratooned rice in Fushun County, Sichuan, show that its development period is very short with rapid production of panicles after ratooning. In the ratoon crop in Fushun panicle production took as little as 25-30 days. Yield was related to the number of tillers produced, the grain number/panicle, the proportion of effective panicles and the 1000-grain weight. Yields were lower than from the main rice crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Feng, R. Z.
Title: A preliminary study on the distribution, occurrence and fluctuation of rice root nematodes.
Abstract Note: Hirshmanniella spp. was distributed in all rice growing regions of Guangxi, China. Nematode numbers found in late season rice roots were higher than those in early season rice and the maximum number were found from tillering stage to booting stage. Nematodes overwinter in undecayed roots of rice stubble, ratooning rice roots, as well as in grass roots. There were more females than males or juveniles.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Bell, Lindsay W.; Byrne (nee Flugge), Felicity; Ewing, Mike A.; Wade, Len J.
Title: A preliminary whole-farm economic analysis of perennial wheat in an Australian dryland farming system
Abstract Note: The development of perennial wheat could have a number of advantages for improving the sustainability of Australian dryland agricultural systems. The profitability that might be expected from perennial wheat of different types was investigated using MIDAS (Model of an Integrated Dryland Agricultural System), a bioeconomic model of a mixed crop/livestock farming system. Although perennial wheat may produce a lower grain yield and quality than annual wheat, it is expected inputs of fertiliser, herbicide and sowing costs will be lower. Perennial wheat used solely for grain production was not selected as part of an optimal farm plan under the standard assumptions. In contrast, dual-purpose perennial wheat that produces grain and additional forage during summer and autumn than annual wheat can increase farm profitability substantially (AU$20/ha over the whole farm) and 20% of farm area was selected on the optimal farm plan under standard assumptions. Forage from perennial wheat replaced stubble over summer and grain supplement at the break of season and increased farm stock numbers. The additional value added by grazing also reduced the relative yield required for perennial wheat to be profitable. This analysis suggests perennial wheat used for the dual purposes of grain and forage production could be developed as a profitable option for mixed crop/livestock producers.

Author: Medappa, C. K.; Mahadevappa, M.
Title: A ratoon crop of Intan paddy in Coorg is possible.
Abstract Note: In Coorg district, Karnataka, a ratoon crop of rice cv. Intan harvested on 30 Jan. gave paddy yields of 1.67 t/ha in 109 days.

Author: Wolbert-Haverkamp, Matthias; Musshoff, Oliver
Title: Are short rotation coppices an economically interesting form of land use? A real options analysis
Abstract Note: Short rotation coppice (SRC) is intensively discussed as being an economical and ecological advantageous alternative to traditional agricultural land use. In various countries, farmers have been encouraged through incentives to cultivate SRC. Nevertheless, they often do not switch from conventional land use to SRC, even if SRC is relatively beneficial according to the net present value (NPV) rule. Therefore, farmers do not follow the classical investment theory. A relatively new theory is the real options approach (ROA). The ROA takes further aspects like irreversibility of the investment costs, flexibility regarding investment timing, and uncertainty of the investment returns into account, which the NPV rule ignores. In the case of SRC, investment (conversion) triggers when a farmer should switch to SRC following the ROA can be higher than those following the NPV rule. As it is often the case in real options applications, decision makers’ possibility to disinvest in general and farmers’ possibility to reconvert, in particular within the useful lifetime of SRC, is not considered. We build a model to calculate the conversion triggers for switching from annual crop production to SRC following the ROA. We consider the opportunity to reconvert the land and evaluate the respective effects on the conversion triggers according to the ROA. Furthermore, we analyze the effect of a former governmental incentive, in terms of an investment subsidy, on the conversion triggers of both theories. Our calculations show that following the ROA, a farmer should change land use to SRC more slowly than when following the NPV rule. Furthermore, neglecting the reconversion possibility would cause considerable bias amongst the results. The consideration of investment subsidies diminishes the conversion triggers of both theories. We conclude that the ROA can at least partially explain farmers’ inertia of converting to SRC.
Manual Tags: Genetic algorithms; Investment subsidy; Land conversion; Net present value; perennial W/1 (rye OR secale) AND NOT ("rye grass" OR "rye-grass" OR ryegrass); Real options approach; relevant; ScienceDirect; search.rye; Short rotation coppice; SPV

Author: Li, C. C.
Title: Artificial chromosome doubling of ratooning haploid rice plants and genetic observation of their progenies.
Abstract Note: Spontaneous chromosome doubling averaged 0.2% in tillers removed from haploid indica plants and planted singly. The plants had been derived from anther callus of IR24 X Juanyedao 26 and were cut after heading and allowed to regrow to 15-20 cm. When the roots of ratooning plants were soaked in 1000 p.p.m. colchicine for 24 h prior to transplanting, chromosome doubling was about 50%. In the first generation after doubling (D 1) a few small grains formed, while in the D 2 and D 3, grain number and size were restored to normal.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Michalkova, N.
Title: A scientific provement on the positive effects of the rye bread on the human health.
Abstract Note: Proximate composition and concn. of beta-glucans were determined in flour from 5 rye varieties cultivated in Bulgaria (Viselo, Evolo, Millenium, Danaya and a perennial rye variety) harvested in 2007. beta-Glucan concn. found was around 2% which was relatively high compared with values reported in the literature. Flour from Evolo rye had the highest beta-glucan levels (2.68%), followed by Viselo (2.59%) while flour from perennial rye had the lowest (1.78%). Results indicate that bread made from Bulgarian rye flour represents a source of health-promoting beta-glucans.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: Anonymous
Title: A short account of the research work done during 1944 at the Institute of Grain Husbandry S.E. U.S.S.R. of the Order of the Red Labour Banner.
Publication Title: Byull. Inst. zern. Khoz. Yugo.-Vost. SSSR
Abstract Note: Wheat varieties of the Lutescens, Albidum, Milturum, Erythrospermum and Hostianum types have been produced, the yields of which have, on trial, exceeded those of standard varieties adopted by various districts. They include 17 varieties of spring and three of winter wheat. One variety of rye, Volzanka No, 7, still undergoing trials, has been produced. Reference is made to supplementary pollination by artificial means, the practice of which has resulted in augmenting the yield by 1 to 3-5 centners per ha. The breeding of millet continues, and one promising new variety has appeared, the vegetative period of which has been prolonged; by thus extending the harvesting period, the loss of seed which accompanies it can be reduced. The yield of seeds and their content of oil are being increased in the sunflowers, three varieties of which have been bred. Perennial wheat varieties, resulting from the hybridization of wheat and Agropyron spp., have also been bred. I. Z.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Lammer, D.; Cai, X.; Arterburn, M.; Chatelain, J.; Murray, T.; Jones, S.
Title: A single chromosome addition from Thinopyrum elongatum confers a polycarpic, perennial habit to annual wheat
Abstract Note: Annual wheat displays monocarpic senescence, but amphiploids between wheat and its wild perennial relatives in the genus Thinopyrum generally display a polycarpic, perennial growth habit. In order to determine the chromosomal basis of this phenomenon, life-history characteristics were examined using Chinese Spring wheat and a complete Thinopyrum elongatum (2n=2x=14) chromosome addition series in a Chinese Spring background. Both monosomic and disomic additions and substitutions of Th. elongatum chromosome 4E conferred a polycarpic life history to annual Chinese Spring wheat. Disomic addition lines were found to be perennial under field conditions. This is the first report of a single alien chromosome conferring a polycarpic growth habit to a monocarpic species. Chromosome 4E altered the timing of tiller initiation, such that two growth phases could be clearly identified, the first phase being indistinguishable from the growth of euploid Chinese Spring, followed by a second phase of tiller initiation after the sexual cycle of the first phase tillers was complete (post-sexual cycle regrowth).

Author: Johansen, C.; Chauhan, Y. S.; Gupta, S. C.; Taylan, F. M.
Title: Assessing short-duration pigeonpea for multiple-harvest potential.
Abstract Note: Twelve pigeonpea ( Cajanus cajan) lines of determinate growth habit, including line ICPL87, were evaluated for the extent of genetic variation in ratoonability. Large- and small-plot trials were conducted. In the large-plot trials, yield rankings of the first flush harvest differed from those of total yield, while in the small-plot trials, rankings between first flush and total yield matched better. Ratoon ratio, defined as seed harvested after the first flush harvest as a proportion of total seed yield of all flushes, was found to be highly environment-dependent, confirming that large-plot trials are more suitable for this purpose.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); Web of Science

Author: Chauhan, Y.S.; Johansen, C.; Gupta, S.C.
Title: Assessment of ratoonability of short-duration pigeonpea genotypes
Abstract Note: The extent of variation in ratoonability was examined in a range of recently bred short-duration pigeonpea [Cajanus cajan (L.) Millsp.] genotypes in 1989/90, 1990/91 and 1991/92 at the ICRISAT Asia Center, Andhra Pradesh, India. Traits with which this variation could be associated were assessed. Differences in the total ratoon yield of two flushes were significant among the genotypes in each season. In a few genotypes, ratoon yield constituted 50% of the total yield, which could be as high as 5-6 t/ha. Total ratoon yield was positively correlated with leaf area index in the last 2 years of experimentation. The relationship of total ratoon yield to main crop yield was significantly positive in 1991/92 only. The results suggest that there is a large variation in ratoonability among short-duration genotypes and that high leaf area retention at main crop maturity appears to contribute substantially to this variation.

Author: Tayo, T. O.
Title: Assessment of the effect of ratooning pigeon pea ( Cajanus cajan (L.) Millsp.) in the lowland tropics
Abstract Note: Pigeon pea (variety Cita-1) was sown on ridges at two plantings in the early and late seasons of 1983 at the University of Ibadan, Two to three weeks after the plants reached maturity and the pods had been harvested by hand-picking, the plants were either ratooned by cutting off the tops at a height of 30 and 60 cm or left intact.At the end of the first and second regrowths, the plants ratooned at 30 and 60 cm had performed better than those left intact in terms of growth and yield characters as well as seed yield. However, the plants ratooned at 30 cm performed best followed by those ratooned at 60 cm. The total seed yield from the planting was 3–6 times higher than if the crop had been harvested once.It would seem that ratooning at 30 cm would give the highest returns from a single planting under the prevailing lowland tropical conditions.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); Web of Science

Author: Subramanian, M.; Ramalingam, A.
Title: Association of rice ratooning ability and vigor with grain yield.
Abstract Note: During kharif 1987 these 3 traits were measured in 22 cultivars. Ratoon rating (RR) was calculated using ratoon vigour and ratoon tillers/plant. Ratoon grain yield was positively and significantly correlated (r = 0.9) with RR. Most cultivars with high RR values had high ratoon grain yields.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: KAI-CHU, Y.
Title: A study of regeneration rice.
Abstract Note: Experiments were made on ratooning of rice, using the medium-early variety Shui Pe Tiao. Since the yield of the ratoon crop was only 21 % that of the first crop, it is recommended that quick-maturing varieties of early to medium type should be grown for ratooning. Harvesting date and height of stubble of the first crop and the role of fertilizers were investigated for their effect on yield of the ratoon crop. F. Eng. s.-D.B.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Akgün, I.; Tosun, M.; Saǧsöz, S.
Title: A Study of the flower biology of different rye genotypes (S. cereale L., S. montanum Guss.)
Publication Title: Turkish Journal of Agriculture and Forestry
Abstract Note: In this study, the pollen germination rate, pollen viability, pollen size, pollen production and anther length of rye (S. cereale L.) and the diploid and tetraploid of perennial rye (S. montanum Guss.) populations were examined. The highest pollen germination rate was obtained in 30 % sucrose. 5 ppm boric acid and 10 ppm calcium nitrate solution with all specimens. Furthermore, the lowest pollen size (length: 18.92 μm; width: 15.26 μm), pollen production per anther (19982) and anther length (7.39 mm), but the highest pollen germination rate (40.48 %) and pollen viability (94.93 %) were observed in diploid perennial rye.
Short Title: Farkli çavdar genotiplerinde (S. cereale L., S. montanum Guss) çiçek biyolojisi üzerine bir araştirma

Author: JULIANO, JOSE B.
Title: A study of the growth habit of rice plants. III. Ratoons and grain size
Abstract Note: The % of setting of the grains was much less in ratoon rice plants than that of the first crop. The increase in the thickness of hulled grains from ratoon rice crop under field cultures was inversely proportional with the mean length and breadth of the grains.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: ShiXi, Zhao; ZhongFu, Wu; LiangWei, Wang
Title: A study on infestation of the white backed planthopper in ratooning rice and its action threshold.
Abstract Note: Damage caused by the white backed planthopper Sogatella furcifera to ratooning rice was studied by inoculating 5-30 insects/hill in caged rice cv. Shanyou 63 at the late booting and milky ripening stages in Fujian, China. The results showed that rice ratooning rate, fertility and 1000-grain weight decreased with increase in delphacid density. Rice yield loss was 0.36-33.43% in rice inoculated with 5-30 individuals/hill. The economic threshold was 7.0-8.3/hill at late booting and 10.0-12.6/hill at the milky ripening stage.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Wang, Q. B.; Tang, Z. H.; Cao, B.
Title: A study on nutrition characteristics of ratooning rice and fertilization techniques for it.
Abstract Note: Experiments were conducted with rice cv. Zhongxian 88-140 in 1988 to study the nutrition and fertilizer requirements of ratooned rice. Most N, P and K was absorbed by rice in the early to mid-growth stages. 80-90% of the total N, P and K were absorbed in the 30 days from the harvest of the first crop of rice to the full heading period of the ratoon rice. It is suggested that 8 kg N, 4 kg P 2O 5, and 8 kg K 2O/mu should be applied 5-10 days before harvest of the first crop. [1 mu = 0.067 ha.]
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Chaudhry, M. S.; Acikgoz, N.
Title: A study on the effect of sowing date on growth and performance of 6 rice cultivars and their ratoons.
Abstract Note: In field trials with rice sown at 10-day intervals from 2 Apr. to 1 June, a ratoon crop of 20% yield was harvested from cv. Krasnodorsky and Maratelli from the 1st 4 sowing dates only. Later maturing cv. Calorse or the high quality cv. Basmati were successfully grown from sowings up to mid-May. Transplanting was feasible until mid-July for the production of rice as a 2nd crop after wheat.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: JianFeng, Cheng; XiaoYun, Pan; XiaoChun, Zeng; YiBai, Liu
Title: A study on the physiological properties of ratooning rice - I. Effects of chloroplast pigment content during the harvest of the main crop.
Abstract Note: Results are presented of a study conducted on hybrid rice to determine the relationship between chloroplast pigment content during the harvest of the main crop and ratooning ability.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: JianFeng, Cheng; XiaoYun, Pan; XiaoChun, Zeng; YiBai, Liu
Title: A study on the physiological properties of ratooning rice. II. Effects of soluble carbohydrate content during the harvest of main crop.
Abstract Note: The relationship between the content of the soluble carbohydrate during the harvest of the main crop and their ratooning ability in hybrid rice was studied. During the harvest of the main crop, the soluble carbohydrate content of the tillering stem and stem sheath was not correlated with their ratooning ability in hybrid rice, but the soluble carbohydrate content of the main stem was interrelated. During the harvest of the main crop, significant positive correlations among the total soluble carbohydrate content of the main stem, tillering stem and stem sheath and their ratooning ability in hybrid rice were observed.

Author: C, OOI P. A.
Title: A SURVEY OF RICE RAGGED STUNT IN RATOON RICE PLANTS IN THE MUDA IRRIGATION SCHEME MALAYSIA
Abstract Note: A survey of ratoon rice plants was carried out from Feb.-March, 1980 after the 2nd season crop of 1979 was harvested. A total of 214 localities was visited and 8560 fields were searched for 10 min each. Altogether 80.5% of the fields visited had no signs of RRS [rice ragged stunt disease] symptoms. Of the fields 19.5% had infected hills, of which 12.2% of them had 1 RRS infected hill per field, 5.3% of the fields had 2 infected hills per field, 1.6% of the fields had 3 infected hills per field, 0.2% had 4 infected hills per field and 0.2% had 5 or more infected hills per field. The survey showed a low level of incidence of RRS and this explains the absence of this disease in the off-season or 1st crop when the vector is prevalent. Disease incidence and viruliferous insects should be monitored to forecast outbreaks of this disease.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: C-C, HO
Title: A SURVEY OF THE HOST RANGES OF STENEOTARSONEMUS-SPINKI ACARI TARSONEMIDAE
Abstract Note: Weeds (73 spp.) belonging to 17 plant families in and near paddy fields were investigated during 1977 and 1978. None were hosts of the rice tarsonemid mite, S. spinki Smiley. Mites species were found in soil samples collected from idle fields and the root part of ratoon rice, but no rice tarsonemid mite was found. No rice tarsonemid mite survived on

Author: He, Ruifeng; Salvato, Fernanda; Park, Jeong-Jin; Kim, Min-Jeong; Nelson, William; Balbuena, Tiago S.; Willer, Mark; Crow, John A.; May, Greg D.; Soderlund, Carol A.; Thelen, Jay J.; Gang, David R.
Title: A systems-wide comparison of red rice (Oryza longistaminata) tissues identifies rhizome specific genes and proteins that are targets for cultivated rice improvement
Abstract Note: The rhizome, the original stem of land plants, enables species to invade new territory and is a critical component of perenniality, especially in grasses. Red rice (Oryza longistaminata) is a perennial wild rice species with many valuable traits that could be used to improve cultivated rice cultivars, including rhizomatousness, disease resistance and drought tolerance. Despite these features, little is known about the molecular mechanisms that contribute to rhizome growth, development and function in this plant. Results: We used an integrated approach to compare the transcriptome, proteome and metabolome of the rhizome to other tissues of red rice. 116 Gb of transcriptome sequence was obtained from various tissues and used to identify rhizome-specific and preferentially expressed genes, including transcription factors and hormone metabolism and stress response-related genes. Proteomics and metabolomics approaches identified 41 proteins and more than 100 primary metabolites and plant hormones with rhizome preferential accumulation. Of particular interest was the identification of a large number of gene transcripts from Magnaportha oryzae, the fungus that causes rice blast disease in cultivated rice, even though the red rice plants showed no sign of disease. Conclusions: A significant set of genes, proteins and metabolites appear to be specifically or preferentially expressed in the rhizome of O. longistaminata. The presence of M. oryzae gene transcripts at a high level in apparently healthy plants suggests that red rice is resistant to this pathogen, and may be able to provide genes to cultivated rice that will enable resistance to rice blast disease.

Author: NengPu, Shi; Zhi, Chen; GuagHan, Xiao; ShiLiao, Lin
Title: A technical study on cropping system reform to prevent rice gall midge in paddy fields of a red soil area.
Publication Title: Journal of Fujian Academy of Agricultural Sciences
Abstract Note: Rice gall midge [ Orseolia oryzae] injury was recently discovered in >30 counties in Fujian province, causing about 30% yield loss. It was observed that infestation of rice plants usually occurred before the 3rd stage of young panicle differentiation. The introduction of ratooning rice, based on a principle of timing the most vulnerable stage to avoid the peak pest period, was investigated. It is suggested that the cropping system should be reformed from single-cropping to medium rice-ratoon rice, and from double-cropping rice to early rice-ratoon rice. The new techniques reduced leaf-rolling damage from 40 to 5% and increased yield by 20%. In comparison with single-cropping rice, the yield was increased by 98%.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: NenPu, Shi; GuangHan, Xiao; ShiLiao, Lin; Zhi, Chen
Title: A technical study on farming system effect of seedling-throwing cultivated ratooning rice, fish and Azolla.
Publication Title: Journal of Fujian Academy of Agricultural Sciences
Abstract Note: A cropping system composed of a ratoon rice crop established from broadcasting rice seedlings in a paddy field with fish and Azolla was studied. Where seedlings were broadcast yields of 2 growing seasons exceeded 1 t/mu and were higher than the controls. Growing medium-sized Azolla fingerlings in the fields with the rice increased the net income by 47%. Intercropping the Azolla with rice provided both fodder for the fish and fertilizer for the rice. It is suggested that this cropping system could stabilize grain production and increase benefits of growing rice in red soil areas as it saves labour and gives high yields of both rice and fish. [1 mu = 0.067 ha.]

Author: Gopala, K.S.; Waters, D.L.E.; Henry, R.J.
Title: Australian wild rice reveals pre-domestication origin of polymorphism deserts in rice genome
Abstract Note: Background: Rice is a major source of human food with a predominantly Asian production base. Domestication involved selection of traits that are desirable for agriculture and to human consumers. Wild relatives of crop plants are a source of useful variation which is of immense value for crop improvement. Australian wild rices have been isolated from the impacts of domestication in Asia and represents a source of novel diversity for global rice improvement. Oryza rufipogon is a perennial wild progenitor of cultivated rice. Oryza meridionalis is a related annual species in Australia. Results: We have examined the sequence of the genomes of AA genome wild rices from Australia that are close relatives of cultivated rice through whole genome re-sequencing. Assembly of the resequencing data to the O. sativa ssp. japonica cv. Nipponbare shows that Australian wild rices possess 2.5 times more single nucleotide polymorphisms than in the Asian wild rice and cultivated O. sativa ssp. indica. Analysis of the genome of domesticated rice reveals regions of low diversity that show very little variation (polymorphism deserts). Both the perennial and annual wild rice from Australia show a high degree of conservation of sequence with that found in cultivated rice in the same 4.58Mbp region on chromosome 5, which suggests that some of the 'polymorphism deserts' in this and other parts of the rice genome may have originated prior to domestication due to natural selection. Conclusions: Analysis of genes in the 'polymorphism deserts' indicates that this selection may have been due to biotic or abiotic stress in the environment of early rice relatives. Despite having closely related sequences in these genome regions, the Australian wild populations represent an invaluable source of diversity supporting rice food security.

Author: MOROZOVA, G. S.
Title: Award of the I. V. Micurin gold medal to N. V. Cicin.
Abstract Note: An outline of Cicin's work on Triticum x Agropyron hybrids and other wide crosses includes reference to resulting cultivars that are approved for 13 different provinces of the Soviet Union, to bread wheats with branched ears, to forms of perennial wheat giving yields for 2-3 successive years, to others that produce first a crop of grain and later a forage crop, to rye amphidiploids combining high yield of large grain with resistance to fungal infection and to hybrids of Nicotiana rustica with N. glauca and of N. alata with N. glauca.

Title: Bigger harvests.
Abstract Note: The Timiryazev Agricultural Academy has been reviewing the results of research carried out since the war. Achievements in plant breeding are particularly encouraging. Academician Zhukovsky has evolved useful new varieties of wheat and rye. His new wheat hybrid with a globular kernel, his perennial rye hybrid with a much larger kernel than normal, and his new hun.lv varieties of barley, which can stand sharp temperature changes, are all remarkable for their high fertility. Academician Zharbak made a report on new wheat varieties with large kernels. Khokhlov reported the development of a new kind of winter wheat with larger ears than usual and a large kernel.

Author: Yakovlev, G. V.
Title: Biochemical evaluation of wild species of rye.
Publication Title: Nauch. tr. Maikop. opyt. st. VNII rastenievodstva
Abstract Note: Most wild species had a higher content of grain protein than the cultivated Secale cereale 'Vyatka'. S. kuprijanivii forms from Krasnodar Territory were distinguished by their high content. Perennial cultivated ryes obtained from crosses of cultivated rye with perennial wild ryes approached the wild species in protein content. Embryo size was unrelated to protein content.

Author: BLAGOVESOENSKIJ, A. V.
Title: Biochemistry of protein substances, and plant evolution.
Abstract Note: Differences in the prolamines and globulins in different cereal grains and in the proportions of vicilin and legumin in the seeds of leguminous, species presumed to be of different phylogenetic ages are mentioned in illustration of biochemical differences that may have evolutionary significance. The gliadin of Agropyron glaucum[Elymus hispidus] has-been shown to differ in composition from that of perennial wheat M2 and the wheat Lutescens 329. The view is expressed that the phylogenetically younger taxa have "smaller, more mobile, more active protein molecules" and that their enzymes have "a greater capacity to reduce the energy of activation of the reactions they catalyse". The older phyla are saved from extinction, it is suggested, by arochemosis, a. process whereby "the processes of metabolism are raised to a higher plane of energy", thus giving the organism a greater capacity to withstand extreme conditions of environment and hence to evolve.

Author: SKRIPCINSKII, V. V.
Title: Biological features and the prospects of utilizing spring and winter forms of perennial rye.
Abstract Note: This work continues that recorded in Fld Crop Abstr. 11: 1727. The data show that the spring perennial rye described is able to fruit when sown either in spring or autumn; its reproductive development is retarded in short photoperiods and the crop overwinters successfully.-M.H.

Author: SHRIPINSKII, V. V.
Title: Biological features of the summer and winter forms of perennial rye and prospects for their use
Publication Title: Doklady Akad Nauk Sssr [bot Sci Sect Transl]
Abstract Note: The form of the perennial summer rye isolated has the ability to bear fruit either under autumn or spring sowing, retain generative development under the effect of a short photoperiod and overwinter successfully. Valuable characteristics as compared to their winter analogs are as follows: possibility of cultivation with both autumn and spring planting, good early ripening under autumn planting, higher productivity of heads and better quality of grain, and less spurred rye.

Author: Reddy, N.
Title: Boldgrain - a high-yielding rice variety for Fiji.
Abstract Note: The new rice cv. Boldgrain, resistant to brown planthopper [Nilaparvata lugens], yielded 7.0 t paddy/ha, compared with 2.51-6.9 t/ha given by standard cv. Under upland rainfed conditions at 4 sites it yielded 3.46 and 4.79 t/ha with direct sowing and transplanting, resp. in the wet season and 4.51-6.25 t/ha in the dry season. At 900 m alt. at Nadarivatu it yielded 3.14 t/ha. It yielded 0.75 t/ha as a ratoon crop and has a growth period of 125 days.

Author: Steinwand, M.A.; Young, H.A.; Bragg, J.N.; Tobias, C.M.; Vogel, J.P.
Title: Brachypodium sylvaticum, a Model for Perennial Grasses: Transformation and Inbred Line Development
Abstract Note: Perennial species offer significant advantages as crops including reduced soil erosion, lower energy inputs after the first year, deeper root systems that access more soil moisture, and decreased fertilizer inputs due to the remobilization of nutrients at the end of the growing season. These advantages are particularly relevant for emerging biomass crops and it is projected that perennial grasses will be among the most important dedicated biomass crops. The advantages offered by perennial crops could also prove favorable for incorporation into annual grain crops like wheat, rice, sorghum and barley, especially under the dryer and more variable climate conditions projected for many grain-producing regions. Thus, it would be useful to have a perennial model system to test biotechnological approaches to crop improvement and for fundamental research. The perennial grass Brachypodium sylvaticum is a candidate for such a model because it is diploid, has a small genome, is self-fertile, has a modest stature, and short generation time. Its close relationship to the annual model Brachypodium distachyon will facilitate comparative studies and allow researchers to leverage the resources developed for B. distachyon. Here we report on the development of two keystone resources that are essential for a model plant: high-efficiency transformation and inbred lines. Using Agrobacterium tumefaciens-mediated transformation we achieved an average transformation efficiency of 67%. We also surveyed the genetic diversity of 19 accessions from the National Plant Germplasm System using SSR markers and created 15 inbred lines.

Author: Kantar, M.; Betts, K.; Hulke, B.S.; Stupar, R.M.; Wyse, D.
Title: Breaking tuber dormancy in Helianthus tuberosus L. and interspecific hybrids of Helianthus Annuus L. × Helianthus tuberosus
Abstract Note: Tubers of Helianthus tuberosus L. are dormant after production in the late fall until the next spring. In the wild, tuber dormancy is broken after exposure to winter cold, resulting in sprouting and shoot development in the spring when conditions are favorable. The dormancy period typically limits H. tuberosus populations to one growth cycle per year. An efficient method for breaking tuber dormancy is needed to have an additional growth cycle per year in a breeding program, which could take place in winter in the nursery or the greenhouse allowing for increased breeding efficiency. The objective of this research was to compare chemical and cold temperature treatments for artificially breaking tuber dormancy in 12 genotypes of H. tuberosus and interspecific hybrids of Helianthus annuus L. × H. tuberosus. Five cold exposures (2, 4, 6, 8, 10 weeks at 2°C), three plant hormones (ethylene, cytokinin, and gibberellic acid), and one untreated control were examined. Gibberellic acid was the best chemical treatment, initiating plant growth within 6.5 to 11.5 days in the majority of genotypes tested. The best cold treatment was exposure to 2°C for 8 weeks, where plant growth began 63.6 to 67.5 days after treatment initiation. Although longer cold treatments shortened the time to emergence while in the greenhouse, the penalty of the long cold treatment per se was too long to be useful. The gibberellic acid treatment strategy described here may not need further optimization, because it is short enough to allow for two growth cycles of H. tuberosus per year.
Manual Tags: ALL(perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE(ar); ALL(perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE(ar); Cold treatment; Cytokinin; Ethylene; Gibberellic acid; Helianthus annuus; Helianthus tuberosus; relevant; Scopus; search.grain; search.rice; SPV

Author: YingJin, Huang
Title: Breeding and application of a late maturing hybrid rice Zhongjiuyou 801 with fine quality, high yield and strong disease resistance.
Abstract Note: Zhongjiuyou 801 is a new indica hybrid rice combination. It was developed during 1993-2002 in Jiangxi, China, by crossing the CMS (cytoplasmic male sterile) line Zhongjiu A with a restorer line R801 with fine grain quality, strong disease resistance and good combining ability. It had the characteristics including strong grain yield heterosis, fine grain quality, strong rice blast ( Magnaporthe grisea) resistance, strong ratooning ability, easy seed production procedure, high seed production potential and wide adaptability. It was examined and approved in March 2003 by the Crop Variety Evaluation Committee of Jiangxi Province. Its main technical points of field cultivation and seed production are described.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Bing, Shu; HongBo, Duan; GuoHua, Xu; Bin, Lu; MingTao, Wang; ZhiJie, Tu
Title: Breeding and application of a new hybrid rice Jingchuyou 148 with high yield and fine quality.
Abstract Note: Jingchuyou is a new indica hybrid rice [ Oryza sativa] combination for late season cropping. It was bred between 1998 and 2002 in Jingzhou, Hubei, China, by pedigree selection from a cross between Jingchu 814 A (a cytoplasmic male sterile line) and R148 (a restorer line). Characteristics of Jingchuyou include fine grain quality, a stable and high yield, good lodging resistance, strong ratooning ability and high seed production. Jingchuyou was examined and approved in February 2002 by the Crop Variety Committee of Hubei Province. The main points for successful cultivation of Jingchuyou are described, as are some aspects of its reproduction and seed production.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: TingXu, Huang; WeiRong, Chen; CongShou, Xie; Ming, Lin; ShiQuan, Zhou
Title: Breeding and application of quasi-aromatic hybrid rice II You 15 with high yield and strong blast resistance.
Abstract Note: Dalixiang 15 (an aromatic indica rice restorer) containing the aromatic gene from a breeding material 7539, derived from a multiple cross between IR36/7539 and 306/IR54, was successfully developed by directional selection for more than 10 years. The quasi-aromatic hybrid rice II You 15, bred during 1991-2001 in Fujian, China from a cross between II-32A and Dalixiang 15, had the characteristics of high and stable grain yield, acceptable grain quality, aromatically cooked rice, suitable maturity, strong rice blast ( Magnaporthe grisea) resistance, strong ratooning ability and high seed production yield. This hybrid rice variety was registered and released in Fujian in February 2001, with a sown area of more than 9266 ha in Fujian in 2000.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Lowe, M.
Title: Breeding a sustainable agriculture
Abstract Note: It is quite accepted that conventional farming depends on finite petroleum and obviously, soil. However, with the introduction of "miracle seeds" in the 1960s, the seeds, devised to increase productivity, require heavy doses of chemical fertilizers, pesticides and herbicides, all of which degrade the soil. In addition to using them, soil is being lost or degraded every year because of the relentless process hastened by slash-and-burn methods and farming on marginal lands and steep slopes. As such, there has been a proposal to protect the soil by means of eliminating tilling. Researchers are trying to breed perennial grain varieties such as crops that have deep, weed-defying roots that do not have to be replanted every year and have better access to water. Steady progress have been made with wheat, sorghum, maize and rice.
Manual Tags: ALL(perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE(ar); alternative agriculture; crop performance; cropping practice; Crop production; perennial plant; Productivity; relevant; Scopus; search.grain; soil remediation; SPV; Triticum aestivum; Zea mays

Author: Htwe, Nyo Me; Singleton, Grant R.; Hinds, Lyn A.; Propper, Catherine R.; Sluydts, Vincent
Title: Breeding ecology of rice field rats, Rattus argentiventer and R. tanezumi in lowland irrigated rice systems in the Philippines
Abstract Note: Rodents are one of the major pests in lowland irrigated rice crops in the Philippines. Rattus tanezumi occurs throughout the Philippines, whereas Rattus argentiventer does not occur on the main island of Luzon. Little is known about the breeding ecology of R. argentiventer and R. tanezumi where they coexist in the Philippines. We hypothesised that R. tanezumi breeding occurs throughout the season whereas the breeding of R. argentiventer is strongly cued to the generative stage of rice crops. We examined the breeding ecology of the two species in San Jose, Mindoro, Philippines, for four rice cropping seasons (two dry and two wet) over two years, 2009–2010, as a basis to develop effective management. We found to our surprise that their breeding ecology was similar. For both species (i) the onset of the breeding season was at the tillering stage of the rice crop; (ii) conception of adult females was highest at booting and ripening of rice; (iii) the highest litter size occurred at the ripening and stubble stages, and the lowest at tillering. Based on their breeding ecology we recommend that the most effective strategy to reduce damage to rice crops is to prevent the development of high populations of both species of rice field rats. This goal requires coordinated community control at both the sowing/planting time and maximum tillering of rice, in combination with the synchronous planting of rice to limit the length of the main breeding season.

Author: Shcheglov, Yu S.
Title: Breeding for grain yield in perennial rye.
Publication Title: Sb. nauch. tr. NII s. kh. tsentr. r-nov Nechernozemn. zony
Abstract Note: The Soviet synthetic population 1, which exceeds the original variety in grain yield by 31% and equals it in fodder yield, was produced from Kormovaya 61 [Fodder 61] by means of recurrent selection for a combination of useful characters.

Author: Sacks, E.J.; Dhanapala, M.P.; Tao, D.Y.; Cruz, M.T. Sta.; Sallan, R.
Title: Breeding for perennial growth and fertility in an Oryza sativa/O. longistaminata population
Abstract Note: The development of perennial cultivars (CVs) of upland rice would give farmers a new tool to reduce soil erosion from hilly fields, thereby mitigating a problem of regional concern in Southeast Asia. Oryza longistaminata is an undomesticated, perennial, rhizomatous relative of domesticated Asian rice (Oryza sativa). Using five sets of 4 × 2 factorial mating designs, we crossed rhizomatous interspecific genotypes (IGs) from an intermated O. sativa/O. longistaminata population with male-fertile IG selections from the intermated population, and with O. sativa CVs. Parents and progeny were planted in an upland field at IRRI using a randomized complete block design and evaluated for rhizome expression, survival after 1 year, vigor of the survivors, and yield. For the IG parents, rhizome expression was variable and penetrance of most genotypes was incomplete, but genotypes that demonstrated the potential for moderate rhizome expression had high penetrance (89% average). The CV parents yielded 11.0 g/plant on average but none produced rhizomes or survived 1 year. The IG parents averaged yields of 3.1 g/plant, 57% rhizomatous and 36% survival. The IG/IG progeny averaged yields of 4.2 g/plant, 32% rhizomatous and 37% survival. The IG/CV progeny averaged yields of 6.0 g/plant, 18% rhizomatous and 16% survival. Nine IG/IG progeny and six IG/CV progeny were rhizomatous, perennial, and yielded at least 5 g/plant, and five of these yielded more than 10 g/plant. For the IG parents and IG/IG progeny, rhizome presence and expression were positively associated with survival and vigor of the survivors. General combining ability effects were significant for percent survival and yield but not percent rhizomatous. Specific combining ability effects were significant for percent rhizomatous, percent survival and yield. By selecting female parents for long rhizomes and male parents for fertility, considerable gains in rhizome expression, survival and yield were made. The development of perennial upland rice CVs should be feasible via introgression of genes from O. longistaminata.
Manual Tags: ALL(perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE(ar); ALL(perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE(ar); Asia; Clonal performance; Crops; Eastern Hemisphere; Erosion; Eurasia; Fertility; Fertilizers; full text added; Growth; Interspecific crosses; Oryza; Oryza longistaminata; Oryza sativa; Perennial upland rice; perennial W/1 grain; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Plant breeding; Proteins; relevant; Rhizome; Rice; ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.grain; search.rice; Soil erosion; soils; Southeast Asia; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); Varieties; Web of Science; World

Author: PRUTSKOVA, M. G.
Title: Breeding grain crops.
Publication Title: Bull. Appl. Bot. Leningrad, Ser. A
Abstract Note: The most notable achievement of the Soviet grain breeders is the distribution of 59 improved varieties of the main grain crops, winter and spring wheat, barley, oats and rye, suitable for cultivation in all the main regions of the Soviet Union. These 59 represent the best varieties chosen in variety tests involving 500-600 varieties, and some of them have been the means of extending the cultivation of the crop in question into new areas, for instance wheat growing has been pushed farther north by the production of the ultra-early spring wheat Novinka, also possessed of excellent grain qualities, and of various new hardy winter wheats, including rye-wheat hybrid 46/131. The same is true in the case of barley and oats. One of the new early oats is also highly resistant to drought and to rust. Cultivation in the arid zones has been made possible by the creation of new drought-resistant varieties of wheat and barley at the same time distinguished by improved quality and greater earliness. Still further improvement in these varieties is desired nevertheless in respect of yield, and in some cases also quality or cold-resistance, and in nearly every case in respect of disease resistance. Various hybrids and selections distinguished by improved disease resistance are quoted, special interest being attached to hybrids of Avena sativa x A. byzantina, which in 1933 exceeded the standard in yield by four times and are much more resistant to leaf rust; certain American and Canadian wheat hybrids are also very promising. For purposes of mechanized harvesting, great importance is directed to non-shedding and non-lodging strains and mention is made of a number of varieties favourable in this respect, and of others that a, re promising in all respects but this. For instance, a new rye produced at Detskoje Selo by crossing the local rye with Rumker is free from both lodging and shedding whilst exceeding the standard variety Vyatka considerably in yield. A table is given in which the origin of all the most promising new varieties is shewn, i.e. the material from which they were produced and the methods used, whether selection or hybridization, etc. From this it is clear that the local varieties have contributed most to the formation of the new improved material, since they are the ones preeminently possessed of the desired characters, such as drought and cold resistance, earliness, yield, etc. Many of these local varieties were introduced years ago from abroad and often represented partly impure populations of some successful cultivated variety, since which time they have been subjected to a process of natural selection for tolerance of the unfavourable conditions of the particular region in which they are grown. An emphatic plea is made for the preservation and further study of these local varieties and for an extension of the work of hybridizing them with varieties from other countries, specially those countries known to be characterized by varieties possessed of certain special characters, such as earliness in the wheats of the near East, etc. etc. The practical possibilities of distant hybridization are also emphasized and reference is made to the production of hybrids possessed of a non-shedding habit, drought-resistance, good milling and baking quality and satisfactory yield from crosses of hard and soft wheats at Saratov, valuable rust-resistant oats from Avena sativa x A. byzantina and disease resistant wheats from crosses of T. durum with T. dicoccum; and finally to the new genus Secalotriticum produced from crosses of wheat and rye, together with a number of other useful hybrids from the same cross, one of which is already being grown on quite a large scale. In 1930 successful crosses were made of spring wheat with Agropyrum intermedium and more recently with A. elongatum, from which it is hoped to obtain perennial wheats and so present an entirely new solution to the problems of drought and cold resistance. A plea is also made for an attempt to accelerate the speed of breeding work by application of vernalization and other measures and to reduce the period required to produce a new variety, if possible, to 5 years.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: RuiDe, Qin
Title: Breeding of a rice restorer line R12 with fine grain quality.
Abstract Note: The R12 is a new indica restorer line. It was bred during 1998-2008 by pedigree selection from the cross Huangkexiangdao * Ce49 in Guangxi, China. It is characterized by good plant type, strong tillering ability, heavy pollen lead, high combining ability, fine grain quality and strong ratooning ability. Its hybrid combinations Jinyou R12 (Jin 23A * R12) performed well in the regional trial and the large-scale demonstrations and was registered and released to commercial production in March 2006 by the Crop Variety Evaluation Committee of Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: WenBang, Tang; LiYun, Chen; GuoHua, Liu; YingHui, Xiao
Title: Breeding of the newly-developed two-line hybrid rice Peiliangyou500.
Abstract Note: Peiliangyou 500, a new 2-line hybrid rice cultivar, was developed from a cross between rice cultivars Pei'ai 64S and 500. The growth duration of Peiliangyou 500 was 4 days shorter and 7 days longer compared to cv. Shanyou 63 for the main crop and the ratooning crop, respectively. The yield of Peiliangyou 500 was twice than that of Shanyou 63 for the ratooning crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: DeLang, Bai; XiaoHe, Luo; QingGuo, Xu
Title: Breeding of two-line super hybrid rice Peiliangyou 559.
Abstract Note: A two-line super-rice hybrid, Peiliangyou 559, was bred using Pei'ai 64S, a thermo-sensitive genic male sterile line with low critical temperature, as the female parent and 559, a storer line, as the male parent. In super-rice hybrid trials in Hunan, China, this cultivar yielded an average of 9.6 t/hm 2 and has a whole growth period of 135.4 days. Compared with the control, it characterized by higher disease resistance, more pleasant appearance, better taste, better ratooning ability and easier seed production.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Cox, T. S.; Bender, M.; Picone, C.; Van Tassel, D. L.; Holland, J. B.; Brummer, E. C.; Zoeller, B. E.; Paterson, A. H.; Jackson, W.
Title: Breeding perennial grain crops
Abstract Note: One-third of the planet's arable land has been lost to soil erosion in recent decades, and the pace of this degradation will increase as the limits of our food production capacity are stretched. The persistent problem of worldwide soil erosion has rekindled interest in perennial grain crops. All of our current grain crops are annuals; therefore, developing an array of new perennial grains - grasses, legumes, and others - will require a long-term commitment. Fortunately, many perennial species can be hybridized with related annual crops, allowing us to incorporate genes of domestication much more quickly than did our ancestors who first selected the genes. Some grain crops - including rye, rice, and sorghum - can be hybridized with close perennial relatives to establish new gene pools. Others, such as wheat, oat, maize, soybean, and sunflower, must be hybridized with more distantly related perennial species and genera. Finally, some perennial species with relatively high grain yields - intermediate wheatgrass, wildrye, lymegrass, eastern gamagrass, Indian ricegrass, Illinois bundleflower, Maximilian sunflower, and probably others - are candidates for direct domestication without interspecific hybridization. To ensure diversity in the field and foster further genetic improvement, breeders will need to develop deep gene pools for each crop. Discussions of breeding strategies for perennial grains have concentrated on allocation of photosynthetic resources between seeds and vegetative structures. However, perennials will likely be grown in more diverse agro-ecosystems and require arrays of traits very different from those usually addressed by breeders of annuals. The only way to address concerns about the feasibility of perennial grains is to carry out breeding programs with adequate resources on a sufficient time scale. A massive program for breeding perennial grains could be funded by diversion of a relatively small fraction of the world's agricultural research budget.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); Web of Science

Author: DERZAVIN, A. I.
Title: Breeding perennial varieties of wheat and other plants.
Abstract Note: Since 1930 work on the production of perennial forms of barley, wheat and rye has been in progress. The three methods used for wheat are hybridization of wheat with perennial rye and with Agropyrum and the selection of perennial wheats from wild and cultivated forms. The most promising of the wheat-rye crosses have been Leucurum 1364/1 x S. montanum and Stepnjacka x S. montanum and from the first-named combination a fertile perennial hard wheat was obtained comprising lines with 49-39 grains to the ear and a thousand corn weight of from 43.7 to 44.2 grm. These yields were obtained from vernalized seed without irrigation or manuring. Normally developed hybrids of increased yielding capacity proved resistant to brown rust and drought. Their winter-hardiness has still to be fully tested. Their main defect is brittleness of the ear but it is hoped that in the course of segregation forms without brittle ears may be obtained as has already been done by hybridization with non-shattering forms. Crosses are also contemplated between wheat and perennial rye with a rough rachis experimentally obtained by crosses of cultivated and wild perennial rye. So far only a few F 1 combinations from wheat crossed by Agropyrum are available but an F 2consisting of 100 plants has been raised from Agropyrum elongatum x Melanopus 0122. Comparing the perennial wheat x rye and wheat x Agropyrum hybrids the latter are seen to have a great advantage in their resistance to fungus diseases. On the other hand their yield is very low. The likelihood of the existence of undiscovered wild perennial wheats, particularly among the wild wheats of Armenia, is mentioned. Among the advantages cited which the perennial forms of various crops such as cereals, flax and sunflower have over the annual forms is high yielding capacity in successive years which ensures a second crop of hay and in the case of some spring forms, even a second crop of grain. The different developmental stages shewn by various groups of plants and their relation to tillering capacity are discussed. Suggestions for meeting various difficulties that arise in the cultivation of perennial forms and a statement of future aims in the production of perennial wheat conclude the paper.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: DERZAVIN, A.
Title: Breeding perennial wheat and other crops.
Abstract Note: In a comparative test of annual and perennial forms of the same plants, perennials out-yielded the annuals. This is thought to be due to the habits of the plants which in the first year utilize a considerable amount of plastic material for building up the roots; in subsequent years the perennials live mainly on the roots previously formed and use the nutrients deposited in the autumn. Perennials are more resistant and adaptable to environment, and therefore the vegetation of deserts, highlands and extreme northerly regions is mainly represented by perennials. Almost all known plants have their own perennial forms, but a number of defects prevent their direct use in practice. These defects could be eliminated, however, in hybridization with the annual cultivated forms or with some other species, as in the case of wheat. Crossing Vicia cracca with cultivated annual forms eliminates the defects of perennial vetch. Among perennial Lathyrus latifolius valuable forms have been selected. Crossing perennial sorghum and its hybrids with annual forms results in plants with a high drought resistance. See also Derzavin, Herb. Abstr. 1. 16. 1937.-M.A.O.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; search.sorghum; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: SMERNITSKAJA, M. I.
Title: Breeding rye at the Kharkov Station.
Abstract Note: Crosses have been made between cultivated rye and perennial rye, Secale montanum, various strains of each being used. The most successful combinations are indicated. The germination of the hybrid seeds was poor and the F 1 plants were highly sterile and very late in maturity; some few were perennial but the rest annual in habit. The other characters of the perennial parent were mostly dominant, though the grain was of the cultivated type. Pollination of the hybrids with cultivated rye gave only 4.4 per cent success. A great rise in fertility was observed in the back-cross hybrids, amounting to 70 per cent. in the second generation and a number of perennial plants occurred in both these generations.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: Andriyash, V. P.
Title: Breeding winter rye and the differentiation of varieties for resistance to root rots in the Poles'e area of the Ukrainian SSR.
Abstract Note: Among 400 forms tested for use in breeding for resistance to fungal root rots in the Poles'e (Pripyat' Marshes) area, no varieties of Secale cereale were completely resistant. The most useful were selected forms of perennial cultivated rye bred using S. montanum, such as Derzhavinskaya 29 and Odesskaya Mnogoletnyaya [Odessa Perennial].
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: Anonymous
Title: Brief outline on the work of the 4th session.
Publication Title: Bjulleten' Vsesojuznoi Akademii S.-Kh. Nauk im. V.I. Lenina (Bulletin of   the Lenin Academy of Agricultural Sciences) 1937.
Abstract Note: The fourth session of the Lenin Academy of Agricultural Sciences, devoted to breeding and genetics, was attended by more than 3, 000 people. A brief account is given of the president's inaugural address and of the sessions. The subjects for discussion were limited to the results attained in the experimental production of new varieties of cultivated plants and races of domestic animals and each breeder described his productions. In addition to improved and more productive forms of many crops, special mention is made of the perennial wheats, hybrids of oats and barley shewing heterosis, a barley giving two yields a year, very productive new high-quality cottons and others ripening 13 days earlier than the variety Schroeder, and bisexual hemp. After the above papers came addresses and discussions on the fundamental principles and methods of genetics and breeding.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Boehringer, A.; Caldwell, R.
Title: Cajanus cajan (L.) Millsp. as a potential agroforestry component in the Eastern Province of Zambia
Abstract Note: Farmers in the Eastern Province of Zambia are faced with problems common to other parts of the tropics: increased pressure to expand food production leading to accelerated forest clearing, decrease in traditional fallow periods, increased soil erosion, and reductions in soil fertility. Of special concern are shortages of labor during their growing season, a shortage of staple foods during January through March, pest (termite) problems, and seasonal fires. Alleycropping appears able to solve some of the farmers' problems. Both on-farm and experiment station trials were initiated to screen potential agroforestry species. Perennial pigeonpea, Cajanus cajan (L.) Millsp., a species indigenous to the Province, showed particular promise. Cultivars grew over 3 m tall and produced up to 4.8 tons/ha dry matter (in 7 months after pruning) for green manure. Farmers reacted favorably to their experience with the on-farm trials. Ease of establishment and production of food (green pod and grain) make perennial pigeonpea a special agroforestry option in the Province, deserving additional research.
Manual Tags: Agroforestry; agroforestry species trial; alleycrop; ALL(("long duration" OR "long-duration" OR perennial) W/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon pea" OR "pigeon-pea" OR pigeonpea)) AND DOCTYPE(ar); ALL(perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE(ar); Intercrop; Mylabris spp.; on-farm research; Pigeonpea; relevant; Scopus; search.grain; search.pigeonpea; Sesbania; SPV; TS=(("long duration" OR perennial) NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); Web of Science; Zambia, Eastern Province

Author: TSITSIN, N. V.
Title: C. Darwin and some questions in biology [English summ.]
Publication Title: Izvest Akad Nauk Sssr Ser Biol
Abstract Note: The author shows that the problem of non-interbreeding of species, genera, and families presented a major difficulty for Darwin in his time; now owing to the work of I. V. Michurin and L. Burbank and the new methods and means of influencing interbreeding pairs, this problem is, in principle, resolved. The research of the author and his co-workers on the interbreeding of cultivated and wild grains, methods employed by them for overcoming non-interbreeding, obtaining fertile hybrids and cultivating underdeveloped hybrid embryos (in highly nutrient media) are reported here. Thus the interbreeding of wheat with species of Agropyron produced not only new varieties but also new species of wheat: perennial wheat, Triticum agropyrotriticum perenne (Cic), and grain-fodder wheat T. agropyrotriticum submitans (Cic). The interbreeding then of Agropyron with the forms of rye having a high gluten content makes it possible to obtain a valuable grain competing in its flour-grinding and bread-baking qualities with wheat. Hybrids obtained from crossing the cultivated grains T. vulgare, T. durum, Hordeum, Secale with some species of Elymus (E. arenarius, E. giganteus) possess a number of valuable qualities: the potential for powerful development, no exacting demands in regard to soil or climatic conditions, and a high yield, 700-800 grains on one spike.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: N, SINGH R.
Title: CERTAIN ASPECTS OF EPIDEMIOLOGY OF RICE DISEASES IN UPLAND RAINFED RATOON AND POST-FLOOD RICE CROPS IN EASTERN UTTAR PRADESH
Publication Title: Narendra Deva Journal of Agricultural Research
Abstract Note: Incidence, severity and succession of diseases [fumgi bacteria, virus, nutrient deficiency] in the rice crops, grown under upland rainfed, ratoon and post-flood situations in eastern Uttar Pradesh [India], have been noted. Some of the diseases occur only in one situation. Others, which are common to two or all the three situations, vary in their severity under different agro-ecological conditions.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Stavi, Ilan; Lal, Rattan
Title: Challenges and Opportunities of Soil Organic Carbon Sequestration in Croplands
Abstract Note: This chapter reviews the main farming practices related with soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in croplands, aimed, simultaneously, at improving soil quality and health, and reducing net emission of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. The reviewed practices include conservation tillage, reduced tillage, no tillage, crop residues management, manuring and fertilizing, and cover cropping. In addition, this manuscript addresses prospects for future development by means of agroforestry, biochar application, and perennial grain crops, aimed at maintaining sustainability of agroecosystems, restoring degraded croplands, and increasing the SOC sink capacity. The data collected supports the conclusion that taking into consideration the prevailing physical conditions, wise integration of various conservation practices may increase the ability of croplands in sequestering SOC while maintaining ecosystem services and enhancing agronomic production.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); Web of Science

Author: SOKOLOVA, S. M.
Title: Changes in nitrogenous substances in the leaves of perennial wheat Referat Zhur., Biol., 1962, No. 16 G271. (Translation)
Publication Title: Byul Gl Bot Sada Akad Nauk Sssr
Abstract Note: Determinations were made of changes in the content of N compounds (total, protein and nonprotein N, and amino acids) and of the activity of proteolytic enzymes in the leaves of a perennial wheat variety obtained by N. V. Tsitsin as a result of hybridization of winter wheat with Agropyron tenerum. The leaves of this wheat were found to contain more raw protein than those of fodder grasses. The content of total, protein and nonprotein N reached a maximum at the tillering stage and decreased thereafter. The activity of proteolytic enzymes (calculated per unit protein) increased from the tillering phase to the stage of milky ripeness. The leaf content of free amino acids decreased with ripening. The ratios of various amino acids also changed. The green bulk of perennial wheat is most valuable for fodder purposes at the tillering phase when the leaf content of amino acids is maximal.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Crews, Timothy E.; Brookes, Philip C.
Title: Changes in soil phosphorus forms through time in perennial versus annual agroecosystems
Abstract Note: We compared inorganic and organic P fractions to a soil depth of 92 cm in two long-term Classical Experiments at Rothamsted Research in the U.K. The predominant soil-forming factor that differentiated the sites was vegetation type. The Broadbalk plots feature annual wheat and have been in continuous production since 1843, while the Park Grass plots feature perennial grassland vegetation that has been hayed every year since 1856. To evaluate the long-term effects of annual versus perennial vegetation on soil P forms, we carried out Hedley P fractionations and microbial biomass-P fumigation-extraction analyses on soils from fertilized and unfertilized treatments of both experiments. In both P-fertilized and unfertilized soils we found an inverse relationship between pool sizes of actively cycling Po (0.5 M bicarbonate + 0.1 M NaOH fractions) and recalcitrant Pi (hot conc. HCl + final digest fractions) with Po dominant in the perennial hay meadow and recalcitrant Pi dominant in the annual wheat. Microbial biomass-P in the surface horizons of fertilized and unfertilized perennial hay meadow was an order of magnitude greater than in annual wheat. To investigate how P fractions changed through time we conducted Hedley P fractionations on archived soils sampled from Broadbalk wheat in 1893, and Park Grass hay meadow in 1876. Since 1893, unfertilized Broadbalk soils experienced almost no change in P fractions in the surface 23 cm, but substantial depletion in labile and recalcitrant Pi and Po in deeper strata. The Park Grass perennial vegetation showed greater depletion of surface soil fractions over time. When fertilized for over 100 years, almost all P fractions in the surface 23 cm were enriched in both crop types, but below 70 cm, only the active Po pool in Park Grass showed a substantial increase under fertilization. Even when fertilized, low available or occluded Pi fractions in both annual and perennial systems were substantially depleted below 70 cm. Our findings suggest that herbaceous perennials maintain a greater proportion of native or fertilizer-P in relatively available organic forms compared to annual wheat. By reducing the fraction of P held in recalcitrant forms, P fertilizer requirements could be reduced

Author: Akgun, I.; Koc, A.; Sagsoz, S.
Title: Changes in some agronomic characters of the autotetraploid perennial rye ( Secale montanum Guss.) over time.
Abstract Note: Studies of samples of S. montanum taken at 15-day intervals between May and August in 1996 and 1997 in Erzurum, Turkey, showed that plant height, hay production, leaf ratio, and contents of dry matter, crude protein, crude cellulose, crude ash, K, Mg and P varied over time.
