Author: Chauhan, J. S.; Lopez, F. S. S.; Vergara, B. S.
Title: Effect of harvest time on IR44 ratoon grain yield.
Abstract Note: The effect of time of harvest of an IR44 rice ratoon crop on grain yield was studied between Dec. 1983 and July 1984. The ratoon crop was harvested at 75, 80, 85 and 90 days after main crop harvest. Main crop grain yield was 516 g/m. Ratoon crop harvest time significantly affected spikelet fertility, number of filled grains and ratoon grain yield. Ratoon grain yield varied from 126 g/m for 75 days after main crop harvest (DAH) to 168 g for 85 DAH. Lowest grain yield (136 g) was at 75 DAH and the highest was at 85 DAH. Differences in grain yield were not fully explained by differences in spikelet fertility. Opt. time for harvest of ratoon crop was 80-85 days after main crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Maharaj, K.; Brathwaite, R.A.I.
Title: Effect of herbicide treatments on the main rice (Oryza sativa L.) crop and its subsequent influence on the ratoon crop in Trinidad
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted in 1993-94 to study the effect of five post-emergence herbicide combinations on weed control and yield of wet seeded (WS) and transplanted (TP) main rice (Oryza sativa L.) crop (MC) and its ratoon (RC). Common weeds which occurred in this study were Fimbristylis littoralis Gaudich, Ischaemum rogusum Salisb., Sphenoclea zeylanica Geartn., and Ludwigia hyssopifolia (G. Don) Excell. Combinations of propanil (3.0 kg a.i. ha-1) with oxadiazon (3.0 kg a.i. ha-1), pendimenthalin (1.5 kg a.i. ha-1), and butachlor (2.0 kg a.i. ha-1) were applied 14 days after seeding (DAS) and 7 days after transplanting (DAT) and a split application of propanil (3.0 kg a.i. ha-1 + 3.0 kg a.i. ha-1) was applied 14 DAS, 28 DAT, and 7 DAT. The 21 DAT treatment resulted in lower weed biomass and better crop yields than propanil plus 2,4-D (3.0 kg a.i. ha-1 + 0.5 kg a.i. ha-1) applied 14 DAS and 7 DAT. Higher weed biomass was associated with WS in the MC (78 g m-2) and TP in the RC (184 g m-2). The MC and RC grain yields were similar in both planting systems under optimum weed control. Weeds that emerged in the RC differed from those of the MC, but herbicides producing good weed control in the MC resulted in better control in the RC, especially under WS.

Author: MASLOV, A. B.
Title: Effect of high-energy protons on mitotic division in roots of perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: The number of disrupted anaphases increased with dose. The efficiency of protons as a muta-genic agent equalled that of any other form of ionizing radiation.

Author: Arunachalam, L.; Kulandaivelu, R.; Palaniappan, S.; Devashhayam, M. M.
Title: Effect of intercrops on yield attributes of sorghum ratoon.
Abstract Note: In a field experiment, plant sorghum crop was intercropped with cowpeas and in the following 2 years, a ratoon sorghum crop was intercropped with safflower, Bengal gram [ Cicer arietinum], horse gram [ Macrotyloma uniflorum], coriander or wheat or not intercropped. Intercropping decreased ratoon sorghum DM production and grain yields. The lowest reduction in grain yield was with horse gram (18.6%) and and highest with wheat (29.9%).
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: Ambujam, N. K.; Manickam, D.
Title: Effect of irrigation on yield in main and ratoon crop of sorghum (Sorghum bicolor).
Abstract Note: Fodder and grain yields of main and ratoon crops were higher in treatments irrigated every 5 d than every 10 or 15 d or irrigated twice at critical stages [not stated]. Fodder yields of main and ratoon crops, harvested after 74 and 63 d growth, were 51.45 and 31.6 t/ha, respectively. Grain yield of the ratoon crop was 2.6 t/ha irrigated every 5 d. Irrigation at 10-d intervals gave the highest economic productivity per unit of water consumed.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: Arumugachamy, S.; Vivekanandan, P.; Subramanian, M.
Title: Effect of leaf senescence and stubble carbohydrate content on ratoon rice yield.
Abstract Note: Main crop stubble carbohydrate content (SCC), leaf senescence and ratoon grain yields were measured in 6 genotypes and their F1s during 1988. IET7552 and Bhavani had the highest ratoon grain yields (15.1 and 14.4 g/10 plants, respectively). The effects of SCC and leaf senescence on ratoon yields were not significant.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Chauhan, J. S.; Lopez, F. S. S.; Vergara, B. S.
Title: Effect of light intensity before and after main crop cutting on ratooning ability of rice.
Abstract Note: In pot trials, effects of reduced light intensity during the ripening period of the main rice crop and after cutting the main crop on the regeneration of ratoon plants, their yield components and grain yield were studied. The regeneration of ratoon plants was only 19 and 44% with reductions of 60 and 40% in the light intensity, resp., during main crop ripening compared with 81% regeneration of ratoon plants in the untreated control. Regeneration was decreased to 63% by a 60% reduction in the light intensity after cutting the main crop but was not adversely affected by a 40% reduction in light intensity. The low light intensity treatments had no adverse effect on yield components of the ratoon plants, but decreased grain yields by increasing the number of missing ratoon plants.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: S, CHAUHAN J.; S, LOPEZ F. S.; S, VERGARA B.
Title: EFFECT OF LOW LIGHT INTENSITY BEFORE AND AFTER MAIN CROP CUTTING ON RATOONING ABILITY OF RICE
Abstract Note: Reduced light intensity before cutting appreciably reduced regeneration of ratooned rice. Only 19% of the plants regenerated under 60% shading during ripening phase of the main crop. The regeneration was also slightly reduced under 60% shading after main crop cutting. Low light intensity before and after main crop cutting decreased ratoon grain yield through increased missing hills in the ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Mobasser, H. R.; Rostaei, K.; Alamdari, M. Q.
Title: Effect of main crop harvesting time on rice-ratoon and berseem clover ( Trifolium alexanderinum L.) yield as intercropping system.
Publication Title: Technical Journal of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Abstract Note: To determine the effect of main crop harvesting time on rice ratoon and berseem clover yield as intercropping system, the experiment was conducted out as split plot in randomized complete block design with three replications in Northern Iran at 2010. Main crop harvesting time of rice has been chosen as main plot at four levels; 19 and 26 August, and 2 and 9 September. The kind of cultivation has been also chosen as sub-plot at three levels; berseem clover cultivation, ratooning, and intercropping berseem clover with rice ratoon. The results showed that the total number of tillers and effective tillers per hill, the total number of spikelet per panicle and percentage of filled spikelet were significantly decreased by delaying harvesting time. The maximum grain yield and harvesting index were attained by earlier harvesting time at
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Deka, K. C.; Bhagowati, A. K.; Baruah, U. K.
Title: Effect of monocrotophos application in rice-fish farming.
Publication Title: Journal of the Agricultural Science Society of North East India
Abstract Note: Field studies in Assam, India, in 1990-91 showed that a perennial system of integration of fish culture (5 species of carp) with rice cultivation resulted in good control of stem borers [? Scirpophaga incertulas] and case worms [ Parapoynx stagnalis] but not of rice hispa [ Dicladispa armigera] and leaf folders [ Cnaphalocrocis medinalis]. Foliar sprays of monocrotophos (Nuvacron 40 EC) applied at the rate of 1.25 kg/ha effectively controlled the pests without any apparent toxic effects on fish. No residues of monocrotophos were detected in brain, gill, liver, muscle and kidney tissues taken from fish 223 and 228 days after application. This suggested that monocrotophos at 1.25 kg/ha was safe for use in perennial rice-fish farming systems.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: HongFei, Chen; Dong, Yang; YiYuan, Liang; ZhiXing, Zhang; KangJing, Liang; WenXiong, Lin
Title: Effect of nitrogen application strategy in the first cropping rice on dry matter accumulation, grain yield and nitrogen utilization efficiency of the first cropping rice and its ratoon rice crop.
Publication Title: Zhongguo Shengtai Nongye Xuebao / Chinese Journal of Eco-Agriculture
Abstract Note: The effect of fertilizer application strategy on nitrogen (N) and dry-matter accumulation, grain yield and N utilization efficiency (NUE) of the ratoon rice crop and its first cropping rice was determined in China by designing 3 N applied proportion between basal-tiller dressing and panicle dressing [8:2(N 1), 7:3(N 2), 6:4(N 3)] in the first cropping rice season with a constant N supply at 225.00 kg/hm 2. The results indicated that N accumulation under the N 3 treatment was 9.26 and 3.54% higher at ripening stage of the first cropping rice than that under N 1 and N 2 treatments. Transportation of N from vegetative parts to panicle during the grain-filling stage of the first cropping rice under N 3 were 21.47 and 6.76% higher than under N 1 and N 2 treatments. For the entire growth period, the net dry matter accumulation in rice under N 3 treatment increased by 5.10 and 4.78% compared to the N 1 and N 2 treatments. For grain yield of the first cropping rice, the N 3 treatment produced the highest yield (12 431 kg/hm 2), which was significantly higher than that produced by the N 1 and N 2 treatments. The N utilization efficiency of N 3 treatment was as high 46.4%, 14.81 and 5.43% higher than that under N 1 and N 2. N agronomic efficiency in the N 3 treatment was 20.66 kg/kg, 14.97 and 12.34% higher than in N 1 and N 2. Furthermore, the results showed that different N proportion between basal-tiller dressing and panicle dressing with a constant N supply (225.00 kg/hm 2) in the first cropping rice had no significant influence on the ratoon rice crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Prakash, K. S.; Prakash, B. G.
Title: Effect of nitrogen source and insect control on growth of a ratoon crop.
Abstract Note: In field experiments in 1985-86, 0 or 50 kg N/ha, 2.5 t Azolla applied 3-4 times, or Azolla + 25 kg N were applied to a rice cv. Sona Mahsuri ratoon crop in combination with 0.5 kg monocrotophos or 0.3 kg chlorpyrifos/ha. Combinations with 50 kg N/ha or Azolla + 25 kg N increased plant height, number of regenerated tillers, number of tillers per plant and number of panicles per plant. Yield ranged from 0.7 t/ha with Azolla + chlorpyrifos to 2.2 t with 50 kg N. Highest harvest index was 0.50 with 2.5 t Azolla/ha.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: M, AKRAM; A, CHEEMA A.; A, AWAN M.; M, AHMAD
Title: EFFECT OF PLANTING DATE AND FERTILIZER LEVEL ON GRAIN YIELD AND PROTEIN CONTENT OF RICE
Abstract Note: The effects of planting date and fertilizer level on grain yield and protein content were studied in a double cropping (by ratooning) experiment using a rice cultivar, 'Kashmir Basmati'. Four fertilizer levels with 4 planting dates were used in these studies. A considerable variability in protein content and grain yield was observed with different fertilizer doses and date of transplanting combinations. Planting on June 8 with 45:90 (P2 O5 : N2) fertilizer gave highest grain yield (4.48 t/ha) while maximum protein content (9.7 percent) was observed in the crop planted on June 24 with same fertilizer doses.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Espino, L.; Way, M. O.; Pearson, R.; Nunez, M.
Title: Effect of Planting Date on Lissorhoptrus oryzophilus (Coleoptera: Curculionidae) Density-Yield Relationship on Rice in Southeastern Texas
Abstract Note: Results of planting date and insecticide efficacy experiments targeting Lissorhoptrus oryzophilus Kuschel (Coleoptera: Curculionidae) on rice, Oryza sativa L., in Southeastern Texas between 2002 and 2007 were used to determine density-yield relationships as a function of planting date. Soil core samples were collected on two dates during main crop development to estimate immature L. oryzophilus populations followed by main and ratoon crop harvests. Analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) revealed that planting date did not affect the density-main crop yield relationship during most years and that these relationships varied substantially among years. For ratoon crop yield, an effect of main crop L. oryzophilus immature infestation was detected during some years, but the real effect of these populations on ratoon crop yield remains unclear. Using estimates of yield reduction per L. oryzophilus immature, economic injury levels were calculated. Main crop yields from treated plots and first soil core sample L. oryzophilus immature populations from untreated plots were significantly higher in plots planted at recommended dates than in plots planted earlier or later. This suggests that the presence of high populations of reproductive L. oryzophilus coincides with the period when rice fields planted at optimum dates are flooded. Results from this study reinforce the importance of managing L. oryzophilus populations when planting rice at recommended dates in southeastern Texas.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: MuYing, Li; QingHua, Shi; ZhongMing, Wang; XiaoHua, Pan; XueMing, Tan
Title: Effect of planting density on the population development and yield of II Youming 86 as Mid-season rice plus ratooning rice.
Abstract Note: The effect of transplanting density on the population development and yield on II Youming 86 as mid-season and ratooning rice in the region of double season rice was studied. The highest yield was obtained under the density of 244 300 holl/ha. As a dominant population in the main season, it was advantageous to coordinating the conflicts between the individuals and the population, and between the main season and the ratooning. The effective rate of tiller was negatively correlated with the planting density and the maximum tiller number. The maximum number and effective number of tillers increased with the planting density. The leaf area index and the planting density were positively correlated before full heading but not after full heading. The lower density was propitious to bud growth. The bud growth and xylem sap amount were positively correlated. The number of ratooning was positively correlated with the dry weight of stalk of main season subsistence. The nitrogen content of individual plant, total nitrogen amount in the population, nitrogen amount in each organ, and nitrogen consumption of 100 kg grain increased with the decrease in density in the main season.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Srinivasan, K.; Purushothaman, S.
Title: Effect of plant spacing on ratoon rice performance.
Abstract Note: In field experiments in 1986 at Madurai, Tamil Nadu, rice cv. Ponni and Bhavani were transplanted into a sandy clay loam at 15, 20 or 25 × 10 cm plant spacings. The main crop was harvested 110 d after transplanting leaving 15 cm stubble. The ratoon crop was irrigated to 5 cm depth and harvested 67 d after ratooning. Averaged across plant spacings, grain yields of main and ratoon crops were 4.7 and 1.8 t/ha, resp., in cv. Ponni and 5.5 and 2.8 t in cv. Bhavani. Averaged across cultivars, yields of main and ratoon crops were 5.2 and 2.4, 5.0 and 2.2 and 5.0 and 2.1 t/ha at 15 × 10, 20 × 10 and 25 × 10 cm plant spacings, resp. Higher plant density increased number of productive tillers and total plant DM in main and ratoon crops but had no significant effects on grain and straw yields of ratoon crops.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: De la Cruz, C. G.; Litsinger, J. A.
Title: Effect of ratoon rice crop on populations of green leafhopper Nephotetix virescens, brown planthopper Nilaparvata lugens, whitebacked planthopper Sogatella furcifera, and their predators [Philippines]
Abstract Note: Mature plants of IR 1917 (insect-susceptible but rice tungro virus-resistant) were ratooned by cutting stalks 15 cm above the ground. No insecticides was used on any crop, but fertilization, irrigation, and weeding were done as recommended. Hoppers and their predators were sampled intensively using a FARMCOP suction machine. As the main crop matured, hopper populations declined naturally because of outward migration and natural enemy activity. Space-web and hunting spiders were most abundant in the first crop and were more prevalent than orb-web spiders. On the subsequent ratoon, all spider groups were generally higher than on the second crop. Possibly, the spiders foraged from the ratooned plots to the second transplanted crop, explaining why hopper numbers in general were lo1802w in all second crops. Hunting spiders, dominated by Lycosa pseudoannulata, maintained higher numbers throughout the ratoon crop. Space-web spider Atypena formosana numbers declined as the ratoon matured. Because it makes its webs at the base of tillers, A. formosana and the highly mobile hunting spider can readily colonize a new crop or remain unaffected during harvest and growth of a ratoon. Orb-web spiders Tetragnatha spp. and Dyschiriognatha sp. spin webs in tall foliage. They become abundant during later growth stages, but decline at main crop harvest when hoppers disperse to colonize younger crops.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Lindau, C.W.; Bollich, P.K.; DeLaune, R.D.
Title: Effect of rice variety on methane emission from Louisiana rice
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted to determine the effect local cultivars of Oryza sativa L. (rice) had on methane evolution from flooded plots. Semidwarf and tall varieties were drill-seeded into a Crowley silt loam (Typic Albaqualf) and methane fluxes were measured twice a week over the first and ratoon cropping seasons. Semidwarf varieties evolved significantly less methane over both growing seasons. Over the main cropping season, semidwarfs emitted an average 185 kg CH4 ha−1 to the atmosphere compared with 300 kg CH4 ha−1 for the tall varieties. During the ratoon sampling season, semidwarf and tall varieties evolved 540 and 830 kg CH4 ha−1, respectively. Compared with tall cultivars, semidwarfs evolved 36% less methane over both seasons.

Author: Alfonso-Morel, D.; Althoff, D.; Dittrich, R. C.
Title: Effect of Seeding Time and Fertilizer Rate on Rice Ratooning
Abstract Note: Experiments were conducted to study the effect of (1) seeding time of the main crop on the ratoon crop, planted in observation plots, and (2) fertilizer rate on the ratoon crop in Santa Catarina State, southern Brazil, in the summer of 1994, 1995, and 1996. The soil at the experimental site was a Cambicsol Gley.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Singh, L. N.; Devi, K. N.
Title: Effect of seedling age, cutting height and nitrogen levels on yield and economics of ratoon paddy.
Publication Title: Journal of the Agricultural Science Society of North-East India
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted in Imphal, Manipur, India during April-November 1996 and 1997 to study the effects of seedling age, cutting height and nitrogen levels on the yield and economics of ratoon rice. Transplanting of 27-day-old seedlings, harvested at 30 cm height and with the application of 60 kg N/ha in ratoon rice gave the highest grain yield and it was economically sound and viable for the small-scale farmers of Manipur.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Azandehi, S. M. M.; Fallah, A.; Taghizadeh, R.
Title: Effect of spraying potassium silicate and nitrogen on the physicochemical characteristics of Ratoon rice (Tarom's local variety).
Publication Title: International Journal of Agronomy and Plant Production
Abstract Note: The quality of rice is the most important issue to be considered after yield. Amylose is an important determinant of the quality and one of starch component and its linear components. To evaluate the effect of spraying potassium silicate and nitrogen on the physicochemical properties of chemical Local Tarom Ratoon, an experiment was done in 2011 at the Institute of Rice Research of Iran based on a factorial and completely randomized block design with three replications and nine combined treatments. The treatments were spraying potassium silicate and nitrogen at the levels of zero (control), three and six per thousand and in two steps away after 20 and 40 days from the harvest of main crop. Analysis of the variance showed that the effects of potassium silicate and nitrogen treatments and their interactions are not statistically significant at any level. But means comparison of treatments showed significant difference between the control and other treatment combinations; so that the increased rate of 2-3 percent for all attributes of quality properties and conversion efficiency were measured.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: TingJie, Jiang; ZhenXie, Yi; NaiMei, Tu
Title: Effect of stubble height on ratooning properties of Pei'ai64S/E32.
Abstract Note: The effects of stubble height (10-40 cm) on the ratooning properties of rice cv. Pei'ai64S/E32 were investigated. The regeneration speed of axillary buds, total ratooning rate and yield of ratooning rice increased with increasing stubble height. Increasing stubble height resulted in an increase in plant height, but reduced the total leaf number. Under the same stubble height, the plant height, leaf number and grain number/panicle increased when the position of node descended, but the seed setting rate and 1000-grain weight of the upper node's ratooning rice were higher than those of the lower node. The highest stubble height should be reserved for ratooning cultivation of this particular genotype.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: FuXian, Xu; Hong, Xiong; YongChuan, Zhu; Lin, Zhang
Title: Effect of the amount of N application for bud development on the ratooning ability and in association with ratio of source to sink in mid-season hybrid rice.
Publication Title: Southwest China Journal of Agricultural Sciences
Abstract Note: Field studies were conducted in China to determine the difference of the amount of nitrogen (N) fertilizer application for bud development (NABD) among genes of mid-season hybrid rice. The effect of the amount of NABD on the ratooning ability under the amount of NABD and cut leaves and spikelet treatments was investigated using 25 mid-season hybrid rice combinations. At full heading of the main crop, there existed highly significant positive correlations between the spikelets per panicle and dry weight of leaves and stem sheath per stem, and highly significant negative correlations between the spikelets per panicle and ratio of leaves to grain and stem to grain, respectively. The more spikelets were set on per panicle, the less photosynthetic matter remained in the basic stems for ratooning rice growth at harvest of main crop. Therefore, when ratooning rice is to be cultivated with cultivars having many spikelets per panicle of the main crop, more amount of NAHD will be needed. But the effect of NABD on increasing grain yield of ratooning rice were slight when photosynthetic matter that remained in the basic stems were very high or low. The cultivars of 130-160 s,170-200 spikelets and 210-250 s were set on per panicle, their best amount of NABD were 150, 300 and 300 kg urea/hm 2. There were highly significant positive correlations between the amount of NABD for high yield of rationing rice and the spikelets per panicle of the main crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Srinivasan, K.; Purushothaman, S.
Title: Effect of time of N application of ratoon rice.
Abstract Note: In field experiments, the greatest grain and straw yield of rice cv. Bhavani and Ponni came from N given as a basal application.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Balasubramanian, R.; Ali, A. M.
Title: Effect of variety, nitrogen, and stubble height on ratoon rice yield.
Abstract Note: The short duration varieties ADT36, ASD16 and ADT37 were tested at 3 N fertilizer levels (75, 100 and 125 kg/ha) and 2 stubble heights (20 and 30 cm). ADT37 had the highest ratoon crop grain yield, straw yield, productive tiller number and daily productivity. Increasing N application increased yields, while stubble height had no effect on ratoon yields.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Quddus, M. A.; Pendleton, J. W.
Title: Effect on ratoon rice of cutting height and time of nitrogen application on the main crop.
Abstract Note: The effect of main crop management practices on the performance of ratoon rice was studied during 1980-81. The crop was harvested by cutting 5 cm and 15 cm above soil surface. 2 days after harvest 40 kg N/ha was applied and fields were flooded with 2-3 cm water. Cutting ht. and N application at different main crop growth stages did not affect grain yield. Plants cut at 5 cm ht. had more healthy ratoon tillers, heavier grains and more even maturity; they matured in 74 days compared with 65 days for those cut at 15 cm.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Borkhataria, Rena R.; Nuessly, Gregg S.; Pearlstine, Elise; Cherry, Ron H.
Title: Effects of blackbirds (Agelaius phoenicius) on stink bug (Hemiptera: Pentatomidae) populations, damage, and yield in Florida rice
Abstract Note: Blackbirds are important agricultural pests that can cause major economic losses in a variety of crops. Although birds in other agro-ecosystems may perform biological control services by controlling insect pests, the potential of blackbirds to provide these services in rice had not been evaluated. We used bird exclosures to evaluate the effects of blackbirds on stink bugs in rice and on crop damage and yields in the Everglades Agricultural Area in southern Florida. Experiments were conducted in both the main rice crop and the ratoon crop. We found no difference in the abundance of rice stink bugs (Oebalus spp.) in exclosures vs. controls, indicating that predation by birds did not reduce stink bug populations. Damage to rice by stink bugs (pecky rice) was similar between exclosures and controls, as well. However, bird damage, quantified as the percentage of panicles damaged, differed by as much as an order of magnitude in exclosures vs. controls. Mean damage estimates were 3.5% in the bird exclosures vs. 35.3% in the control for the main crop and 4.5% and 20.5%, respectively, in the exclosures and controls for the ratoon crop. Nonetheless, mean yields did not differ between exclosures and controls. Our results suggest that despite their conspicuous presence, blackbirds have little effect on stink bug populations or rice yield in Florida rice fields.

Author: Nakano, H.; Hattori, I.; Sato, K.; Morita, S.; Kitagawa, H.; Takahashi, M.
Title: Effects of cutting height of the first crop on estimated total digestible nutrient concentration and yield in double-harvested rice
Abstract Note: We examined the effects of cutting height (15, 5, or 0 cm) and equipment traffic treatment (treatment or no treatment) of the first crop on estimated total digestible nutrient (TDN) concentration and yield in double-harvested forage rice (Oryza sativa L.) in southwestern Japan. In forage rice production, it is important to maximize the nutrition in leaf and stem, especially leaf sheath plus stem (stem) due to the high ratio to the whole plant weight, rather than in panicle, to minimize the overall loss of nutrition from the crop. In the total of the first and second crops, stem estimated TDN yield was lower when the first crop had been cut at a height of 15 cm (517 g m-2) than 5 and 0 cm (576 and 598 g m-2, respectively). In the second crop in 2006, stem estimated TDN concentration decreased from 541 to 478 g kg-1 with increasing cutting height from 0 to 15 cm, because the organic cel-lular contents (OCC), which include starch and sugar, concentration decreased. The second crop headed earlier with increasing cutting height. Thus, although starch was translocated from the stem to the panicle in the second crop when the first crop was cut at a height of 15 cm, insufficient starch was translocated to the panicle when the first crop was cut at 5 and 0 cm because of the low temperatures after heading. To reduce the overall loss of nutrition from a crop, it is effective to cut stubble lower. In the second crop, whole plant estimated TDN concentration and yield was not greatly influenced by equipment traffic treatment.
Manual Tags: ALL(ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Concentration (process); Crops; Cutting equipment; Cutting heights; harvesting; Low temperatures; Nutrient concentrations; Nutrients; Nutrition; Oryza sativa; relevant; Rice production; Scopus; search.rice; Southwestern Japan; SPV; Starch; Sugar (sucrose); Whole plants

Author: Wu, H. Q.
Title: Effects of different cultivation ways on root growth of ratooning rice.
Abstract Note: Trials on ratooning rice cv. Shanyou 63 compared planting on ridges, planting on raised beds, flat planting with alternating wide and narrow row spacing, and conventional flat planting in submerged paddy fields. Ridge planting produced a yield 21.1-36.64 kg/mu higher than in the other 3 treatments. The total yield of two crops in a year was in the order ridge planting > flat planting with wide and narrow rows > bed planting > flat planting. The transplanted plants had a survival rate of old roots and a germination rate of new roots in the order of ridge planting > bed planting > flat planting with wide and narrow rows > conventional flat planting for first crop rice and ratoon rice. At the heading stage of first crop rice, redox potential (Eh value) in the 0.220 cm soil layer was in the order ridge planting > bed planting > flat planting with wide and narrow rows > conventional flat planting. [1 mu = 0.067 ha].
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: YouGuang, Liu; Ri, Yang; FengWu, Wei; ChangZhi, Wu; ShuHua, Wei; HanZhou, Zhang; YunQu, Wei
Title: Effects of different seeding dates on the first cropping and ratoon of super rice.
Abstract Note: In order to make full use of light resources, temperature and field in one-cropping middle rice zone, super rice variety Zhongzheyou 1 was used to study the effects of different seeding dates on the yields of the first cropping and ratoon rice. The results showed that the first cropping of rice variety Zhongzheyou 1 (sown during March, 19 to April, 8 in one cropping middle zone) could be harvested before August, 20 and ratoon could be harvested in the first ten-day of November. But the yield of super rice was the highest as sowing around March, 19 and the total yield of two cropping rice reached 14197.5 kg/ha. Therefore, it could be extended in one-cropping middle rice zone.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: GuangMing, Wang; BaoGuo, Liu; Jing, Chen; ChangFu, Ren
Title: Effects of endogenous ABA on the germination of ratooning buds in paddy rice.
Abstract Note: In a pot experiment with rice cv. Shanyou 63, the plants were fed with urea at 3 g/pot on the 25th day after heading of the main crop (25 DAH), and the changes in dry weight, peroxidase (POD) activity and endogenous abscisic acid (ABA) content in the vegetative parts, ratooning buds and spikes from heading (0 DAH) to harvest (30 DAH) were investigated using ELISA. From 0 to 20 DAH of the main crop, ABA in the plants rose steadily while POD activity and straw dry weight dropped gradually, and a sharp increase was observed in spike dry weight. Starting from 20 DAH, ABA content in the main crop and the ratooning buds drastically decreased, POD activity and straw dry weight showed a slight increase, the growth in spike dry weight slowed and the ratooning buds began to germinate. The death of ratooning buds occurred mainly during their growth after germination. N application changed ABA content and POD activity and raised the content of soluble protein in the plants, thus improving the germination and growth of the ratooning buds and promoting their survival.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Mochizuki, Toshihiro; Kajihara, Yoshinori; Torikai, Yoshihide; Nakagawa, Yukio
Title: Effects of fertilization and cutting hight on growth and yield of ratooning rices
Publication Title: Science Bulletin of the Faculty of Agriculture Kyushu University
Abstract Note: Effects of fertilization and cutting hight on growth and yield of ratooning rices were investigated. The highest grain yield of ratooning rices was obtained in highest fertilization and higher cutting plot, which was 199gm-2 and 229gm-2, respectively, in Koshihikari and Yumetsukushi. Total grain yields of parent and ratoon crops were about 700gm-2 in both varieties. Dry matter yield was highest in the same plot, which was 780gm-2 and 739gm-2, respectively, in Koshihikari and Yumetsukushi, and total dry matter yields were over 2000gm-2 in both varieties. These results sugested that the ratooning rice is useful as a succeeding crop of an early culture rice and/or a forage crop in Northern Kyushu. There were significant effects of fertilization and cutting hight on the yields of grain and dry matter and the number of tillers in ratooning rices at 1 % or 5 % probability levels. Fertilization and higher cutting increased the number of tillers, resulting in the increase in grain and dry matter yields. The increase in the number of ripened tillers by the both treatments was mainly due to the increase in the number of secondary and tertiary ones. The leaf number of fourth tillers was smaller than that of others.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Akhgari, H.; Noorhosseini-Niyaki, S. A.
Title: Effects of first harvest time on total yield and yield components in twice harvesting of rice ( Oryza sativa L.) in Rasht, Iran.
Abstract Note: An experiment was conducted to evaluate the effect first harvest time on ratoon crop and main crop yield of rice ( Oryza sativa L.) in Rasht, north of Iran during 2011 crop year. This experiment was done as a randomized complete block design (RCBD) in four replications. The treatments were harvesting main plant in six levels (7, 14, 21, 28, 35,

Author: MuYing, Li; QingHua, Shi; YongJun, Zeng; XiaoHua, Pan; XueMing, Tan; ZhongMing, Wang; MeiHua, Zeng
Title: Effects of growth characters of mid-season hybrid rice on growth and development of ratooning buds and yield of ratooning rice.
Abstract Note: The effects of growth characters of main rice on the growth and development of ratooning buds were studied in 5 hybrid rice combinations that are suitable for ratooning. Photosynthetic capability and root activity of main rice at its later growth stage had significant effects on the development of ratooning buds. The growth and development of ratooning buds were faster in hybrid combinations with low leaf area index during the filling period and high dry matter accumulation in culm and sheath after the milky stage. The culm-bleeding-intensity of the first and second nodes from the top had close correlations with growth and development of ratooning buds, with coefficients of 0.78 and 0.67 during the milky and mature stages, respectively. The number of panicles of ratooning rice was also correlated with the number of ear-bearing tillers of the main rice.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Garcia, R. N.; Mabbayad, B. B.; Vergara, B. S.
Title: Effects of growth duration and different levels of light intensity on the ratooning ability of rice.
Abstract Note: Plant with 4 growth duration periods (117, 137, 157, and 177 days after planting) were used to determine the relationship between growth duration and the ratooning ability of BPI-76. In another experiment, Mingolo was subjected to 0,49 and 66% shading treatments at flowering until maturity to determine the effects of low light intensity on ratooning. A negative linear correlation was observed between growth duration and the ability to regenerate ratoon tillers ( r=0.98). However, the total carbohydrate concentration was positively correlated with growth duration ( r=0.88). Rapid generation of ratoon tillers in planting 177 and 137 days after planting might be due to high nitrogen levels in their stubble. Ratoon yield from unshaded crop plants was 34% higher than from crop plants with 66% shading. The increase in yield was due to a higher number of total spikelets per panicle and reduced percentage of unfilled spikelets in the unshaded plants. Plants with 0 and 49% shading did not differ significantly in growth and yield parameters. The total carbohydrates concentration was negatively of the crop plant stubble was negatively correlated with the degree of shading ( r=0.95). The nitrogen concentration was independent of the shading treatments.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Quddus, M. A.; Pendleton, J. W.
Title: Effects of growth regulators applied to the main crop on ratoonability of IR9784-52-2-3-2 in pots.
Abstract Note: Growth regulators were applied during the 1981 dry season at crop flowering or at the late milk stage. IAA, NAA, GA3, and 2,4-D were sprayed as aq. sol. at 1, 10 or 100 p.p.m. and 3 ml/plant, and carbofuran was broadcast in prill form at 1 kg a.i./ha. There were no significant effects on yield of the main crop or on yield components of the ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Yazdpour, Hossein; Shahri, Mohamad Mehdi; Soleymani, Ali; Shahrajabian, Mohamad Hesam
Title: Effects of harvesting time and harvesting height on grain yield and agronomical characters in rice ratoon (Oryza sativa L.)
Abstract Note: Rice is the staple food and it is the second most important food in Iran. In order to survey the effects of harvest time and harvest height on grain yield and yield components of rice (Taroem Hasemi variety), an experiment was done in Sari province in 2009. A split plot design within randomized complete block design with 3 replications was used. In this experiment, harvest time was considered as the main factor at two levels (T1 the first harvest on 29 th August and T2 8 th September), and harvest height was considered as sub factor (H1 level ground, H2 10 cm, H3 20 cm, H4 30 cm and H5 40 cm). Harvest time had significant effect on grain yield and harvest index. Plant height, flag leaf length, panicle length, straw yield and biological yield were not significantly affected by harvest time. Harvest time and interaction of harvest time and harvesting height had no significant influence on experimental characteristics. On the basis of the results the highest plant height, flag lead length, panicle length, grain yield, straw yield, biological yield and harvest index were obtained on 29 th August harvesting time. There were no significant differences between harvesting height treatment, but the highest yield was related to harvesting height of 40 cm. The low grain yield of the rice may be attributed to the poor management of cutting height and harvesting time during the cultivation and harvesting period. The results of the survey concluded that the harvesting at 40 cm height on 29 th August had the potential to produce higher yields.

Author: Eitzen, J. B.
Title: Effects of main crop nitrogen on rice ( Oryza sativa L.).
Publication Title: Dissertation Abstracts International. B, Sciences and Engineering
Abstract Note: Two early season rice cultivars, Gulfmont (semidwarf) and Lebonnet (tall), were drill-sown on phosphatic settling pond clays in Polk County, Florida. Phosphatic clays are characterized as smectites, carbonate-fluorapatite, attapulgite and other soil constituents which form a fertile soil environment. 50, 100, 150, 200 or 250 kg N as urea/ha was applied basally before permanent flooding of the main crop. The ratoon crop received 100 kg/ha applied basally before permanent flooding. Total nonstructural carbohydrates (TNC) in main crop stubble, decreased as N rates increased. Significant and positive correlation was found between early ratoon tiller number (14 and 28 DAH [days after harvest]) and TNC concn in the 1988 main crop stubble. Main crop tiller number/m increased as main crop N rates increased for both cultivars, while Lebonnet produced more tillers than Gulfmont. Ratoon tiller data showed no N effect; however, Lebonnet produced more tillers than Gulfmont. Number of main crop panicles/m (PM) increased as N rates increased, with Lebonnet producing more panicles than Gulfmont. Ratoon crop PM data showed no N effect, and Lebonnet again produced more PM than Gulfmont. Gulfmont produced more grains/panicle than Lebonnet in both main and ratoon crops. Variable plant density in 1988 resulted in unreliable yield data. In 1989 yields of Lebonnet (6.48 t/ha) were greater than Gulfmont (5.65 t). Ratoon crop data showed no N effect for Gulfmont while Lebonnet displayed a quadratic N response. Max. ratoon yields were 3.50 t for both cultivars. Total yield data for both cultivars exhibited a linear N effect. Total yields of Lebonnet were greater than Gulfmont (7.70 and 7.18 t, resp.).
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Mahale, S. R.; Salunkhe, C. D.; Bonde, R. D.; Attarde, D. R.
Title: Effects of methods of ratooning and fertilizer levels on productivity of red gram (ICPL-87)
Abstract Note: The benefits of ratooning have been universally recognised. With introduction of short duration (determinate type) pigeonpea (Cajanus cajan L. Millps), cultivar ICPL-87, ratooning has been found to give almost equal yield as that of main crop in shorter span of time and it is thus possible to achieve a two fold increase in pigeonpea yield. A field experiment on the effect of ratooning methods and levels of fertilizers on pigeonpea (red gram) was conducted on medium type of soils (60 cm depth) at the Agronomy Farm, College of Agriculture, Dhule, during kharif reasons of 1990-91, 1991-92 and 1992-93, the ratoon of which was raised in rabi seasons. The treatments comprised three methods of ratooning (plucking of pods, cutting of pods cluster bearing portion of branches and cutting of main branches and three fertilizer levels (o. 12.5 kg N + 25 kg P/ha and 25 kg N + 50 kg P/ha). The results indicated that application of full recommended dose (25 kg N + 50 kg P/ha) and ratooning with plucking of pods produced the highest and significantly more yield of ratoon as well as total productivity per hectare than rest of the treatment combinations.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); Web of Science

Author: HongFei, Chen; ZhiXing, Zhang; WenXiong, Lin
Title: Effects of nitrogen application for bud development on protein expression of ratooning buds of rice.
Publication Title: Zhongguo Shengtai Nongye Xuebao / Chinese Journal of Eco-Agriculture
Abstract Note: Ratooning rice, with significant improvement in potential yield, has become a major farming system to raise multiple crop index. Ratooning rice yield is directly related to the rate of ratooning bud germinating into spikes, and thereby enhancing ratooning bud germination is a key element for ratooning rice high yield. Numerous studies on rice eco-physiology have shown that nitrogen application enhances bud development also strongly promotes ratooning bud germination. However, the molecular mechanism of nitrogen application for bud development to promote ratooning bud germination has remained unclear. This paper studied the effects of nitrogen application for bud development on protein expression of ratooning buds of rice and the corresponding physiological characteristics by using comparative proteomics and relative physiological indicators. A total of 20 differentially expressed proteins were detected in different treatments in 2-DE maps of ratooning bud proteome. The proteins involved in energy metabolism, growth regulation, defense response to stress, etc. The results indicated that the expression abundance of nucleoside diphosphate kinase protein involved in energy metabolism was down-regulated and the proteins involved in photosynthesis (probable photosystem II oxygen-evolving complex protein and cytochrome b6-f complex iron-sulfur subunit) were up-regulated during ratooning bud germination. Furthermore, protein expressions were higher under nitrogen application treatment than non-fertilization treatment on 7 d and 14 d after nitrogen application for bud development. It suggested that nitrogen application for ratooning bud development significantly slowed the down-regulation of proteins involved in energy metabolism, and promoted the up-regulation of proteins involved in photosynthesis. Thus ratooning buds mediated by fertilization treatment had relatively stronger energy synthesis and photoautotroph capabilities, which better met the needs of energy and material for ratooning bud germination and differentiation. Six protein spots involved in cellular growth and five protein spots involved in resistance were detected and identified in the study. Among them, two protein spots (translationally-controlled tumor protein homolog and actin-depolymerizing factor) were down-regulated and nine protein spots (e.g., germin-like protein, ABA/WDS-induced protein, putative quinone-oxidoreductase QR2, Cu-Zn superoxide dismutase and dirigent-like protein) were up-regulated during the ratooning bud germination. Furthermore, expression abundance of proteins (e.g., ABA/WDS-induced protein and actin-depolymerizing factor on the 7th and 14th day, germin-like protein on the 7th day of fertilization) was lower under nitrogen application treatment than non-fertilization treatment. Proteins (e.g., translationally-controlled tumor protein homolog, putative quinone-oxidoreductase QR2, Cu-Zn superoxide dismutase and dirigent-like protein on the 7th and 14th day, germin-like protein on the 14th day) had higher expressions under fertilization treatment than non-fertilization treatment. It indicated that nitrogen application for ratooning bud development relatively cut down the expression abundance of proteins that inhibited ratooning bud germination. Meanwhile, it increased the expression abundance of proteins related to cell division, elongation and resistance, which promoted the germination of ratooning bud and enhanced the ability to resist adverse conditions. Therefore compared with those under non-fertilization treatment, living bud rate and length of the 2nd to the 5th ratooning bud were significantly higher in nitrogen application treatment. As a result, nitrogen application for bud development significantly improved effective panicle number, seed setting rate and grain yield of ratooning rice, which was aimed at getting high yield and significant improvement in ratooning rice production.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Petroudi, E.R.; Noormohammadi, G.; Mirhadi, M.J.; Madani, H.; Mobasser, H.R.
Title: Effects of nitrogen fertilization and rice harvest height on agronomic yield indices of ratoon rice-berseem clover intercropping system
Abstract Note: To determine the effect of nitrogen, main crop harvest height of rice and intercropping of berseem clover (Trifolium alexandrinum L.) with rice ratoon (Oryza sativa L.) on agronomic yield indices a series of field experiments were conducted at different dates in 2007-2008 and 2008-2009. The experimental design was a split-split plot with randomized complete block design with three replications. Accordingly, three levels of N (0, 35 and 70 kg ha-1) in main plots, two planting dates of berseem clover (coincident with main crop harvest and 40 days after it) in sub plots and two harvesting heights (10 and 40 cm above the soil surface) in sub-sub plots were laid out. The application of 70 kg N ha-1 and short harvest height (10 cm) yielded the highest ratoon rice grain, ratoon days to 50% heading and harvest index. The best biological yield was obtained from higher harvest height as well. Qualitative traits such as gelatinization temperature (GT) and protein content (PC) increased with large amount of N. But amylose content (AC) and gel consistency (GC) were not affected by experimental treatments. Effect of nitrogen and harvest height on fresh and dry weight of both cuts, protein content in the first cutting and total land equivalent ratio (LER) were significant at 1% level. The highest fresh and dry weight yield was obtained by application of 35 kg N ha-1. The highest protein and total LER obtained from higher N application (70 kg N ha-1). All studied traits had the highest value in shorter harvest height and the first planting date of berseem clover.
Manual Tags: ALL(ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Berseem clover; Harvest height; Intercropping; nitrogen; Oryza sativa; Ratoon rice; relevant; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; Trifolium; Trifolium alexandrinum; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Way, M. O.; Reay-Jones, F. P. F.; Stout, M. J.; Tarpley, L.
Title: Effects of nitrogen fertilizer applied before permanent flood on the interaction between rice and rice water weevil (Coleoptera : Curculionidae)
Abstract Note: Nitrogen fertilizer was applied to rice, Oryza sativa L., before permanent flood to determine the interaction between rice and the rice water weevil, Lissorhoptrus oryzophilus Kuschel (Coleoptera: Curculionidae), through a series of experiments conducted over a 3-yr period in Texas and Louisiana. Both absolute and relative percentage of yield loss because of L. oryzophilus feeding was not affected by fertilizer rates in the Texas experiment. Absolute yield loss increased with nitrogen rates in 2001 and 2002 in the Louisiana experiment; however, percentage of yield loss was not affected. This finding suggests that nitrogen rate does not affect tolerance of rice to L. oryzophilus injury. In the Texas experiment, differences were detected for ratoon crop yield among nitrogen rates and insecticide that were applied at preflood on the main crop, indicating a carryover of fertilizer and insecticide effects from the main to the ratoon crop. L. oryzophilus populations tended to increase with nitrogen fertilizer in the Louisiana experiment. Our results show that farmers should not increase preflood nitrogen fertilizer to increase tolerance of rice to L. oryzophilus injury.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: ZhaoWei, Jiang; WenXiong, Lin; YiZhen, Li; ChuanYing, Zhuo; HuaAn, Xie
Title: Effects of nitrogen fertilizer rates on dry matter accumulation and transportation in ratooning rice.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted in 2000 to study the effects of nitrogen fertilizer rates on dry matter accumulation and transportation in ratooning rice. Fertilizer application rates were designed at 0 (control), 57.5, 115.0, 172.5, 230.0, and 287.5 kg/ha. Photosynthetic efficiency was significantly enhanced in main rice receiving optimum nitrogen rates to promote bud and tiller. Dry matter accumulation in leaves and stem sheaths increased. Large amount of dry matter remained in rice stubble after harvesting, thus contributed to the increase of productive tillers and leaf area, and increasing the photosynthetic products of ratooning rice. Optimal nitrogen rates played a very important role in increasing transport rates of dry matter from the stubble and leaves of main rice, thus resulting in significant increases in dry matter accumulation in ratooning rice. In the period from full heading to ripening of ratooning crop, the net accumulation of dry matter, panicle number and grain yield was parabolically related to nitrogen rate used to promote bud and tiller. The grain yield of ratooning crop exposed to 241.3 kg N/ha was the highest.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: ZhaoWei, Jiang; WenXiong, Lin; YiZhen, Li; ChuanYing, Zhuo; HuiJie, Yang; HuaAn, Xie
Title: Effects of nitrogen fertilizer rates on some physiological characteristics of ratooning rice.
Abstract Note: The effects of nitrogen fertilizer rates on some physiological characteristics of ratooning rice were studied in a field plot experiment carried out in 2000. Six nitrogen treatments were used: 0 (control), 57.5, 115.0, 172.5, 230.0, and 287.5 kg/ha. The results showed that the activity of nitrate reductase, chlorophyll contents and net photosynthetic rate in leaves of ratooning rice increased with the nitrogen application rate. The biochemical analysis indicated that the optimum nitrogen application rate also increased the activities of cell defence enzymes, thereby reducing membrane damage by active oxygen species produced in the process of senescence. Consequently, this protected the photosynthetic function of green leaves in rice and enhanced root activity, which in turn delayed senescence and increased yield of rice.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: ZhaoWei, Jiang; WenXiong, Lin; YiZhen, Li; ChuanYing, Zhuo; HuaAn, Xie
Title: Effects of nitrogen fertilizer rates on uptake and distribution of nitrogen in ratooning rice.
Abstract Note: The effects of N fertilizer rates on uptake and distribution of N in ratooning rice were studied in field experiments in 2000. The relationship between N uptake and its recovery rate with nitrogen application rates for promoting bud and tiller in main rice and ratooning rice was a parabola curve. After applying nitrogen fertilizer, the amount of N uptake decreased with the growth of crops. About 1/3 of N uptake from the nitrogen fertilizer was deposited in the main rice stubble. The total amount of N accumulated in the stubble was closely related to nitrogen application for promoting bud and tiller, the relationship exhibited a parabola curve. The nitrogen source in the stubble of the main season was gradually transported to the tillers of ratoon crop after the main crop was harvested. It played a great role in bud sprouting and tiller growing. N accumulation in the leaves and stem-sheath of ratoon rice increased with the increase of nitrogen application, and a large amount of N in the parts of ratoon rice were transported to the panicles after full heading. The apparent transportation rate was 57-76% of N translocation from the stubble of the main crop. This fact indicated that the nitrogen transported from the stubble and other parts was the main nitrogen source deposited in grains of ratooning rice. The grain yield of ratooning crop showed a parabolic correlation with the application rate for promoting buds and tillers. The highest grain yield of ratooning crop was obtained with the N application rate of 241.3 kg/ha.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Xiong, H.; Fang, W.; Tan, Z. B.
Title: Effects of number of axillary buds and main crop cutting time on ratoon crop yield.
Abstract Note: In field trials the effects of cutting at 33 cm height 22-34 d after heading and of number of axillary buds sprouting on yield of ratoon rice cv. Shanyou 63 were studied. Number of axillary buds was correlated with carbohydrate content and stem and sheath wt, which increased as cutting of the main crop was delayed. Cutting date of the main crop was correlated with yield of the main crop, number of axillary buds sprouting and number of productive panicles and yield of the ratoon crop. Cutting the main crop at 34 d after heading, when axillary buds began sprouting, gave the highest yields for both main and ratoon crops (8.1 and 1.8 t/ha, resp.). The increased yield of the ratoon crop was attributed to higher numbers of productive panicles.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Akhgari, H.; Noorhosseini-Niyaki, S. A.; Sadeghi, S. M.
Title: Effects of planting methods on yield and yield components of ratoon and main plant of rice ( Oryza sativa L.) in Rasht, Iran.
Publication Title: Indian Journal of Fundamental and Applied Life Sciences
Abstract Note: In order to evaluate the effect of planting methods on ratoon yield of rice varieties ( Oryza sativa L.) an experiment was conducted in Rasht, north of Iran. In this study was used a split-plot on base of randomized complete block design with three replications. The main-plots were variety with four levels (Hashemi, Khazar, Hassani and Ali-Kazemi) and the sub-plots were planting methods with four levels (broadcast direct seeding, linear direct seeding, hill direct seeding and transplanting). Results showed that effect of variety on main plant and ratoon yield of rice were significant (p<0.01) that maximum average of main plant and ratoon yield were in treatments of Hashemi and Hassani with means of 364.05 and 146.92 g/m 2, respectively. Also, there was a significant difference (p<0.05) between treatments of planting methods regarding ratoon yield that maximum average of ratoon yield (M=139.08 g/m 2) was in transplanting.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Bond, Jason A.; Bollich, Patrick K.
Title: Effects of pre-harvest desiccants on rice yield and quality
Abstract Note: Field studies were conducted from 2000 to 2003 to determine the effect of paraquat and sodium chlorate applied as pre-harvest desiccants on rice yield and quality. In these trials, paraquat and sodium chlorate were applied 7 and 3 d prior to main-crop rice harvest (pre-harvest). In the first study, the rice cultivars Cocodrie, Cypress, and Wells responded differently to desiccants. Paraquat could be an effective desiccant for rice, but dose, application timing, and cultivar must be taken into account prior to its use. In the second study, both doses of sodium chlorate applied 7 d pre-harvest reduced head rice yield, but only the dose of 6.7 kg/ha reduced head rice yield when applied 3 d pre-harvest. Sodium chlorate should be applied to rice as a desiccant at 4.5 kg/ha no earlier than 3 d pre-harvest to avoid losses in grain yield and quality.

Author: Thompson, T. N.; Rister, M. E.; Grant, W. R.; McCauley, G. N.; Turner, F. T.; Stansel, J. W.; Klosterboer, A. D.
Title: Effects of rice quality on profit-maximizing ratoon crop nitrogen decisions.
Abstract Note: Optimal nitrogen rates for the ratoon (second cropping) rice crop are derived utilizing estimated production functions for rice grain quantity and quality. Field-level data for 464 ratoon rice-cropped fields representing more than 50 000 acres were collected in Texas, USA, during 1987-89. Returns above variable costs (RAVC R) are calculated using both a non-quality-dependent rice price and a price based on grain quality factors. When considering quality, maximization of RAVC R requires lower nitrogen rates and realizes lower RAVC R per acre than are projected based on non-quality dependent prices. Results reinforce existing recommendations and cast doubt on decisions to exceed recommended rates.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; ratoon* N5 (oryza OR rice); relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Huang, Z.-G.; Tu, N.-M.; Jiang, J.-A.; Qin, P.; Huang, Z.-C.
Title: Effects of rudimental stubble heights on the yield and source-sink characteristics of ratooning rice: a case study for two-line hybrid rice Peiliangyou 210
Abstract Note: Rudimental stubble height of rationing rice is one of important factors on high-yielding cultivation. Effects of rudimental stubble heights on the yield and source-sink characteristics of ratooning rice were studied in two-line hybrid rice Peiliangyou 210. Three rudimental stubble heights were arranged in the study, which were 40 cm, 20 cm, and 10 cm respectively. The results indicated that rudimental stubble heights affected source-flow-sink characteristics of ratooning rice significantly. With the decreasing of rudimental stubble heights, ( 1) the growing stage of ratooning rice was postponed, but stubble height, spike length and leaf area index ( LAI) were increased, (2) the activities of leaf sucrose-phosphate synthetase ( SPS) decreased, while the crop growth rate and the number and area of big vascular bundle of different internodes and the activity of catalase were increased during the grain filling stage. (3 ) the accumulation and output rates of non-structure carbohydrate content in stem and sheath, the ratio of grain number to leaf area and specific leaf weight, the spikelets per panicle and the yield were increased. In Changsha region, the suitable rudimental stubble height of two-line hybrid rice Peiliangyou 210 is 10 cm.
Manual Tags: ALL(ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Asia; carbohydrate; Changsha; China; Cultivation; enzyme activity; Eurasia; Far East; growth rate; height determination; Hunan; hybridization; Ratooning rice; relevant; Rice; Rudimental stubble height; Scopus; search.rice; Source and sink characteristics; source-sink dynamics; SPV; stubble; Two-line hybrid rice; Yielding characteristics; Yield response

Author: GuiLian, Zhang; NaiMei, Tu; JuHong, Yuan; Peng, Liu; ShunTang, Zhang
Title: Effects of sowing stage on the sprouting of axillary bud and yield of ratooning rice.
Abstract Note: The effects of sowing time on the sprouting of axillary bud and yield of ratooned rice hybrids Peiliangyou 500 and Shanyou 63 were determined. Rice sown on 31 March recorded the highest yield, whereas those sown in

Author: Zhen-xie, Yi; Wen-xin, Zhou; Nai-mei, Tu
Title: Effects of Stubble Height of the Main Crop on Source-Sink Characteristics and Assimilates Transportation in Ratooning Rice
Abstract Note: The characteristics of source, sink and flow of ratooning rice with different stubble heights of the main crop were studied with eight rice varieties as materials. According to yield of ratooning rice with different stubble heights of the main crop, the eight varieties were classified into three ratooning types, Such as high-stubble type (HST), low-stubble type (LST) and high/medium-stubble type (HMST). Decline of the stubble height resulted in decreased number of effective panicles and increased grain number per panicle in ratooning rice, especially for the grain number per panicle in ratooning rice of LST varieties. The leaf area index in ratooning rice of FIST and HMST varieties was the highest under the high stubble treatment (40 cm), whereas that in ratooning rice of LST varieties increased with the decline of the stubble height. The leaf photosynthetic rates from full heading to 20 days after full heading in ratooning rice of HST varieties were higher under the medium (20 cm) or high (40 cm) stubble treatments, whereas the leaf photosynthetic rates at the full heading stage in ratooning rice of HMST and LST varieties were higher under the high stubble treatment and those at 10 days and 20 days after full heading were higher under the medium (20 cm) or low (10 cm) stubble treatments. The crop growth rates of ratooning rice of HST varieties were the highest under the high stubble treatment. whereas those of HMST and LST varieties were the highest under the low or medium stubble treatments. The activity of catalase in rachis branches of ratooning rice of HMST and LST varieties improved with declining stubble height, whereas a contrary trend was observed for HST ones. The transport rates of carbohydrate in stems and sheathes of ratooning rice of HST varieties were higher under the high stubble treatment, and those of LST ones were higher under the low and medium Stubble treatments. These results indicate that the effect of stubble height of the main crop on characteristics of source, sink and flow of ratooning rice were closely related to ratooning types of rice varieties.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: ZhenXie, Yi; NaiMei, Tu; PingPing, Chen
Title: Effects of stubble height on the root system of ratooning rice.
Abstract Note: A field experiment with rice cv. Peiai 64S * E32 was carried out in Changsha, Hunan, China in 2002. Seven stubble heights, ranging from 10 to 40 cm, were used to study the effects of stubble height on the recovery and maintenance of activities of roots of first cropping rice (FCR) in the ratooning season and on the generation of ratooning roots. The ratooning roots mainly came from ratooning tillers of lower nodes. At full heading stage of ratooning rice, the amount of ratooning roots and the ratio between ratooning roots and the total roots increased with the decrease in the stubble height of FCR, and the amount of FCR in ratooning rice (RR) decreased. These results indicate that higher stubble height was favourable to the recovery and maintenance of activities of FCR, and lower stubble height was favourable to the generation of ratooning roots. Considering the factors (including root amount, root activity and root absorption area) together, the roots of FCR are always the principal part of the roots of RR, regardless of the height of stubble.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: FuXian, Xu; Hong, Xiong; Lin, Zhang; XiaoYi, Guo; YongChuan, Zhu; XingBing, Zhou; Mao, Liu
Title: Effects of the decreased index of SPAD value of leaf after full heading on ratooning ability.
Abstract Note: Objective: Many studies on the source-sink characters of high-yielding combinations of main crop or ratooning rice, but there were few studies on high-yielding combinations total yield of main crop and ratooning rice. In this paper, the relationship between the decreased index of SPAD value of leaf from full heading to harvesting (DISVLFHH) and ratooning ability, the plant characters of main crop for high yielding combinations of main crop and ratooning rice were studied, which could provide a theoretical and practical basis for improvement of high yield breeding and cultivation of hybrid rice. Method: The experiment was conducted with eighteen mid-season rice combinations grown in a traditional high yield cultivation system, in a randomized block design with 3 replications. The results were analyzed through variance, correlation, regression and path analysis. Result: Alive bud rate, born bud rate, effective panicles and grain yield of ratooning rice were the key traits of ratooning ability, which was a an important approach for further high yield of ratooning rice by increasing effective panicles. There were significant or highly significant relationships between spikelets per panicle, the ratio of leaf area to spikelets, the ratio of leaf area to grains, the ratio of leaf area to grain weight, decreased LAI index, DISVLFHH of main crop and alive bud rate, born bud rate, effective panicles, grain yield of ratooning rice, and the partial correlation coefficient between only DISVLFHH among all trais and alive bud rate, born bud rate, effective panicles, grain yield of ratooning rice got significant at 0.05 level. As for one variety, it's impossible that both main crop and ratooning rice could get top grain yield. The high-yielding combinations for 11.5 t per ha of the theory grain yield and 14 t per ha of potential grain yield for main crop and ratooning rice would have the following source-sink characteristics: 160-190 spikelets per panicle, the ratio of leaf area to grain weight 0.0737-0.0827 cm 2 per mg, DISVLFHH 0.4029-0.5409, effective panicles 232.12*10 4-249.40*10 4 per ha, seed setting percentage 81.54%-85.74%, 1000-grain weight 28.58-30.07 g, grain weight 4.13-4.43 g per panicle. Conclusion: Increasing effective panicles is an important approach for further high yield of ratooning rice, DISVLFHH of main crop can be used as a new evaluation index for ratooning ability, and the combinations with middle-big spikelets per panicle are the key characteristic for selection of mid-season rice hybrids for high yield of main crop and ratooning rice.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Nakano, Hiroshi; Morita, Satoshi
Title: Effects of time of first harvest, total amount of nitrogen, and nitrogen application method on total dry matter yield in twice harvesting of rice
Abstract Note: We examined the effects of time of first harvest, total amount of nitrogen, and nitrogen application method on the total dry matter yield of a twice-harvested rice (Oryza sativa L.) cultivar Taporuri grown in southwestern Japan. The highest total dry matter yield was 27.1 t ha−1. We examined the effects of two times of first harvest (booting stage versus full heading stage). Plants harvested at the full heading stage produced 50% higher dry matter yield of first crop than those harvested at the booting stage, because the plants had greater weights per tiller than those harvested at the booting stage. Plants harvested at the booting stage produced 37% higher dry matter yield of second crop than those harvested at the full heading stage, because the plants had greater dry weights per tiller than those harvested at the full heading stage. Overall, plants harvested at the full heading stage produced 8% higher total dry matter yield than those harvested at the booting stage. We also examined the effects of two total amounts of nitrogen (300 kg N ha−1 versus 150 kg N ha−1) and three nitrogen application methods (method 1: 33.3% applied at transplanting, 66.7% at the maximum tiller number stage, 0.0% at 7 days after the first harvest, and 0.0% at 21 days after the first harvest; method 2: 33.3, 33.3, 16.7, and 16.7%, respectively; method 3: 33.3, 0.0, 33.3%, and 33.3%, respectively). For the first crop, plants that received 300 kg N ha−1 produced 10% higher dry matter yield than those that received 150 kg N ha−1 in 2004. Plants that underwent nitrogen application methods 1 and 2 produced 21% and 23% higher dry matter yield of first crop than plants that underwent method 3, respectively. The increase in number of tillers per meter in the 300 kg N ha−1 treatment and in nitrogen application methods 1 and 2 resulted in the higher dry matter yields of first crop in these treatments. For the second crop, plants that received 300 kg N ha−1 produced 10% higher dry matter yield of second crop than those that received 150 kg N ha−1. Plants that underwent nitrogen application methods 2 and 3 produced 57% and 56% higher dry matter yield of second crop than method 1, respectively. The increase in number of tillers per meter in the 300 kg N ha−1 treatment and in nitrogen application methods 2 and 3 resulted in the higher dry matter yields of second crop in these treatments. Overall, plants that received 300 kg N ha−1 produced 7% higher dry matter yield than those that received 150 kg N ha−1 and plants that underwent nitrogen application method 2 produced 21% and 11% higher dry matter yield than those that underwent methods 1 and 3, respectively. Therefore, our findings suggest that to produce the highest total dry matter yield the best time for first harvest is the full heading stage and the best nitrogen management is to provide 300 kg N ha−1 in accordance with nitrogen application method 2.
Manual Tags: Agricultural management; ALL(ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Asia; Booting stage; cropping practice; Crops; Crop yield; cultivar; Cultivation; dry matter; dry matter yield; Eurasia; Far East; fertilizer application; Forage rice; harvesting; Japan; nitrogen; Nitrogen management; Oryza sativa; Oryza sativa L.; Plants (botany); Ratoon cropping; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); relevant; Rice; ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; Taporuri; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Twice harvesting; Web of Science

Author: Nakano, Hiroshi; Morita, Satoshi
Title: Effects of twice harvesting on total dry matter yield of rice
Abstract Note: We examined the effect of twice harvesting of forage rice with the first harvest at the full heading stage on total dry matter yield in the cultivars Taporuri, Mohretsu, and Hinohikari and in line Saikaishi 253 in southwestern Japan. Taporuri produced the highest total dry matter yield, with a value 60% higher than that of Hinohikari. The first crop of Taporuri had a longer duration of vegetative growth than those of Mohretsu and Hinohikari, and had the highest dry matter yield because of its greater weight per tiller than Hinohikari and its more tillers per square meter than Saikaishi 253, which had a similar duration of vegetative growth. The second crops of Mohretsu, Taporuri, and Saikaishi 253 had longer vegetative growth and higher dry matter yields than Hinohikari. Dry matter yields of both crops were closely related to the duration of vegetative growth and the weight per tiller, but not to tillers per square meter. These results suggest that cultivars with a long duration of vegetative growth, high weight per tiller, and adequate tillers per square meter can produce high dry matter yield in both crops. There was a significant interaction (P < 0.05) in total dry matter yield between cultivar or line and cultivation type. The total dry matter yield of Taporuri in twice harvesting was about 10% higher than that in once harvesting, whereas that of Hinohikari was about 10% lower. The suitability for twice harvesting ([total dry matter yield in twice harvesting]/[total dry matter yield in once harvesting]) was significantly positively correlated (r = 0.875) with the increase in dry weight before the full heading stage, but significantly negatively correlated (r = -0.903) with the increase in dry weight between full heading and the yellow ripe stage. Thus, cultivars with a high increase in dry weight before full heading appear to be more suitable for twice harvesting than those with a high increase between full heading and the yellow ripe stage. In addition, our study showed that twice harvesting can prevent lodging in Taporuri, thereby increasing the suitability of this cultivar as a forage rice. Our results suggest that twice harvesting can be performed in southwestern Japan and warmer regions.

Author: T, SASAKI
Title: ELONGATION OF THE RATOONS IN RICE PLANTS INOCULATED WITH FUSARIUM-MONILIFORME ON THE LEAVES AND STEMS
Publication Title: Annals of the Phytopathological Society of Japan
Abstract Note: The stems of the rice plants of the Towada strain grown from seeds were sprayed with a F. moniliforme conidia suspension solution. The plants were cut 5 cm from the stem base at harvest time, and growth, wilting, and conidial formation of the tillers [ratoons] were studied. The infection rate of 300 plants was 1.3-20.7%. The tillers grew mainly from the sheaths of the 2nd-4th leaves, the tillers growing after harvest showed elongations, wilting and conidial formations, and the leaves showed some brown infected spots. F. moniliforme was isolated from leaf sections of plants with white fungal colonies on the leaves (Group I), sections taken 2-3 cm apart from the leaves with the fungal colonies of the same plants (Group II), leaf sections sprayed with a conidial suspension solution (Group III), and sections from the leaves which had been in contact with the naturally infected plants (Group IV). The rate of isolation of F. moniliforme was 65.5% in Group I, 10.0% in Group II, 6.9% in Group III, and 6.3-11.7% in Group IV. Hyphae were found inside and outside the diseased tissues. Plants infected with F. moniliforme on the leaves and stems, however, did not show systemic symptoms of the infection. Infection of rice plants by F. monoliforme through the leaves and stems insignificantly influences grain yield.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Derzavin, A. I.
Title: [English title not available]
Abstract Note: Experiments on intraspecific hybridization, variety tests and seed production are receiving special attention. From Ukrainka, plants with higher rust resistance and yield have been selected. A special study has been made of the local races of spring and winter wheat and barley and selections are being made. Promising forms of spring Triticum durum have been obtained in this way; similarly, lines of winter wheat surpassing Kooperatorka by 5-7 c. per ha. have been selected. Rust-resistant selections of Kanred * Fulcaster and Illini Chief have been produced and have exceeded the standards in yield. Other selections include a naked barley exceeding the standard in yield by 10 per cent. The hybrids of wheat with perennial rye when pollinated with normal pollen set seed mainly from unreduced egg cells. Large numbers of amphidiploids are expected and the work of producing them is being carried out on a mass scale by the workers in the collective farms. The perennial hybrids all have one serious defect, brittle ears, but are drought resistant and of good baking quality. Hybrids have been obtained between cultivated and wild sunflowers, some of which bear both seeds and tubers.
