Author: Larkin, Philip J.; Newell, Matthew T.; Hayes, Richard C.; Aktar, Jesmin; Norton, Mark R.; Moroni, Sergio J.; Wade, Len J.
Title: Progress in developing perennial wheats for grain and grazing
Abstract Note: Dual-purpose cereals have been important for increasing the flexibility and profitability of mixed farming enterprises in southern Australia, providing winter feed when pasture dry matter production is low, and then recovering to produce grain. A perennial dual-purpose cereal could confer additional economic and environmental benefits. We establish that, at the end of a second growth season, selected perennial cereals were able to achieve up to 10-fold greater below-ground biomass than a resown annual wheat. We review and expand the data on available, diverse, perennial, wheat-derived germplasm, confirming that perenniality is achievable but that further improvements are essential through targeted breeding. Although not yet commercially deployable, the grain yields and dry matter production of the best performing lines approach the benchmarks predicted to achieve profitability. On reviewing the genomic composition of the most promising wheat-derived perennials, we conclude that the best near-term prospect of a productive breeding program for a perennial, wheat-derived cereal will utilise a diploid, perennial donor species, and the most promising one thus far is Thinopyrum elongatum. Furthermore, the breeding should be aimed at complete wheat-Th. elongatum amphiploids, a hybrid synthetic crop analogous to triticale. We advocate the generation of many primary amphiploids involving a diversity of Th. elongatum accessions and a diversity of adapted annual wheat cultivars. Primary perennial amphiploids would be inter-crossed and advanced with heavy, early-generation selection for traits such as semi-dwarf plant height, non-shattering heads, large seed size and good self-fertility, followed by later generation selection for robust perenniality, days to flowering, grain yield, forage yield, stability of grain yield across seasons, and disease resistance.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.grain; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: XiaoQi, Zhu; QiYun, Deng; ChunGuang, Chen; Wen, Zhuang; Wen, Wu
Title: Progress in research on ratooning rice and ratooning utilization of super hybrid rice.
Abstract Note: Ratooning rice is a type of rice with a special cultivating system. The research progresses on ratooning rice and ratooning utilization of super hybrid rice are reviewed. Super hybrid rice has a great yield potential, however, how to give full play to its yield potential and how to further increase rice yield by means of the ratooning system would be a new topic for the development of super hybrid rice.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Anonymous
Title: Progress reported in the development of perennial wheat for Canada.
Abstract Note: A brief report is presented of an interview with L. H. Shebeski on perennial wheat. It is not yet known whether the perennial wheat now being grown experimentally at Saskatoon would be suitable as a forage or as a grain crop. Experimental results have, however, indicated that it might prove useful as a spring wheat; the grain ripens while the straw is still green and if the crop was swathed instead of being harvested with a binder or directly combined, the straw could provide good feed. The perennial wheat is of a bread wheat type, and is reported to have superior disease resistance but is insufficiently hardy. Yield, drought resistance, and milling and baking quality have not yet been tested.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Anonymous
Title: Prospect for creation of perennial wheat not bright says Saskatchewan Professor.
Abstract Note: A very brief report is given of an address by J. B. Harrington to the Saskatchewan Agricultural Graduates' Association. Canadian plant breeders, the speaker pointed out, have only had limited success in the development of perennial wheat, and particular mention is made of unsatisfactory yield in seasons of insufficient rainfall, and the difficulties of weed control. Brief reference to current breeding work on winter wheat is also included.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Shi, Chunlong; Tian, Chao; Li, Jilin; Zhang, Yanming
Title: Prospect of Perennial Wheat in Agro-ecological System
Abstract Note: The development of perennial crops through breeding would help deal with the multiple issues involving environmental conservation and food security in a world of shrinking resources. Perennial wheat offers a new solution to the long-standing problems of soil erosion and degradation associated with conventional annual small-grain cropping systems. This paper presents morphological characteristics and cytogenetics analysis of perennial wheat that from crosses between octoploid trititrigia and Thinopyrum intermedium, introduces the important role of perennial wheat at the development of sustainable agriculture system as well as discusses the significant utilization of perennial wheat in ecological benefits.
Manual Tags: ecological benefits; full text added; perennial W/1 grain; perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat); perennial wheat,Thinopyrum; relevant; ScienceDirect; search.grain; search.wheat; soil erosion control; SPV; Sustainable agriculture

Author: Cox, Thomas S.; Glover, Jerry D.; Van Tassel, David L.; Cox, Cindy M.; DeHaan, Lee R.
Title: Prospects for developing perennial-grain crops
Abstract Note: Perennial plants, growing in mixtures, make up most of the world's natural terrestrial biomes. In contrast, monocultures of annual crops are sown on more than two-thirds of global cropland. Grain and oilseed crops are the foundation of the human diet, but to date there are no perennial species that produce adequate grain harvests. Yet perennial plant communities store more carbon, maintain better soil and water quality, and manage nutrients more conservatively than do annual plant communities, and they have greater biomass and resource management capacity. These advantages provide a base from which to begin hybridization and selection for increased resource allocation to developing seeds, a decades-long process that must overcome or circumvent genetic complications. Breeding programs aimed at developing perennial grain crops have been initiated in wheat, sorghum, sunflower, intermediate wheatgrass, and other species.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); Web of Science

Author: Ali, M. H.; Hoque, M. S.; Jahiruddin, M.
Title: Prospects of boro ratoon cropping in alleviating rural poverty in haor areas of Bangladesh.
Abstract Note: The haor areas in Bangladesh (low lying basins that stay under water for about 6 months of the year) are mainly located in the greater Sylhet-Mymensingh districts and the areas' economy is highly under-developed because only a single boro (summer) crop can be grown a year. The government has undertaken embankment and sluice-gate projects to protect boro crops from early flash flood water. While the major beneficiaries of these projects will be medium and large farmers who own over 70% of the cultivable land, the landless and small farmers may also benefit from more secured ratoon cultivation. This study, conducted in three haor areas in Sunamganj district, indicates that ratoon cropping is an important source of self-employment for the landless and small farmers and contributes a significant portion of their income. Ratoons are currently grown on only a small proportion of boro land, because of the problem of early flash floods, and lack of interest by medium and large farmers who own the land, for reasons of social prestige. However, the area under ratoon is expected to increase as embankments are completed. Reducing the risk of ratoon cropping through embankments increases the probability that medium and large farms will grow ratoons. The government can protect the interests of the rural poor by enacting rules for a ratoon sharing arrangement.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Sarma, Kamal; Ravisankar, N.; Roy, S. D.; Grinson, G.; Srivastava, R. C.
Title: Prospects of fish culture in the broad bed and furrow system in Andaman.
Abstract Note: The BBF system of cultivation is a technique of land manipulation to grow vegetables and fodder right in the midst of rice field. The technology involves making of broad beds and furrows alternatively in rice fields. In the BBF, the raised broad bed areas are used for cultivating seasonal vegetable or fodder crops during monsoon season months. To study the economic feasibilities of fish culture in broad bed and furrow system a study was undertaken in south Andaman. Indian major carps and air breathing fishes were cultured in the furrows along with rice (Taichung -sen-Yu) separately. No supplementary feeding and other management techniques were adopted for fishes. From 6000 m 2 area of furrow fish production of 25 and 45 kg of magur and singhi and 78 and 73 kg of Indian major carps were obtained. Best return was obtained in rice+ratoon+ground nut+fishes (singhi and magur) combination and B:C ratio was 0.94 where fishes alone contributed for 12.5 B:C ratio.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Bahar, F. A.; De Datta, S. K.
Title: Prospects of Increasing Tropical Rice Production through Ratooning
Abstract Note: Production of a rice (Oryza saliva L.) crop by ratooning is feasible under some conditions. Ratooning of rice eliminates two labor-saving operations: raising seedlings in the seedbed and transplanting in the main field. Field experiments were conducted for 2 years on Maahas clay (an isothermic clayey mixed Aquic Tropudalf) to evaluate the performance of rice cultivars for ratooning ability and the agronomic practices that affect ratooning. The agronomic practices studied were cutting height of the crop produced from seed (referred to as the “main” crop), N level, plant spacing, water management, and degee of land preparation. All the cultivars that were grown as ratoon crops were infected by the grassy stunt virus disease; the same cultivars grown simultaneously by transplanting and direct seeding were not infected. That indicates the high risks of growing virus-susceptible cultivars as a ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Chuan-hang, Yang; Yu-ping, Wang; Bin, Tu; ZengYu-qing; Shi-gui, Li
Title: QTL Analysis of Cold Resistance and Ratooning Ability by Using indica-japonica RIL Populations in Rice
Abstract Note: A molecular linkage map containing 105 SSR markers was constructed by using a RIL population which was derived from the F-7 descent of a cross between japonica glutinous rice variety Nuo 89-1 and an indica variety Shuhui 527. The cold resistance of bud for both the parents and the RIL was investigated at 5 degrees C low temperature, and their survival and ratooning ability were evaluated under natural temperature conditions in winter. QTL analysis showed that the cold resistance of rice was controlled by QTLs and followed a continuous distribution in RIL population. Two QTL, qCtg3 and qCtg5 controlling cold resistance at bud stage were located on chromosome 3 and 5. explaining 75.57% and 79.04% phenotypic variation, respectively. A major QTL, qCtr5 controlling the survival and ratooning ability in rice was mapped on chromosome 5. Two QTLs(qRa4, qRa5) conferning ratooning capacity were detected on chromosome 4 and 5, explaining 8.17% and 7.09% phenotypic variation, respectively. qCtg5 qCtr5 and qRa5 locus were simultaneously linked to RM153 on chromosome 5, which indicated the relationship of those traits.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: ChuanHang, Yang; YuPing, Wang; Bin, Tu; Ting, Li; Liang, Hu; ShiGui, Li
Title: QTL analysis of rice ratooning ability and related agronomic traits by using RIL populations.
Abstract Note: A molecular linkage map containing 105 SSR marks were constructed by using a RIL population generated from the F 7 descent of a cross of japonica glutinous rice variety 89-1 and an indica heavy panicle backbone hybrid rice lines SH527. By using this map, we mapped 15 QTLs for seven agronomic traits in the normal season, which was distributed on chromosomes 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, and 10, respectively. The LOD value varied from 2.10 to 7.51, and the contribution rate varied from 3.77% to 25.37%, among which seven QTLs had the contribution rate larger than 10.0%. The number of a single trait QTL varied from 1 to 5. Two QTLs ( qRA4, qRA5) affecting rice ratooning ability were detected on chromosomes 4 and 5, the contribution rate was 8.17% and 7.09%, and the additive effect was 0.32 and -0.39, respectively. Thirty-six QTLs for agronomic traits were detected in two seasons and among which eight were detected repeatablely. According to the results, the ratooning ability was remarkably negatively related to the effective ear of the normal season. In addition, the ratooning ability was tightly positively related to the effective ear in the ratooning season, and was negatively related to the grain number per ear and seed density. The QTLs mapping results revealed that the effective ear of normal season and ratooning season is the main factor that affects rice's ratooning ability.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Nagaraja, A.; Mahadevappa, M.
Title: Quality of main and ratoon crop seeds of rice.
Abstract Note: Data are tabulated on germination, vigour and yield-related characters for the ratoon and main crops of 7 varieties. Grain viability deteriorated more quickly in the ratoon than in the main crop, resulting in poor germination, field emergence and vigour. Differences were observed between plants grown from grain collected from the two crops in 1000-grain weight, root and shoot lengths and seedling dry weight.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: SHIBAEV, P. N.
Title: Quality of the grains of wheat-Agropyron hybrids
Publication Title: Trudy Zonal Inst Zernovovo Khoziaistva Nechernozemnoi Polosy Sssr
Abstract Note: A large number of species of wild grasses of the tribe Hordeae, particularly in the genera Aegilops and Agropvron, have a high gluten content in their grains. The percentage of dry protein in the grains of Agropvron elongatum, A. glaucum,, and A. junceum ranged from 24.-3 1.6, and that in wheat vars. Lutescens 062 and Caesium 0111 from 17.7-17.8. Great diversity in protein and gluten content exists even among different strains of the same species of Agropvron. For 170 different annual lines of wheat-Agropyron hybrids the quality of the grain was determined indirectly by the time taken for falling off of the seed coat during fermentation with yeast at 32[degree]C. Of these, 37 were superior to the wheat var. Lutescens 062, 14 were inferior, and 119 about the same. Direct tests of porosity and volume yield of bread in 10 of these gave higher values than Lutescens 062 for 8 vars. One var., no. 22580, was slightly superior to both Lutescens 062 and Caesium 0111 in these qualities and in protein content at both the Gorki-Leninsk and Nemchinovka exp. stations. Fertilization with 1 metric ton of manure, 259 kg. of N, 252 kg. of P, and 126 kg. of K per acre had a greater effect in increasing protein content and bread quality in hybrid 22850 than in Lutescens 062. Perennial wheats nos. 34085 and 23086 have higher dry protein and gluten content than Lutescens 062, and their bread has a higher volume yield, but the color of the flour and bread is dark. Bread made from perennial wheat of the 1940 harvest had a poor texture due to the insufficient ripeness of the grains.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: SKOSYREVA, A. N.
Title: Question of the salt resistance of perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: Seeds of Cicin's perennial wheat No. 34085 were sown in pots in sand and watered with Hell-riegel's solution to which varying quantities of NaCl and Na 2S0 4 had been added. The variety Caesium 0111 was used as control. The perennial wheat seedlings developed more vigorously and produced better plants in solutions containing 0.04% NaCl than in those without NaCl. Thus in the normal solutions without salt the yield of grain was 16.43 grm. and in those with 0.04% NaCl it was 18.46; with 0.25% NaCl the yield was still almost normal and the yield of grain in 0.35% NaCl solutions was only reduced to 11.03; even in 1% solutions some grain was formed. The control plants of Caesium 0111 failed to grow at all in 1% NaCl solutions and produced no grain even in 0.35% and 0.25% solutions. In isotonic solutions of NaCl and Na 2SO 4 the perennial wheats gave higher yields with Na 2SO 4. Thus with 0.35% NaCl the yield per pot (three plants) was 11.03 grm. and with 0.5% Na 2SO 4 it was 14.76 grm. ; with 1% NaCl the yield was 3.63 grm. and with 1.5% Na 2SO 4 it was still 10.76 grm. In the early growth phases however the perennial wheat was less tolerant of the sulfates than the chlorides. The straw was found to contain larger quantities of salts than the grain and in fact exuded much of it on to the surface. The plants grown in high salt concentrations bore quite large grains, which had a higher protein content than those grown without salt.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: cicin, N. V.
Title: Questions of distant hybridization in plants.
Abstract Note: Five generations of hybrids of Triticum x Elymus have now been produced and mutagenic treatments are being applied in an attempt to remove the dominant wheat genes reducing the number of grains per spike. True perennial wheats have been selected from the Triticum x Agropyron hybrids, some of them persisting for two and even three years; a few of them have ears resembling those of bread wheat. Other hybrids produce an aftermath after the grain has been reaped and give several crops of autumn forage; conversely they can be cut for early forage before the grain crop is formed; they have lax ears with vitreous grain of medium size and the ears ripen while the leaves are still green. Among the annual wheats produced from these crosses, five have been approved; one of them, Vostok [East], is completely resistant to loose smut, another, 599, is resistant to bunt and 172 to brown smut [ sic].
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: A, DERZAVIN
Title: Raising perennial wheats and other crops.
Abstract Note: In many crop plants the perennial surpass the annual forms in greatly increased and earlier yields in its second, third and fourth year as compared with its first year's output. Many perennial spring crops are also highly frost resistant. The author's early work with hybrids between wild and cultivated species is mentioned with more recent work on the production of perennial wheat and the problem of eliminating the F 1 sterility in wheat x perennial rye crosses. After 189, 000 pollinations, hybrid combinations were chosen which on back-crossing gave a set of 0.01-2.00 per cent. Only a very small proportion of the plants raised from such seed showed normal fertility. In a cross between Leucurum 1364/1 and perennial rye apparently back-crossed to perennial rye two large seeds were obtained of the Triticum durum type. One of these seeds produced a normally fertile plant. The hybrid proved to have 42 chromosomes and was therefore an amphidiploid resulting from the union of two unreduced gametes. No back-crossing to the rye had therefore occurred. This plant produced seed in 1933 and twice (summer and winter) in 1934 and 1935, thus indicating a perennial wheat had been obtained. The numerous progenies were resistant to drought and rust, being only slightly attacked by brown rust and not at all by stem or yellow rust; they also showed high yields, e.g. 70 grains per ear with a 1000 grain weight up to 50 grm. The perennial wheat is a vigourous plant which in the second year frequently gives a higher yield and usually ripens 10-15 days earlier than the autumn sowing of the first year. It can also be used for hay, yielding about 1-2 tons per hectare. The second harvest in the year amounts to 50-80 per cent of the first and the 1000 grain weight is 35 grm. The winter-hardiness of the hybrids has been little studied but the winter form survived the 1935-36 winter. In 1937 a few plants without the defect of fragile ears were selected and the type is to be tested in variety trials. A coefficient of multiplication of 11, 339 has been obtained and, in 1938 it is hoped, 30, 000 grains may be obtained from 100 plants from one grain. Spring forms were also found among the hybrids. Similar investigations axe being conducted with perennial hybrids from perennial x annual rye and wild perennial rye plants are also being collected for breeding plants suitable for use as hay. Work has also been done on perennial vetches ( Vicia cracca and Lathyrus species) and sorghum. Forms of L. latifolius with non-splitting pods have been obtained, while perennial sorghum hybrids should prove valuable in view of their normal fertility, great drought resistance, hardiness under poor soil conditions and high coefficient of multiplication.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; search.sorghum; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Ge, S.; Oliveira, G. C. X.; Schaal, B. A.; Gao, L. Z.; Hong, D. Y.
Title: RAPD variation within and between natural populations of the wild rice Oryza rufipogon from China and Brazil
Abstract Note: Genetic variation within and between eight natural populations of Oryza rufipogon from China and Brazil was investigated at the DNA level by analysis of RAPD fragments. Out of 60 random primers, which were initially screened against DNA from four individuals, 20 generated highly reproducible RAPD fragments which were then used for further population analysis. With these primers, 95 discernible DNA fragments were produced and 78 (82.1%) were polymorphic, which indicated that high levels of genetic variation existed in these natural populations. In addition, the Chinese populations showed greater polymorphism than those from Brazil at both the population and regional levels. This is noteworthy considering that the Chinese populations are from a relatively restricted area of China. The factors responsible for these findings include the contrasting mating systems in the Brazilian and Chinese populations, and gene flow from annual cultivated rice to perennial natural populations in China. An Analysis of Molecular Variance (AMOVA) was used to apportion the variation between individuals within populations, between populations within regions, and between regions. Results showed that 61.8% of the total genetic diversity resided between the two continents, whereas only 14.9% and 23.3% was attributable to population differences within regions and to individual differences within a population, respectively. The great genetic differentiation between the Chinese and Brazilian populations is in agreement with recent treatment of the American form of O. rufipogon as a separate species, O. glumaepatula.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; ALL(perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE(ar); analysis of molecular variance; Brazil; China; DNA fragment; gene flow; genetic difference; genetic diversity; genetic variance; Genetic variation; Mating system; Oryza glumaepatula; Oryza rufipogon; perennial N1 (oryza OR rice); primer DNA; Random amplified polymorphic DNA; RAPDs; relevant; Rice; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science; wild relative

Author: IVANOV, A. P.
Title: Rare and wild species of cereal crops Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1960, No. 94761. (Translation)
Abstract Note: Rare and wild species of cereal genera are listed: (Triticum timopheevi Zhuk., T. macha Dek. et Men., T. aegilopoides Bal. and T. araraticum Jakubz.), barley (Hordeum spontaneum C. Koch. and H. bulbosum L.), annual rye (Secale chaldicum An. Fhed., S. vavilovi Grossh.) and perennial rye (S. kuprijanovi Grossh. and S. montanum) collected by an expedition of the Institute in the mountainous regions of Armenia, Georgia and Azerbaidzhan.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: Jones, D. B.
Title: Ratoon crop management.
Abstract Note: A series of experiments to assess the efficiency of various rice ratoon cropping techniques are reported briefly. Main crop sowing rates of 50, 100 or 150 kg/ha and row spacing of 15, 20 or 25 cm had no effect on ratoon crop yield. Cutting height (10, 20, 30, 40 and 50 cm) had a significant effect on ratoon crop maturity, height and yield. However, cv. selection had a greater effect on yields. Draining the main crop appeared to be the stimulus for ratoon crop regrowth rather than cutting or reflooding. Greatest response to N (60 kg/ha) occurred when applied 4 weeks after main crop draining, at the panicle initiation stage of the ratoon crop. The occurrence of rice stink bugs ( Oebalus pugnax) in the crop was monitored; numbers increased steadily during the grain filling period of the ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Tanesaka, E.
Title: Ratoon crop maturation in an abandoned rice field, Orysa sativa ssp. japonica, that passed the winter in central Japan.
Publication Title: Memoirs of the Faculty of Agriculture of Kinki University
Abstract Note: Ratoon crop maturation and weed flora were observed in an abandoned paddy field of rice, Oryza sativa subsp. japonica, in Nara Prefecture, central Japan. The presence of weed flora, which included perennial species such as Andropogon virginicus and Solidago altissima, supported the fact that two years had passed since any agricultural management had occurred, as confirmed by an interview with a few farmers. This observation showed that Japanese rice is perennial in fields even after the passage of winter.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Sutaryo, B.; Suprihatno, B.
Title: Ratoon crop performance in some rice hybrids
Abstract Note: Ratoon hills/sq m ranged from 20 for V20 A/Krueng-Aceh to 25 for V20 A/IR25912. Yields ranged from 0.76 t/ha for V20 A/Krueng-Aceh to 1.27 t/ha for V20 A/IR28178, about 14-22% of the main crop yield. Number of filled spikelets/panicle for the ratoon crop varied from 69.3 for V20 A/Krueng-Aceh to 97.6 for V20 A/IR25912, about 62-92% that of the main crop. The ratoon of hybrid V20 A/IR 46 showed the maximum number of panicles/hill at 11.95. The 1000-grain weight of the ratoon crop was about 76-78% of that of the main crop. Plant height ranged from 64.7 cm for V20 A/IR28178 to 73.5 cm for V20 A/Krueng-Aceh. Helminthosporium sigmoideum incidence on the hybrids was 6-50%, while that of Dodokan was only 1%. V20 A/IR25912, V20 A/IR64, and V20 A/IR28178 yielded significantly more than the check. F1 hybrids offer some advantages for use in the ratoon crop. In breeding programs for hybrid rice, emphasis should be given to selecting parents with good ratooning ability.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Wali, M. C.; Mahadevappa, M.; Krishna Murthy, R. A.
Title: Ratoon crop performance of experimental rice hybrids in Karnataka.
Abstract Note: Eight hybrids plus 3 controls were evaluated for ratooning performance during kharif 1992. Highest ratooning ability and increased yields were noted in the hybrid IR-54752A/ARC-11353, followed by hybrids having the same maternal parent IR-54752A. Highest yields were recorded in IR-54752A/IR-54 (67.57 q/ha) followed by IR-54752A/IR-27315 (60.67 q/ha) [1 quintal = 100 kg].
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Reddy, T. G.; Mahadevappa, M.; Coffman, W. R.
Title: Ratoon crop performance of some promising rice genotypes.
Abstract Note: Data are tabulated on height, days to maturity, and grain yield per plant and production per day in 45 genotypes and in 25 selected genotypes in the main and ratoon crops in the wet and dry seasons of 1980-81. Inton and Mingolo performed better than the others when ratooned; they flowered late in both crops and thus escaped damage from low temperatures in the ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Basavaraju, B.; Jayakumar, B. V.; Mahadevappa, M.
Title: Ratoon crop performance of three rices.
Abstract Note: Rice cv. Mangala, CT1351 and Halubbalu (S317) were planted on 15 Aug.,
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Palchamy, A.; Purushothaman, S.; Rajagopal, A.
Title: Ratoon cropping in rice for better water resource management in river command area in Tamil Nadu.
Abstract Note: In a field experiment in 1984-85 at Madurai, Tamil Nadu, rice cv. Bhavani, Ponni and IR 20 were kept flooded to a depth of 5 cm or were flooded to 5 cm depth after the disappearance of ponded water (DPW) and were given 50-125 kg N/ha. The crops were ratooned after the plant crop. Ratoon cropping decreased grain yield by between 45.3 (with Bhavani) and 91.5% (IR 20) compared with the plant crops in 1984/85. Yields were decreased by similar levels the following year. Grain yield was higher where the crop was flooded to 5 cm after the DPW compared with keeping the crop flooded to a depth of 5 cm. The application of 125 kg N gave the highest grain yield.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Escalada, R. G.; Plucknett, D. L.
Title: Ratoon cropping in sorghum. 1. Origin, time of appearance and fate of tillers.
Abstract Note: Sorghum cv. Mini-milo Br 54, NK 222A and NK 300 were grown at 5, 10 or
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: Reddy, T. G.; Mahadevappa, M.; Kulkarni, K. R.
Title: Ratoon cropping of rainfed rice.
Abstract Note: In 1976, rice cv. Intan was ratooned and yielded 2.2 and 1.7 t/ha for the 1st and 2nd crop after 166 and 109 days, resp., with no additional fertilizer. In 1977-8, rice cv. Intan was ratooned in the Chikmagalur district and yielded 2.0-5.5 t/ha in the 1st crop and 2.3-7.7 t/ha in the 2nd crop. The 2nd crop matured in 133 days and grain yield increased with increasing N application from 0 to 50 kg N/ha.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Mahadevappa, M.
Title: Ratoon cropping of rice in Karnataka.
Abstract Note: Results of a trial on lowland of the rain-fed tract of Karnataka showed that paddy yields of the ratoon crop of rice cv. Itan were 76-350%, depending on fertilizer rates, of the maincrop yield. The duration of the maincrop and ratoon crop was 185 and 133 days, resp.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: EVATT, N. S.; BEACHELL, H. M.
Title: Ratoon cropping of short-season rice varieties in Texas.
Abstract Note: In Texas the practice of ratoon cropping, which appears to be a practical means of increasing rice yields, is gradually being extended by using early-maturing varieties (109-132 days from sowing to maturity). Yields of 1500-2000 lb of paddy/ ac have been reported from some ratoon crops. Under favourable growing conditions the new, very early rice varieties (100-105 days) gave yields comparable with those of later varieties. The use of these very early varieties will eliminate much of the risk involved in ratoon cropping by reducing the necessity for early sowing.-E.B.O.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Escalada, R. G.; Plucknett, D. L.
Title: Ratoon cropping of sorghum. 3. Effect of nitrogen and cutting height on ratoon performance.
Abstract Note: [See FCA 29, 219]

Author: Escalada, Rodolfo G.; Plucknett, Donald L.
Title: Ratoon Cropping of Sorghum: II. Effect of Daylength and Temperature on Tillering and Plant Development
Abstract Note: Tillerlng capacity and behavior determine the success or failure of ratoon cropping in grasses. This work was initiated to gain more understanding on the seasonal effects on tillering and ratoon cropping of sorghum [Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench] in the high rainfall tropics by studying the effects of various daylengths and temperature regimes on plant growth and development and yields of ratoon crops. Sorghum plants were grown under two daylengths and four temperature regimes in controlled-environment chambers. Temperatures and daylengths used simulated tropical winter and summer conditions similar to rainfed sugarcane (Saccharum officinarum L.) plantations of Hawaii where ratoon sorghum has been grown. It is contemplated that sorghum could be used as an alternate crop for sugarcane plantations phasing out of production and that ratooning the crop could be utilized as a management practice, thus reducing the high cost of production. An interaction between photoperiod and temperature was observed. With low temperature (23.9 C-day/15.5 C-night) and short day (10 hours), fewer tillers/plant were produced resulting in the development of fewer reproductive tillers. At the same low night and day temperatures, but with photoperiod increased from 10 to 14 hours, more tillers/plant, more reproductive tillers/plant, greater leaf area, more leaves, more numerous but shorter internodes, and longer panicles were produced. The check plants grown outside produced more reproductive tillers/plant than the various treatments. Increasing both the temperature (32.2 C-day/23.9 C-night) and daylength (14 hours) resulted in further increase in tiller number/plant, leaf area, and internode number. Higher temperature and shorter daylength tended to bring about early maturity. Low light intensity, short photoperiod, and low temperature, resulted in rosette form of foliage with very short internodes and reduced number of leaves. This condition led to low grain and stover yields.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: Escalada, Rodolfo G.; Plucknett, Donald L.
Title: Ratoon Cropping of Sorghum: I. Origin, Time of Appearance, and Fate of Tillers
Abstract Note: This study was conducted to understand the basic growth patterns and tillering behavior of sorghum (Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench) from plant crop to succeeding ratoon crops in order to attain maximum production with minimum tillage using a particular practice such as ratooning. Under this system, it is possible to have several harvests from a single planting. Time and location of tiller appearance and survival of tillers are important factors in determining the number and vigor of productive tillers which, in turn, influence the growth, development, yields, and longevity of ratoon crops. Successive tiller production and death of tillers affect the perenniality of the crop. Three cultivars of sorghum ‘Mini-milo Br 54’, NK 222A, and NK 300 were grown under three plant populations [P1 = 5, P2 = 10, and P3 = 20 plants per 3.7 liter (5-gal.) pot] and were observed for tillering behavior in relation to the place of origin, time of appearance, duration of early tillers, and to grain and stover yields. Tillers that sprouted early (first and second tillers) originated from basal nodes of the plant. Later tillers (third, fourth, and so on) developed from the nodes adjacent to elongated internodes. Not all tillers which developed, however, reached maturity. Usually the first two tillers died. Tillers developed earlier in lower populations (P1 and P2) than in the higher population, P3. Cultivar NK 222A produced only two tillers per plant in each population. Compared with tillers of ratoon crops, it took a longer time for the two early tillers of the plant crop to die. Tillers that developed on the upper parts of the stubble were more susceptible to breakage. More tillers were produced during the plant crop, and the number declined in each succeeding ratoon crop. High plant populations resulted in development of few reproductive tiller, less uniformity in plant height, and a delay in tiller formation. In spite of this condition, increased plant population resulted in increased grain and stover yields. More plants per unit area compensated for the production of fewer tillers. Mini-milo Br 54 produced the highest number of tillers per plant, followed by NK 222A, and then NK 300 in the first population. Understanding the basic growth patterns and tillering behavior of a particular sorghum variety, therefore, facilitates management of ratoon crops for maximum production.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: Adigbo, S.O.; Olojede, M.O.; Harris, P.J.C.; Ajayi, O.
Title: Ratooned lowland nerica rice varieties as an option for triple cropping in inland valleys of derived savannah in Nigeria
Abstract Note: Although triple cropping in inland valleys of Nigeria is technically feasible, the third crop between the main crop and dry season non-rice crop has been considered not to be economically viable because of poor crop establishment due to soil inundation. The identification of an appropriate technology with low input, such as ratooning, would allow this niche to be utilized. Field experiments were conducted at the University of Agriculture, Abeokuta, Nigeria in 2007-2008 and 2008-2009 cropping seasons to evaluate the performance of the main and ratooned crops of lowland NERICA (New Rice for Africa) rice (Oryza sativa L.) varieties in a lowland rice-ratooned rice-fluted pumpkin (Telfairia occidentalis Hook F.) sequence. The experiment was laid out in a randomized complete block design with three replicates. The lowland rice varieties used were NERICA-L 19, NERICA-L 20, NERICA-L 22, NERICA-L 24, OFADA, NERICA-L 26, NERICA-L 41, NERICA-L 42, NERICA-L 44 and NERICA-L 47. The grain yield of the main rice crop ranged from 5.0 to 7.3 t ha-1 in 2007-2008 cropping season and from 4.1 to 9.1 t ha-1 in 2008-2009. The ratooned rice had a grain yield of 1.0-4.7 t ha-1 in 2007-2008 and 1.2-3.4 t ha -1 in 2008-2009. The total grain yield obtained in 2007-2008 from the main and ratooned rice crops in seven months was 6.7-11.6 t ha-1, while in 2008-2009 it was 5.3-2.6 t ha-1. The fresh leaf yield of fluted pumpkin ranged from 14.6 to 16.9 t ha-1 in 2007-2008 and from 18.3 to 19.8 t ha-1 in 2008-2009, similar to previously reported rainy season unfertilized yields. Thus, a ratooned rice crop appears to be a feasible technology capable of boosting rice production and consequently increasing the overall productivity of the inland valley in a rice-rice-vegetable cropping sequence.
Manual Tags: ALL(ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Oryza sativa; relevant; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; Telfairia occidentalis; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Gorbet, D. W.
Title: Ratoon evaluations of grain sorghum hybrids.
Abstract Note: In a trial of 7 commercial hybrid varieties and another of 9 F 1 testcross populations, sown in April 1984 and harvested first in August and again, as ratoon crops, in November, resistance to anthracnose ( Colletotrichum graminicola) in first and ratoon crops among the hybrid varieties was highest in NK Savanna 5 and DeKalb DK64, but was in general higher among the testcrosses, being highest of all in A-Tx622 X F-A54IS12609 and A-Tx622 X F-NKS3. NK Savanna 5 gave the highest yields of all, both in the first harvest (7060 kg/ha) and the ratoon crop (5050 kg/ha). Among the testcrosses, A-Tx622 X F-A54IS12609 outyielded all others in both harvests.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: Gorbet, D. W.
Title: Ratoon evaluations of grain sorghum testcrosses in north Florida.

Author: Pandey, N.; Singh, N. B.
Title: Ratoon feasibility of long-duration pigeonpea hybrids.
Abstract Note: Experiments were conducted in 1995-97 to assess the grain yield performance of ratoon crop in long duration pigeon pea [ Cajanus cajan] hybrids. In the first year 74 entries (71 hybrids and 3 controls) were sown followed by 38 entries (35 hybrids and 3 controls) in the second year. Data were recorded on yield in both main and ratoon crops. The highest grain yield (2314 kg/ha) was recorded in the main crop by the hybrid NDPH 94-20 while in the ratoon crop the highest yield (1413 kg/ha) was recorded by hybrid RAUPH 9001. In the second year trial, the highest yields were recorded by RAUPH 9507 main crop (3981 kg/ha) and RAUPH 9501 ratoon crop (1300 kg/ha). Hybrids RAUPH 9001 and RAUPH 9501 have the same genetic background (MS 3783 * Bahar). Studies of the plant population were also conducted. On the basis of these findings it is concluded that it is not feasible to raise a ratoon crop in long duration pigeon pea hybrids in northern India. Due to high rainfall and excess soil moisture, plants attained 4-5 m height and suffered serious diseases.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(("long duration" OR perennial) NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); Web of Science

Author: Chauhan, J. S.; Lopez, F. S. S.; Vergara, B. S.
Title: Ratoon Growth and Development in Rice (Oryza sativa L.) Under Various Temperature Regimes
Publication Title: Journal of Agronomy and Crop Science
Abstract Note: Plants exhibited differential response for ratoon growth and development under different temperature regimes before and after main crop harvest. Low temperature (23°/20 °C) before cutting induced ratooning whereas similar temperature after cutting delayed and reduced ratoon tillering. Ratoon grain yield and its attributes were significantly affected under various temperature regimes. Ratoon grain yield under low temperature regime before cutting did not differ from that of the control. Ratoon growth duration was maximum under low temperature regime after cutting. High temperature (37°/27 °C) after main crop cutting resulted in high spikelet sterility in the ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science
Automatic Tags: Growth and development; Oryza sativa L.; ratooning; rice; temperature regime

Author: Kupkanchanakul, T.; Vergara, B. S.; Kupkanchanakul, K.
Title: Ratooning ability and potential herbage production from ratoon crops of rice cultivars.
Abstract Note: Of the 20 deepwater and 4 lowland cultivars studied only 17 produced ratoons. Deepwater cultivars Huntra 60, Khao Rachinee and Luang Pratharn had high levels of ratooning. Biomass yield was measured 30 and 60 days after ratooning and at maturity. Deepwater cultivars with high ratooning ability had high biomass yields and grain yields. Khao Rachinee and Luang Pratharn gave the highest grain yields (2.7 t/ha) among the deepwater cultivars while Binato (lowland cultivar) yielded 2.9 t/ha. Deepwater cultivars Huntra 60 and Luang Pratharn gave the highest biomass yields (10.3 and 12.9 t/ha, respectively).
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Shivakumaraswamy, P. H.; Mahadevappa, M.
Title: Ratooning ability of 20 F 3 rice crosses.
Abstract Note: Analysis of data from 8 varieties and 20 crosses advanced to the F 3, revealed that ratooning measured 3 weeks after the main harvest varied from 4% in Karikagga to 99% in Mahsuri. The average ratooning ability (RA) of the crosses was 90% vs. 64% for the parents. This is taken to indicate dominant and heterotic expression by genes governing RA. Mutants of parental varieties with good RA generally maintained the trait, but Intan mutants 1, 2 and 3 did not; this is taken to indicate that recessive genes govern RA in this material.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Qiu, B. Q.; Jin, Q. S.
Title: Ratooning ability of IR varieties in Hangzhou, China.
Abstract Note: A total of 28 varieties in the IR series (IR5-IR64) were evaluated for ratooning ability (RA) in a screenhouse by cutting mature plants to a height of 15 cm and measuring ratooning 15 days later on a 1-9 scale. IR29, IR30, IR43 and IR64 had relatively high RA (1 on scale) and their ratoon crops yielded c. 50% of main crops. In 13 varieties, RA was intermediate and ratoon crops yielded 20-30% of main crops. Data are tabulated for all 28 varieties.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Srinivasan, K.; Purushothaman, S.
Title: Ratooning ability of medium duration rice varieties.
Abstract Note: In field trials at Madurai, in 1986-87, the ratoon crop of cv. Bhavani performed better than Ponni with regard to growth, yield attributes and grain yield. The Bhavani ratoon crop produced 2752 kg/ha grain which was 50.2% of the maincrop yield whereas the ratoon crop of Ponni (1754 kg/ha) was 38% of the maincrop yield. Different spacings (15, 20 or 25 *
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Roy, B. C.; Hossain, M. A.; Rahman, M. A.
Title: Ratooning ability of photoperiod-sensitive rice varieties transplanted in the boro season.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted at the Bangladesh Rice Research Institute, Charbadna farm, Barisal, from boro 2001 to aman 2002. Seven photoperiod-sensitive rice cultivars (BR22, BR23, BRRI dhan34, BRRI dhan37, BRRI dhan38, BRRI dhan40 and BRRI dhan41), including three fine grain aromatic cultivars (BRRI dhan 34, BRRI dhan37 and BRRI dhan38), were transplanted on 15 and 30 December 2001. After harvest of the boro crop, the ratoons were allowed to grow and in the succeeding aman, a good harvest was obtained from those ratoons. In the boro season, the highest yield was obtained from BRRI dhan41 (7.51 t/ha) followed by BR23 (7.06 t/ha). The yield of aromatic cultivars was ~5 t/ha. The ratoon yields of both aromatic and non-aromatic cultivars in the succeeding aman season were also encouraging and produced ~2 t/ha, which was more than the average yield of local cultivars normally cultivated in the transplanted aman season in that region. The highest yield was obtained by BR23 (2.87 t/ha) followed by BRRI dhan37 (2.63 t/ha). From this experiment, it was revealed that the photoperiod-sensitive rice cultivars could be planted in the early boro season and the ratoons from this crop also produced a good harvest. This might be a low-cost rice cultivation technique in those areas, where crop establishment in the transplanted aman season is somewhat difficult due to the early intrusion of tidal water in the field at the end of boro season.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Roy, S. K. B.; Mondal, J.
Title: Ratooning ability of some photoperiod - sensitive rices.
Abstract Note: Ten photoperiod sensitive deepwater and wetland rice cv. grown during 1982 were harvested in May by cutting to 8 or 12 cm. Ratooning ability, scored 15 days after cutting, was not affected by cutting ht. Photoperiod sensitive cv. scored higher than cv. IR36; cv. SR26B showed highest ratooning ability with 97% of hills producing new tillers, followed by NC1263 (94%), Achra 10811 and NC365 (93%) and Tillakachari and Bhasamanik (91%).
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Singh, B. K.; Thakur, R. B.; Singh, R. P.
Title: Ratooning ability of some summer rices on saline-calcareous soil.
Abstract Note: Ratooning ability of 7 rice cv. was determined in field trials carried out on calcareous silt loam in 1979. The C8585 and NC1626 ratoons yielded 32 and 24%, resp., of the main crop yields of 3.5 and 4.1 t/ha. Cv. NC1626 yielded higher overall when the yields of the main and ratoon crops were combined. The ratoon crop was 25% shorter than the main crop. The number of panicle-bearing shoots/hill of the ratoon was positively correlated with the number for the main crop. The ratoon crop had lower grain wt. than the main crop and matured 70 days earlier.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Patil, R. C.; Mali, V. S.; Kadam, D. E.
Title: Ratooning ability of ten sorghum hybrids.
Abstract Note: The hybrids were grown in kharif 1983 and subsequently also harvested as winter (ratoon) crop. The performance of SPH221, SPH225, SPH232, MSH50 and CSH5 showed promise in respect of yields of grain and of fodder in each of the two crops.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: SARAN, A. B.; PRASAD, M.
Title: Ratooning in paddy.
Abstract Note: A trial was laid down at the Rice Experimental Area, Sabour, India, using Aus CH 10 rice, to determine the effect of harvesting at 4 different cutting heights on the yield of the subsequent ratoon crop. The treatments were randomized and replicated 6 times. The best ratoon-crop yield, equal to 31% of the yield of the preceding main crop, was obtained when the main crop was harvested at a cutting height of 14 in.-W.J.B.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Chatterjee, B. N.; Bhattacharyya, S.; Debnath, P.
Title: Ratooning of rice.
Abstract Note: Tabulated data are presented on grain yield, number of panicles per hill, number of filled grains per panicle and 1000-grain weight for five varieties in wet and dry season ratoons, after transplanting.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: GARCIA DURAN, E.
Title: Ratooning of rice.
Abstract Note: In some regions of Colombia ratooning of rice is practised, and 2-3 consecutive crops are obtained. Experiments showed that yields of the first and the second ratoon were 54 and 59% less, respectively, than that of the sown crop. There was more weed growth in ratooned fields and a higher loss of the elements N, P and K. Although production costs per ha of ratooned rice were lower, the cost per kg of rice was higher than that of a sown crop. From Trop. Abstr. 18: k48.-R.B.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Thanunathan, K.; Kalyanasundaram, D.; Imayavaramban, V.; Singaravel, R.; Kandasamy, S.
Title: Ratooning of rice: An economically viable agrotechnology for flood prone areas.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted to find out the effect of ratooning of rice and feasibility of growing rice-fallow pulses in the flood prone tail-end areas of Cauvery deltaic zone. Rice cultivars having different duration viz., long duration (Ponmani, White ponni and CO 43), medium duration (ADT 38) and short duration (PY5) were tried in different rice growing seasons viz., 'Samba', late 'Samba', 'Kuruvai', 'Thaladi' and late 'Kuruvai' seasons. Ratooning was practised in short and medium duration varieties with a view to accommodate a pulse crop in rice-fallows. Results of the study showed that short duration rice variety was amenable for ratooning and rice-fallow blackgram could be successfully grown in the correct season (January-March). The cumulative crop yields (main rice crop, ratoon rice and blackgram), cropping intensity, net income and cost: benefit ratio were maximum when short duration rice cv. PY 5 was cultivated in 'Kuruvai' followed by ratooning of the same rice cultivar and growing of blackgram in rice fallows.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: G, RAMSHE D.; R, BAPAT D.; S, POL P.; S, MANE S.
Title: RATOONING PERFORMANCE OF HYBRID SORGHUM CSH-5
Abstract Note: The ratooning potential of hybrid sorghum (CSH-5) was studied by harvesting the main crop at different times and irrigating the ratoon at different critical stages, keeping different numbers of tillers for ratoon. Harvesting the main crop at physiological maturity (15 days before the normal date), irrigation at all critical stages of plant growth, and free tillering of ratoon yielded maximum grain and fodder yield.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: Sanni, K.A.; Ojo, D.K.; Adebisi, M.A.; Somado, E.A.; Ariyo, O.J.; Sie, M.; Akintayo, I.; Tia, D.D.; Ogunbayo, S.A.; Cissé, B.; Sikirou, M.; Adekoya, M.A.
Title: Ratooning potential of interspecific NERICA rice varieties (Oryza glaberrima×Oryza sativa)
Abstract Note: Field experiment was conducted in Deve (6°48 N, 1°47'E, 72 masl) in the Savannah zone of Benin Republic, to examine the increase in grain yield due to ratooning. Eighteen upland interspecific varieties (NERICA1-18) and their Oryza glaberrima (CG 14) and one of the O. sativa (WAB 56-104) parents were used in a Randomized complete block design with three replications. The first (main) crop was harvested at mass maturity, after which the tillers were hand mowed to stubbles of about 10 cm tall. These were then left without any further input, until the ratooned plants were ready for harvest. The result showed a large variation in the ratoon performance among NERICA, with ratoon ability ranging from 13% (NERICA 2) to 39% (NERICA 14 and 17). Total grain yield (main plus ratoon) was significantly different (p<0.001) from that of the main harvest. The maximum total grain yield was 6.141 ha-1 for NERICA 2 followed by NERICA 15 and 11 (6.02 and 6.01 t ha-1, respectively). The yield increase of more than 1.5 t ha-1 (the average yield of upland rice in Sub-saharan Africa) recorded in NERICA, with no additional input was very encouraging. This will presumably increase with additional input during ratoon. Therefore, NERICA rice is able to fructify twice, hence farmers can harvest more rice and make more profit.
Manual Tags: ALL(ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Grain yield; NERICA; Oryza; Oryza glaberrima; Oryza sativa; Ratoon; relevant; Rice; Scopus; search.rice; Second harvest; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: GuiLian, Zhang; NaiMei, Tu; ShunTang, Zhang
Title: Ratooning properties of axillary buds in hybrid rice.
Abstract Note: The ratooning characteristics of the 2-line hybrid rice combination, Peiliangyou 500 and a 3-line hybrid rice Shanyou 63 were studied. Compared to Shanyou 63, Peiliangyou 500 had higher ratooning ability of axillary buds and living bud rate, showing significant heterosis in terms of dry matter accumulation and non-structural carbohydrate content at the late stage of the main crop. A significant relationship between living bud rate and dry matter weight of the different stem nodes, soluble carbohydrate content and starch content. Superoxide dismutase and peroxidase activities increased 20 days after full heading of the main crop and reached its highest at the maturity stage.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: ZhenXie, Yi; NaiMei, Tu; Pu, Wang; PingPing, Chen
Title: Ratooning properties of axillary buds of two-line hybrid rice in vivo and in vitro.
Abstract Note: Two-line hybrid rice combinations Pei' ai 64S/E32 and Peiliangyou 500 were used to investigate the ratooning properties of axillary buds from different nodes in vivo and in vitro. High-stubble and node-cutting experiments were conducted. The length of the middle nodes' axillary buds was longer than that of other nodes during fully heading stage (FHS) in the main crop. The growth rate of all axillary buds was slow from FHS to 20 days after FHS, and accelerated from 20 days after FHS to maturing stage. However, the growth rate of higher nodes' axillary buds was faster than that of lower nodes. Plant height of ratooning rice of the 2nd and 3rd node from the top of Pei'ai 64S/E32 and of the 2nd, 3rd and 4th node from the top of Peiliangyou 500 in vitro were shorter than in vivo. The higher the nodal position the bigger the difference in height. Compared to those in vivo, the panicle length and spikelets per panicle of all ratooning rice nodes in vitro were higher. The lower the node position the bigger the difference, which suggests that the dependence of middle and higher node axillary buds to stubble nutrition was higher than that of lower nodes, and the limitation of nutrient application to lower node axillary buds was higher than that to higher ones in vivo. The difference between ratooning rate of axillary buds from different nodes was bigger in vivo than that in vitro. The correlation between total N content of internodes and ratooning rate of corresponding axillary buds was positive at 0.05 level from FHS to 10 days after FHS, but it was negative or very weak from 20 days after FHS to maturing stage. The higher soluble sugar and starch content in full heading stage did not increase ratooning rate. From 10 days after FHS to maturing stage, negative correlation existed between starch content and ratooning rate, and positive correlation existed between soluble sugar content, soluble sugar and starch in gross and ratooning rate. The results suggests that total N content of internodes is the main deciding factor in determining the ratooning rate of corresponding-node axillary buds in early productive stage.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Lomte, M. H.; Dabhade, R. S.
Title: Ratoon management in grain sorghum (Sorghum bicolor).
Abstract Note: In field trials in the winter season of 1982-85 at Parbhani, ratoon crops of sorghum hybrids CSH 1, CSH 5 and CSH 6 were given 40, 80 or 120 kg N/ha and 3 tiller-management treatments (1, 2 or all tillers/plant retained). CHS 5 gave significantly higher grain and fodder yields than CSH 1 and CSH 6, which were similar. Retention of all tillers with application of 80 kg N/ha was the best and most economical practice for increasing the ratoon yield under irrigated conditions. The max. grain yield of 4.09 t/ha was obtained with 180 kg N/ha. The highest net profit was obtained when prices were Rs 4/kg applied N and Rs 2/kg sorghum grain.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: Molina, A. B.; Cabangbang, R. P.; Quintana, R. V.
Title: Ratoon performance of selected grain sorghum varieties at three levels of plant population and nitrogen fertilization.
Abstract Note: Data are given on number of productive ratoons/ha, grain yield, stover yield, av. panicle length, number of grains/panicle, 100-grain wt., leaf angle, days to flowering and plant ht. for 7 grain sorghum cv. grown with 0, 100 or 200 kg N/ha, 50% applied at sowing and the other 50% side-dressed after 3 wk, and at plant populations of 120 000, 200 000 or 280 000/ha. With increase in plant population, there were decreases in panicle length and number of grains/panicle, and an increase in the number of productive ratoons. It was concluded that 100 kg N/ha was opt. for number of productive ratoons, grains/panicle and panicle length; number of days to flowering was reduced by 10 days with 100 kg N/ha compared with plots without N fertilizer.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: Karunakaran, K.; Jalajakumari, M. B.; Sreedevi, P.
Title: Ratoon performance of some short-duration rice cultures.
Abstract Note: 20 rice cv. were grown at Pattambi during the 1981 kharif season. Seedlings were transplanted at 15 cm * 10 cm spacing and received 70-35-35 kg NPK/ha. The main crop was harvested to leave 15 cm tall stubble and entries were then assessed for ratoon performance. Main crop grain yields varied from 3.2 to 4.9 t/ha while ratoon crop yields varied from 0.1 to 0.5 t/ha.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Faria, E. A.; Soares, P. C.
Title: Ratoon production of irrigated rice in Minas Gerais. Present situation and prospects.
Abstract Note: Data are given of ratoon production of irrigated rice in Minas Gerais in 1981-3, av. yield being about 30% of that of the first crop. In other countries a corresponding figure of 50% is obtained. Factors to be taken into consideration for ratoon management include sowing date, cv., cutting height, fertilizers, water management and weed control. Trials to study rice ratoon cropping are being established in various regions of Minas Gerais.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Rao, P. K. A.; Shivashankar, G.
Title: Ratoon regeneration in rices and their single-cross hybrids after three cuttings.
Abstract Note: After the third ratooning, stubble of 15 varieties and 16 hybrids among them was either left in situ or transplanted in single rows. Height and tiller number/plant were recorded 35 days later. Both characters varied among genotypes. In general, hybrids had greater ratoon regeneration capacity than varieties, TN1 X Type 3 being the best hybrid. Many varieties produced no tillers in situ. Propagation of single-cross hybrids in this way is considered useful because it allows continuous production of F 2 seed and maximizes the population size of the second segregating generation.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Maharudrappa, S. K.
Title: Ratoon rice as influenced by stubble height and nitrogen levels.
Abstract Note: In a field experiment in 1985-86 at Mudigere, Karnataka, plant rice cv. Intar crop was cut to stubble heights of 2.5, 5-7.5 or 7.5-12.5 cm and grown as a ratoon crop and given 0-57 kg N/ha. Grain yield was not affected by stubble height and was highest with 57 kg N (2.32 t/ha).
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Nayak, R. L.; Das, M.; Mandal, S. S.
Title: Ratoon rice can yield well.
Abstract Note: Tabulated data are given for grain yield and number of days to maturity for nine cultivars grown as a main crop in the wet and dry seasons and as a ratoon crop after the dry season crop. IET3629 yielded highest (2.7 t/ha) in the shortest time (95 days). Its ratoon yield was 12% higher than its main crop yield in wet season. Other cultivars with good ratooning ability were IET4555 (2.1 t/ha) and IET3273 (1.8 t/ha).
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Shamiul Islam, M.; Hasanuzzaman, M.; Rokonuzzaman, Md.
Title: Ratoon rice response to different fertilizer doses in irrigated condition
Abstract Note: The response of different fertilizer doses was studied on the ratoon crop as well as main crop. The different fertilizer doses under the study were F 1 (N=90, P 2O 5 = 45, K 2O=50, S=13, Zn = 4: in kg ha -1), F 2 (N=105, P 2O 5 = 55, K 2O=60, S=13, Zn = 4: in kg ha -1), F 3 (N=120, P 2O 5 = 65, K 2O=70, S=13, Zn = 4: in kg ha -1), F 4(N =135, P 2O 5 =75, K 2O=80, S=13, Zn=4: in kg ha -1) and F 5 (N=150, P 2O 5 = 85, K 2O = 90, S=13, Zn = 4: in kg ha -1). In the main crop, the highest grain and biological yields were produced by F 3 dose. The highest straw yield was produced by F 4 dose. The lowest grain yield and the lowest biological yield were produced by F 1 dose and the lowest straw yield was produced by F 2 dose. The highest crop duration was found using F 1 dose and the shortest crop duration was found using F 3 doses. In the ratoon crop, the highest grain yield, straw yield and biological yield was produced by F 5 dose whereas the lowest grain yield, straw yield and biological yield was achieved with F 1 dose. The longest crop duration was observed using F 2 dose and the shortest crop duration was recorded using F 5 dose.
Manual Tags: ALL(ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Crop duration; Crop yield; dose-response relationship; fertilizer application; Fertilizer dose; Irrigation; Ratoon; relevant; Rice; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science; yield; Yield response

Author: Bond, J.a.; Bollich, P.k.
Title: Ratoon Rice Response to Nitrogen Fertilizer [electronic resource]
Abstract Note: Field research was conducted for 2 years to determine the N fertilizer application rate producing maximum ratoon rice grain yields. The long-grain rice cultivars Cheniere, CL161, Cocodrie, and Cypress were grown using a delayed-flood, drill-seeded production system. Immediately following harvest of the main crop, N fertilizer at rates of 30, 60, 90, or 120 lb/acre was applied as urea. No ratoon rice lodging was observed in any site-year at any N fertilizer application rate. Ratoon days to 50% heading was delayed 1 day when the N fertilizer application rate was increased from 60 to 90 or 120 lb/acre. Ratoon rough rice yield increased significantly from 2390 to 2710 lb/acre as the N fertilizer application rate increased from 30 to 90 lb/acre, but increasing the N fertilizer application rate from 90 to 120 lb/acre did not improve ratoon rough rice yields. No ratoon rice lodging was observed in any site-year at any N fertilizer application rate. In this study, the N fertilizer application rate producing maximum ratoon rice yields in the Gulf Coast area of the United States was 90 lb/acre.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; full text added; ratoon* N5 (oryza OR rice); relevant; search.rice; SPV
Automatic Tags: crop production; fertilizer application; fertilizer rates; grain yield; lodging; Louisiana; nitrogen fertilizers; Oryza sativa; ratooning; rice; urea

Author: Chakraborty, P. K.; Roy, S. K. B.
Title: Ratoon tillering in short-duration rice varieties.
Abstract Note: After the main harvest (crop sown in November, 1985, transplanted January, 1986) of a set of varieties in the 1985 International Yield Nursery-Early, irrigation water and 20 : 10 : 10 Kg/ha NPK were applied. Ten varieties (listed) showed high ratooning ability. Varieties with a high percentage of regeneration (91-100%) had the highest number of ratoon tillers/hill (5-13).
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Cox, C.M.; Garrett, K.A.; Cox, T.S.; Bockus, W.W.; Peters, T.
Title: Reactions of perennial grain accessions to four major cereal pathogens of the Great Plains
Abstract Note: Methods of disease management used in annual grain crops, especially cultural practices designed to disrupt the disease cycle of a particular pathogen, will not necessarily be applicable to perennial grain crops. Resistance to multiple pathogens, therefore, will clearly be important in disease management. The objective of this research was to evaluate disease resistance in 10 perennial grain accessions (one to two accessions of each: perennial wheat (Thinopyrum sp. x Triticum aestivum), intermediate wheatgrass (Thinopyrum intermedium), perennial rye (Secale montanum), hexaploid triticale (Triticum turgidum x S. montanum), octoploid triticale (Triticum aestivum x S. montanum), tetraploid perennial rye (Secale cereale x S. montanum), and tall wheatgrass (Thinopyrum ponticum)) to tan spot (caused by Pyrenophora tritici-repentis), take-all (caused by Gaeumannomyces graminis var. tritici), wheat streak mosaic, and barley yellow dwarf, four important diseases of the Great Plains. Several of the grasses were resistant to tan spot, barley yellow dwarf, and wheat streak mosaic. Indeed, the wild grasses and perennial donors T. intermedium (including BFPMC1), T. ponticum, and S. montanum, in addition to Permontra, a tetraploid perennial rye, were highly resistant to all three diseases. Additionally, the remaining grasses tested were also more resistant to tan spot than the susceptible wheat control. However, none of the 10 grass accessions appeared highly resistant to take-all, and substantial losses in biomass were observed, although such effects may be moderated under field conditions due to the potential for take-all decline in perennial plantings.

Author: Arumugachamy, S.; Vivekanandan, P.; Subramanian, M.
Title: Reciprocal differences in a 6 * 6 diallel for ratoon traits in rice.
Abstract Note: Thirty F 1 hybrids and their parents from a 6 * 6 diallel cross were grown to maturity, harvested 20 cm above ground level and then assessed for tiller regeneration and ratoon yield. Marked reciprocal effects were observed, with 6 and 5 crosses showing significant positive and negative reciprocal effects, respectively, for number of regenerated tillers. In general, tiller regeneration was best when IET6709 and IET7552 were used as maternal parents. The latter also had positive reciprocal effects on ratoon yield.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Yan, He; Bin, Wang; Li-geng, Jiang; Cui-li, Meng; Zhao-rong, Ou; Shi-hong, Xu
Title: Refined Climatic Division of Rice Planting Distribution Using GIS in Guangxi, China
Abstract Note: According to the climatic requirements of rice growth and development, four key climatic factors, including length of safe period for rice cropping, active accumulated temperature during the safe period, sunshine hours during the period when daily mean temperature above 10 degrees C and annual mean temperature, were selected as the indices to classify agro-climatic zones for rice cropping in Guangxi. Climatic data during 1961 to 2010 and related geographical information data of 90 weather stations in Guangxi were used to establish spatial calculating models for the classification indices. The spatial calculating models for the safe period for rice cropping (Y=1193.028-9.831 phi -0.086 h -6.680 lambda the active accumulated temperature during the safe period (Y=30166.74-262.656 phi -2.848 h - 165.549 lambda). the sunshine hours during the period when daily mean temperature above 10 degrees C (Y=6665.195-110.344 phi - 0.416 h -23.416 lambda), and the annual mean temperature (Y=73.237 -0.735 phi - 0.005 h - 0.314 lambda) were obtained by using geographic infermation system (GIS) technology and stepwise regression method, and fine-grid calculation and residual error correction were carried out for each classification index. Based on the identified classification rules, four agro-climatic zones, namely late-maturing double-rice cropping zone. middle and late-maturing double-rice cropping zone, early and middle-maturing double-rice cropping zone, and single rice-ratoon rice cropping zone, were classified for rice cropping in Guangxi, and the map of agro-climatic zones for rice cropping in Guangxi was built.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Coale, F.j.; Jones, D.b.
Title: Reflood timing for ratoon rice grown on Everglades Histosols
Abstract Note: Rice (Oryza sativa L.) ratooning is commonly practiced in the Everglades Agricultural Area of southern Florida, yet optimum length of the drained period between main and ratoon crops has not been determined. Research was conducted to determine the effect of length of drain period at main-crop harvest on ratoon rice productivity on an Everglades Histosol. Our research was conducted in 250-L (0.95 m height, 0.58 m i.d.) custom-made water control lysimeters filled with a Pahokee muck soil (euic, hyperthermic Lithic Medisaprist). Ratoon reflood timing treatments were 0, 5, 15, 25, 35, and 45 d drained beginning at main-crop maturity. Ratoon-crop grain yield exhibited a significant quadratic response to length of drain period with maximum grain yield produced at 28 d drained. Ratoon panicle number was not affected by reflood timing, but quadratic responses to length of drain period were observed for grain number and 1000 grain weight. We propose that the resultant effect of reflood timing on ratoon grain yield was the combined responses to increasing mineral N supply and increasing water stress associated with delayed reflooding. For drained durations < 28 d, the beneficial effects of increased mineral N supply resulting from organic matter oxidation resulted in a net increase in ratoon-crop yield. Conversely, for drained periods > 28 d, the detrimental impact of prolonged water stress dominated the response to reflood timing and ratoon rice yields declined.

Author: Christiansen, J.L.; Jørgensen, J.R.; Jørnsgård, B.; Stölen, O.
Title: Regrowth in barley (Hordeum vulgare L.) and rye (Secale cereale L.)
Publication Title: Acta Agriculturae Scandinavica - Section B Soil and Plant Science
Abstract Note: Regrowth after cutting at four development stages, from heading to grain maturity, was investigated in a pot experiment containing three rye and four barley varieties. Regrowth in the barley varieties decreased strongly from heading to grain maturity. Rye generally showed stronger regrowth than barley after late cutting, but only the perennial variety 'Soperta' regenerated as many tillers at cutting as formed when harvested at the ripe grain stage. In both species, significant differences were found between varieties. The level of soluble carbohydrates reached a maximum between heading and maturity, but differences in regrowth could not be explained by such differences. Total N decreased from heading to maturity, except for perennial rye, where an increase was observed towards ripening. It is, however, uncertain whether this was an effect rather than a cause of the regrowth.
Journal Abbreviation: Acta Agric. Scand. Sect. B Soil Plant Sci.
