Author: ZhenXie, Yi; NaiMei, Tu; PingPing, Chen
Title: Source-sink characteristics of main crop and ratoon crop of several new hybrid rice combinations.
Abstract Note: Eight hybrid rice combinations (64S/E32 Pei ai 64S/E32, 500 Peiliangyou 500, 64S/B52 Pei ai 64S/B52, Liangyoupeijiu, 2054 Kangliangyou 2054, 18S/53159 Lu 18S/53159, T98A/259 and 316A/180) were used to study the source-sink characteristics and yields of main and ratoon crops. The leaf area (LA) index (LAI) and the LA per culm of the ratoon crop were approximately 1/3 and 1/7-1/3 of those of the main crop, respectively. The total sink volume of the ratoon crop was higher by 1.5- to 2.0-fold than that of the main crop. The ratio of the number of grains to the LA (RGL) in the ratoon crop was higher than that of the main crop by 1.5- to 2.0-fold. The high RGL was beneficial for obtaining high yields in the main crop. The high LAI and weight of stem sheath at maturity, low RGL, and high dry matter distribution to the stem sheath of the main crop were beneficial for obtaining high yields in the ratoon crop. A positive correlation was observed between LAI at the full heading stage and yield of the ratoon crop. In the ratoon crop, a positive correlation was observed between LA per culm at the full heading stage and yield per culm. A negative correlation was evident between RGL and seed set, and between RGL and yield. The source-sink relationship in the ratoon crop, especially the upper-node ratoon rice, was of the source-limited type. The yields of 18S/53159, Kangliangyou 2054, Pei ai 64S/E32 and Peiliangyou 500 ratoon crops were greater than 5200 kg/hm 2. Based on the yield of the ratoon crop and total yields under the climatic conditions of Changsha region, Hunan, China, during 2002, the optimum combination for ratooning was Peiai 64 S/E32, followed by Kangliangyou 2054 and T98A/259.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: VAVILOV, N. I.
Title: Soviet scientific plant industry during the period of Soviet reconstruction 1930-1933.
Publication Title: Bull. Appl. Bot. Leningrad, Ser. A
Abstract Note: The achievements of the last three years are reviewed, reference being made to the enormous scale on which agricultural research is now carried on in the U.S.S.R. As a result of this it is now possible for every locality to cultivate only those varieties that are adapted to it-the State Variety Testing Service is testing over 2, 000 Soviet and foreign varieties of 125 different crops at 400 different stations. Breeding methods are being fundamentally changed so as to form a complex system involving the co-operation of physiologists, phytopathologists, entomologists, chemists and technologists. The more important achievements in the form of improved new varieties are reviewed. Special mention is made of the use of wild fruit trees in hybridization by Michurin, of the hybrids of wheat by rye of Meister and others, the production by interspecific crossing of wheats of the vulgare type having the hard durum grain, of perennial wheats from crosses with Agropyrum, of fertile amphidiploids between a number of species giving sterile hybrids and of sugar beet x mangold hybrids with increased yield. Special reference is also made to the discovery of new species of wheat and potatoes and the valuable practical results that are already beginning to accrue therefrom; also to the valuable results obtained from artificial curtailment of the length of day in many southern forms of both herbaceous plants and trees. Special new methods, suitable for use by breeders, have been elaborated for determining the cold and drought resistance and other physiological properties of the plant, extensive tests have been carried out with success on vernalization, special attention has been devoted to quality in nearly all crops, and the areas of possible cultivation of a great number of crops, notably cotton, have been extended by the production of improved forms. Collections have been made of the cultivated plants of the whole world, the wild fruit trees having proved to be specially interesting and important, the centre of origin of most European fruit trees having been shewn to be in Transcaucasia and Central Asia, including parts of Persia and Turkey. A thorough study of these areas is being executed. Great numbers of new plants have also been brought into cultivation, including the valuable new rubber plant tau-saghiz, which yields a rubber of the first quality. The application of cytogenetics has led to the production of polyploid forms of certain small bush fruits with increased berry size. Similarly Pangalo's studies on the cucurbits have made known the extent and the interrelationships of this large group for the first time, by classifying the whole world collection and separating out the most valuable types, and by crossing with species themselves not distinguished by high sugar content twofold increases in the sugar content have resulted.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.grain; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Sompaew, V.; Datta, S. K. de
Title: Stand establishment techniques and management practices for direct-seeded rice.
Abstract Note: Four field experiments were conducted from March 1978 to February 1979 at the International Rice Research Institute Farm on Maahas clay to determine the effects of planting method, land preparation method, and nitrogen fertilizer management on the stand establishment, plant characters, grain yield, and yield components of direct-seeded rice. For wetland rice, additional studies were conducted to determine the feasibility of ratoon cropping in increasing the productivity of rice. Furthermore, the different seedling ages were used in the experiment with wetland rice to determine the feasibility of reducing field duration. The dibbling method produced higher grain yield than the other methods for dryland seeding, and the drilling method for wetland seeding. The normal tillage operation gave grain yield similar to that obtained with intensive land preparation. During both dry and wet seasons two split applications of nitrogen fertilizer produced the same grain yield as the placement of nitrogen in the reduced soil layer. For the dry season, the optimum seedling age for the early-maturing varieties was 20 to 30 days, and for the medium- and late-maturing varieties was 30 to 40 days. But for the wet season planting, the optimum seedling ages for all varieties were 20 to 30 days. Seedling ages of the main crop had no effect on the grain yield of the rice ratoon crop. Deep placement of nitrogen fertilizer to the main crop gave a higher grain yield in the ratoon crop compared with split application. Higher grain yields were obtained from the rice ratoons from the late-maturing varieties. The grain yield of the rice ratoon crops ranged from 28 to 34% of the main crop. The maturity of the ratoon crops varied from 53 to 68 days after cutting the main crops depending upon the variety.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Tsitsin, N. V.
Title: State and prospects of research in the field of distant hybridization.
Abstract Note: Information is presented on the methodology of intergeneric hybridization and on Soviet successes in breeding intergeneric hybrids, especially of cereals, such as Triticum X Agropyron, Triticum X Secale and Triticum X Elymus, Triticum X Agropyron X Elymus and Triticum X Secale X Agropyron. Particular attention is paid to Triticum X Agropyron hybrids, which the author has designated as a new wheat species, T. agropyrotriticum, with two subspecies, subsp. perenne (perennial wheat) and subsp. submittans (forage wheats).
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Francki, M.G.; Crasta, O.R.; Sharma, H.C.; Ohm, H.W.; Anderson, J.M.
Title: Structural organization of an alien Thinopyrum intermedium group 7 chromosome in U.S. soft red winter wheat (Triticum aestivum L.)
Abstract Note: Barley yellow dwarf virus (BYDV) resistance in soft red winter wheat (SRWW) cultivars has been achieved by substituting a group 7 chromosome from Thinopyrum intermedium for chromosome 7D. To localize BYDV resistance, a detailed molecular genetic analysis was done on the alien group 7 Th. intermedium chromosome to determine its structural organization. Triticeae group 7 RFLP markers and rye specific repetitive sequences used in the analysis showed that the alien chromosome in the P29 substitution line has distinguishing features. The 350-480 bp rye telomeric sequence family was present on the long arm as determined by Southern and fluorescence in situ hybridization. However, further analysis using a rye dispersed repetitive sequence indicated that this alien chromosome does not contain introgressed segments from the rye genome. The alien chromosome is homoeologous to wheat chromosomes 7A and 7D as determined by RFLP analysis. Presence of the waxy gene on chromosomes 7A, 7B, and 7D but its absence on the alien chromosome in P29 suggests some internal structural differences on the short arm between Th. intermedium and wheat group 7 chromosomes. The identification of rye telomeric sequences on the alien Thinopyrum chromosome and the homoeology to wheat chromosomes 7A and 7D provide the necessary information and tools to analyze smaller segments of the Thinopyrum chromosome and to localize BYDV resistance in SRWW cultivars.
Manual Tags: ALL(perennial W/1 (rye OR secale) AND NOT ("rye grass" OR "rye-grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE(ar); Barley yellow dwarf virus; cytogenetics; disease resistance; Homoeologous group 7; In situ hybridization; plant genetics; plant genome; relevant; RFLP; Rye repetitive sequences; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; Thinopyrum intermedium; Triticum aestivum

Author: EVATT, N. S.
Title: Stubble rice production tests.
Abstract Note: The 8- to 9-month growing season of the Texas Gulf Coast Prairie is not quite long enough to permit two successive rice crops to be grown from seed. A preliminary test in 1956 demonstrated that ratooning was possible if an early-maturing variety was used and the crop was combine-harvested to leave at least 17 in. of stubble. This cutting height was necessary even though all tillering came from the base of the plant. In 1957, more than 4000 Ib. grain/ac. were obtained from the first crop and more than 2000 Ib./ac. from the ratoon-crop. Highest yields were obtained by applying N and P to the crop soon after sowing, and again to the ratoon-crop soon after cutting. There was no response to K. The first crop must be harvested before 10 August to obtain a successful ratoon-crop. Varieties which mature even earlier than Century Patna 231 would be an advantage.-J.D.J.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Gurumurthy, S.; Muthukrishnan, P.; Thirumurugan, V.; Kaliappa, R.
Title: Studies of ratoon in IR 20, Bhavani and Co 42 rice varieties.
Abstract Note: The 3 medium duration cultivars were grown at one wetland site in 1981-82, with NPK fertilization. After harvesting the main crop, 4 levels of N fertilization (100-160 kg/ha) were given either in a single dose 7 days after harvest or with half the dose delayed until 20 days after harvest. Bhavani gave the highest grain yield in the ratoon crop, and IR20 the lowest, although IR20 had given the highest yield in the planted crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: ShiHua, Jiang; Hong, Xiong; Wen, Fang; WenZhi, Luo
Title: Studies on comprehensive cultivation techniques for high yield of ratoon rice in Sichuan Province.
Abstract Note: Management of high-yield ratoon rice was studied in field experiments and demonstration plots in 1991-94 in Sichuan. The optimum temperature, relative humidity and stubble moisture content for the germination of regenerated buds were found to be 25.5-27.0°C, 81-85% and about 70%, respectively. Stubble moisture contents of >70% were negatively associated with germination and elongation of the regenerated buds. The adoption of balanced fertilizer application and other management techniques helped the accumulation of nutrients in the plants, delayed their senescence and improved the sprouting of regenerated buds and their establishment, Fertilizer dressing at the germination and sprout elongation stages increased the number of productive panicles and well-filled grains, thus increasing yield. Application of GA at the initial heading stage helped maintain a stabilized panicle number and increased seed-setting rate, seed-set per panicle and 1000-seed weight. Double cutting of the stubble reduced the negative influence of drought on the germination and elongation of regenerated buds.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Y-I, CHU; S-C, HONG; T-W, LAI; Y-S, CHEN
Title: STUDIES ON EGG OVERWINTERING OF THE BROWN PLANTHOPPER NILAPARVATA-LUGENS
Abstract Note: The overwinter of brown planthopper (Nilaparvata lugens) with its egg stage are studied under the outdoor conditions with the materials collecting from the fields. The eggs deposited in the period between the end of Nov. 1983 and the end of Feb. 1984 are incubated under the outdoor conditions. The eggs are capable of hatching during the winter, no diapause are observed. However the incubation period is increased with the progression of winter season, the egg stage prolongs to 60 days in maximum and 50.12 .+-. 4.18 days in average. The low temperature bring mal-influence on the survival and development of eggs. The symptom can be divided into two large groups. One is characterized with eggs which do not show any embryonic development. The other group of eggs show the symptom of deformation during their embryonic development and fail to hatch at the last. The dead eggs in the first group are considered to be caused by mal-influence of low temperature through their mother adult. The latter are presumed to be influenced directly by the cold conditions at the egg stage. In the fallowing paddy field, the egg population on the ratoon paddy increase from December. The population peak is observed in the middle of January. Most of those eggs hatch in the middle of February. Then, the temperature condition is no longer serious to the newly hatched nymphs. Therefore the survival rate of the nymph are surely high. They are recognized to be the first generation of planthopper of the year. The low temperature seems a mechanism regulating the embryonic development of brown planthopper during winter season. As a result, the hatching of overwintering eggs are concentrated in the middle of February. Based on the finding, the monitoring operation on the abundance of the first generation is suggested to focus on the egg density in ratoon paddy in the beginning of February.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Muddemmanavar, S. S.; Gumaste, S. K.; Angadi, S. S.; Kubsad, V. S.
Title: Studies on fodder yielding and ratooning abilities of sorghum varieties as influenced by fertilizer levels.
Abstract Note: In a field trial in the summer (irrigated) and kharif [monsoon] (rainfed) seasons of 1981 on clay soil at Dharwad, Karnataka, the effects of 50 kg N + 30 kg P + 20 kg K/ha or double or triple these amounts on main crop and ratoon crop fodder yields of sorghum cv. Rio, Roma, Dale, RM 57-1, Annigeri-1 and J-set-3 were studied. Cv. RM 57-1 gave the highest main crop dry fodder yield of 15.26 t/ha, whereas the highest ratoon crop and total dry fodder yields were obtained from cv. Dale. The main crop and total dry fodder yields increased with up to 100 kg N + 60 kg P + 40 kg K, whereas the ratoon crop dry fodder yield increased with up to the highest NPK rate.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: YOSHIDA, T.; HOZONO, S.
Title: STUDIES ON LATERAL BUDS GROWTH INTO RATOON TILLERS IN EARLY-SEASON CULTURE OF RICE PLANTS
Abstract Note: The yielding ability and the effect of fertilization on yield were investigated in ratoon crop rice in early-season cultures. The total leaf number of each tiller in the ratoon crop was compared with Katayama's theoretical total number of leaves. The ratoon crop produced about 30% of the grain yield of the parent crop. Fertilization of the ratoon crop increased the panicle number per hill, resulting in an increased yield, Ratoon tillers were separated from the main stem to determine their tillering position on the seem, and to find the effect of fertilization on regrowth of tillers. Yield increase by fertilization was mainly due to the increase in the number of ripened secondary tillers. Tillers had 2 similar to 3 more leaves than the total leaves expected from the theory of synchronous growth of leaves and tillers. The investigation of growth of lateral buds at each growth stage of the parent crop showed that the relation between growth of the main stem and lateral bud growth of ratoon tillers was not synchronized, resulting in the increase of total leaf number over the theoretical one.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: C-H, CHENG
Title: STUDIES ON POPULATION DYNAMICS AND FORECASTING OF POPULATION ABUNDANCE
Abstract Note: The population changes of brown planthopper, Nilaparvata lugens (Homoptera: Delphacidae) in paddy fields were investigated for the first and second rice crops in Chianan area from 1982 to 1988. The results revealed that the immigration of brown planthopper in the initial stage of the first rice crop in most cases could not be traced due to low immigrant. The first generation adults used to appear during the end of April to the beginning of May, and the hopper took about one month to complete one generation up to the time of harvest of the crop in the end of June. The highest population peak in this crop season ranged from 0.60 to 10.2 with an average of 1.33 per hill, which appeared mostly during 1-2 weeks before harvest of the crop. Analysis of the factors affecting to abundance of the hopper in the first rice crop indicated that the density of over-winter population was the most important (r2 = 0.984). Besides, the number of days with the lowest day-temperature below 10.degree.C during December to Match, and the number of rainy day in April were also the factors affecting the population abundance to a certain extend. On the contrary, the population of the hopper in the second rice crop was high. The immigrant invaded into paddy fields soon after rice planting, and the peak of immigration appeared mostly during 2 to 3 weeks after rice planting. Initial population was varied from year with a range from 0.006 to 0.27 female adults per hill. The population increased from 46.6 to 2071 folds through 2 to 3 generation's multiplication to reach its highest population peak in the range of 0.6 to 450.6 per hill. The population abundance of the hopper in this crop season was highly correlated with the density of immigrant and the rainfall in September. High temperature over 34.degree.C in August was also an important factor in reducing the population abundance in this crop season. Several regression equations has been established for predicting the population abundance of the hopper both in the first and second rice crop in this area. The coefficience of determination of the regressions were higher than 0.986, indicating that they were likely to be used practically. The population characteristics of the hopper in each crop season and on ratoon rice in this area are also discussed in the paper.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Mane, S. S.; Ramshe, D. G.
Title: Studies on ratooning ability of sorghum entries.
Abstract Note: Tabulated data are presented on the grain and fodder yields from one to three tillers per shoot of the ratoon crop of three hybrids and four varieties. The highest mean grain yields were given by the hybrids; of these, CSH1, with 44.13 q/ha, produced most, producing 37, 46, 49 and 55% more than the varieties 168, Swarna, 370 and CS3541, respectively. The highest mean fodder yield was given by Swarna, followed by CSH5.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: Hou, F. F.
Title: Studies on ratooning and its correlation with TNC content in rice.
Publication Title: Bulletin of Taichung District Agricultural Improvement Station
Abstract Note: In a study of 10 varieties, there was a positive correlation at harvest between ratooning ability and the content of total nonstructural carbohydrates (TNC) in the stem bases (10 cm above ground level). Rooting and bud sprouting ability of the first node above ground level, assessed in the laboratory after harvest, was also positively correlated with ratooning ability in the field, indicating that laboratory culture of the first node could be used in early screening tests for ratooning ability.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: BALASUBRAMANIAN, B.; MORACHAN, Y. B.; KALIAPPA, R.
Title: Studies on ratooning in rice. 1. Growth attributes and yield.
Abstract Note: In rice cv. IR8, ADT 27, Co 32 and Jeeraga Samba, the planted crop was harvested at 10, 20 or 30 cm above ground level and 40, 80 or 120 kg N/ha was applied to the stubble. In all treatments, ratoon yields were low even at the highest N application. All ratoon crops were shorter and the time taken to reach maturity was less than in the planted crops. Height of cutting the planted crops did not influence grain yield of the ratoons, but strongly influenced straw yields. Ratooning ability was shown to be a varietal characteristic. AGGH.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Palchamy, A.; Kolandaiswamy, S.
Title: Studies on ratooning in Vaigai and Bhavani rice varieties.
Abstract Note: Effects of 90-150 kg N/ha and stubble ht. on paddy yields of the ratoon crops of 2 rice cv. were determined. The mid-season cv. Bhavani harvested to a stubble ht. of 20 cm and given 120 kg N/ha yielded 4.85 t paddy/ha.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: ZhenXie, Yi; NaiMei, Tu; PingPing, Chen
Title: Studies on ratooning properties of a series of hybrid combinations derived from Peiai 64S.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted in 2002 in Changsha, Hunan, China, to study the growth, development and ratooning properties of 4 combinations of rice derived from Peiai 64S. The total grain yield of the first rice crop and ratooning rice was ranked as follows: Peiai 64 * E32 > Liangyoupei 9 > Peiai 64 * B32 > Peiliangyou 500. The order of the contribution of yield components to grain yield for ratooning rice was: effective panicles/plant > spikelets/panicle > seed setting percentage > 1000-grain weight. The yield components of first rice crop had obvious effects on the ratooning rate (RR). Significant positive correlations were recorded between RR and effective panicles/plant, and between RR and 1000-grain weight. Significant negative correlations were noted between RR and grains/panicle, and between RR and seed setting percentage. The source-sink properties of the first rice crop also had obvious effects on RR. Significant positive correlations were observed between RR and maximal leaf area index, and between RR and output rate of dry matter in stem and sheath.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Naidu, B. S.; Vasanthakumar, H. L.; Seshadri, V. S.; Nagaraju, M. S.
Title: Studies on ratoon performance of leaf blast-susceptible varieties at ARS, Ponnampet, Karnataka.
Abstract Note: Although all 50 rice varieties screened were susceptible to Pyricularia oryzae (7-9 on a 0-9 scale) and gave virtually no yield, IET9667, IET9668 and IET9670 gave rise to productive ratoon tillers which gave an average yield of 1.6 t/ha and were free from disease. In the ratoon, plant height was reduced by 46.6% and days to 50% flowering by 42.6%.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Reimann-Philipp, R.; Eichhorn-Rohde, Hanna
Title: STUDIES ON RELATIONSHIP OF FERTILITY AND MODE OF CHROMOSOME PAIRING IN TETRAPLOID F1-SPECIES HYBRIDS OF RYE (SECALE-CEREALE X SECALE-MONTANUM) HETEROZYGOUS FOR 3 TRANSLOCATED CHROMOSOMES
Abstract Note: 1. The practical purpose of the present investigation was to determine whether “preferential pairing” occurs in artificially induced tetraploid F1 species hybrids ofS. cereale andS. montanum which are heterozygous for three translocated chromosomes. Under these conditions chromosomes might form bivalents rather than the multivalent rings and chains usually found, resulting in a normal degree of fertility. 2. Several individuals of the tetraploidF 1 generation, heterozygous with respect to three translocated chromosomes, showed the expected percentages of quadrivalents always found in tetravalent rye, all other chromosome associations were bivalent (group 1 in table 1). The remaining individuals investigated also produced fewer multivalents than theoretically expected on the basis of the model proposed by Linnert (1962) and extended by us to include translocation figures composed of three translocated chromosomes. 3. It is to be assumed that in all of the plants investigated cytologically the quadrivalents were formed by the chromosomes not involved in the translocations. 4. Since the fertility of individuals with a strong tendency to form bivalents (group 1 in table 1) was no higher than that of plants producing a rather high percentage of multivalents, the rather high proportion of bivalents cannot be attributed to “preferential pairing” between chromosomes with increasing degrees of homology. Instead, it should probably be assumed that in the plants in question chiasma frequency was extremely low, so that heteromorphic bivalents instead multivalents were produced. 5. Proof of “preferential pairing” by cytological methods alone is rather difficult, because of the necessity to correctly distinguish the heteromorphic bivalents from the normal ones. It is discussed how use of the structural difference of chromosome VI ofS. montanum as compared to chromosome VI ofS. cereale which we detected recently, may serve to overcome this difficulty. 6. It appears that the goal of breeding a perennial, fully fertile, high-yielding rye hybrid may be achieved much more easily in diploids than in tetraploids, for in the tetraploid species hybrid success depends upon the selection not only of genotypes with high heritability for chiasma frequency but also for “zig-zag” distribution of the chromosomes involved in the formation of multivalents. In spite of our failure, a continued search for true “preferential pairing” may lead to its discover.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science
Automatic Tags: agriculture; Biochemistry, general; Biotechnology; Plant Biochemistry; Plant Genetics & Genomics; Plant Sciences

Author: Cao, W. Y.; Zhao, W. Y.; Zhao, S. M.
Title: Studies on resistance to rosette virus in different forms of wheat.
Abstract Note: Of 1986 forms screened in the field, 34 had a moderately high and 66 a moderate degree of resistance. In artificial inoculation tests, three very resistant forms were identified, of which "perennial wheat" was the most resistant. These three were also very resistant to Puccinia striiformis, P. graminis, P. recondita and Erysiphe graminis.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Hao, Tang; LiYun, Chen; YiShan, Yang; JunMing, Li
Title: Studies on the correlation between nutrient content and ratooning ability in rice.
Abstract Note: The correlation between nutrient content of the main crop and its ratooning ability was studied in 30 rice cultivars (hybrid crosses) grown in Changsha, Hunan, China. A slight correlation between ratooning ability and nutrient content at 18 days after full heading was observed. Ratooning ability was positively correlated with nitrogen and phosphorus contents at harvest, but negatively correlated with calcium, magnesium, manganese, copper and boron contents. The results suggest that fertilizer application to promote booting at 12 days before harvest and fertilizer application to protect booting at 5 days after harvest are necessary. Phosphorus fertilizer should be applied as a basal fertilizer, and calcium fertilizer should be applied separately depending on the requirement of the main and ratoon crops. Trace element fertilizers, such as magnesium, manganese, copper, boron and zinc fertilizers, should not be applied at later growth stages of the main crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: HSIEH, C. F.; KAO, S.; CHIANG, C.
Title: Studies on the cultivation of ratooned rice. 3. Effect of ploughing depth and amount of fertilizer on the viability and yield of ratooned rice.
Publication Title: Nung-yeh Yen-chiu = Journal of Taiwan Agricultural Research
Abstract Note: In trials in 1959-61, regrowth of ratooned rice decreased with increase in ploughing depth and with increase in the rate of N applied to the previous crop. Maximum grain yields were obtained from a 25-cm ploughing depth. F.en s. FAS.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Schulenburg, S.; Dorffling, K.
Title: Studies on the drought tolerance of perennial ryes.
Abstract Note: Perennial wild rye ( Secale montanum) X S. cereale hybrids show promise for fodder and grain production especially in semiarid regions where their advantages include drought tolerance. In pot experiments in which 6-week-old plants were deprived of water for 18 days, drought injury was markedly lower and survival rate and recovery after restoration of water supply higher in S. montanum and its perennial hybrid Sopertra than in 2 tetraploid and 1 diploid winter rye cultivars. Similarly, loss of leaf turgor and changes in leaf osmotic potentials were lower in hybrids Sopertra and Permontra than in the tetraploid winter rye cv. Teku and Halo. When S. montanum, the same perennial hybrids and several winter and summer rye cultivars were watered every 2 or 4 days, the perennials used less water and accumulated less DM during the first 4 weeks of growth than did the annual rye cultivars, but perennials were less sensitive than annuals to reductions in water supply. Shoot:root ratios were lower in perennials under the dry than under the wet conditions and they used water more efficiently for root growth than did the rye cultivars.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: HSIEH, C.-F.; KAO, S.; CHIANG, C.
Title: Studies on the method of growing rice from ratoons. II. Intervarietal differences in capacity for regrowth and in yield.
Publication Title: Nung-yeh Yen-chiu = Journal of Taiwan Agricultural Research
Abstract Note: The yield of 15 Peng-lai (= Horai) and 2 native varieties grown from ratoons was determined. Yield differences between varieties were marked but were always below that following transplanting.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Chen, W. G.; Lin, H.; Guan, W. F.; Tang, F. Q.
Title: Studies on the optimum NPK ratio and application level to low-intermediate yielding paddy fields.
Abstract Note: This paper summarizes the results of 37 trials of N, P and K application to 1st and 2nd rice crops in the low/intermediate-yielding paddy fields in Fujian Province in 1983. Yields of 1st and 2nd cropped rice given NPK were 15.4 to 54.1 and 17.3 to 46.8% higher, resp., than control yields. With N, P and K applied in various combinations, the order of the rice yield increase was NPK > NK > NP > PK > control. Highest yield was obtained at N:P:K ratio of 1:0.5:1, and the most economic results at 1:0.5:1 or 1:0-0.3:0.5 for 1st and 2nd crops, resp. The order of the yield increase for separate application was N > K > P. The effect of N, P and K on rice yield was higher for low-yielding than for high-yielding paddy fields. Opt. rates were 16 jin N, 4- 8 jin P 2O 5 and 8-10 jin K 2O/mu for 1st crop and 16 jin N, 0-4 jin P 2O 5 and 6-11.5 jin K 2O/mu for the 2nd rice crop. [1 jin=0.5 kg ; 1 mu=0.067 ha].
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Singh, R. B.; Singh, R. A.; Sharma, R. C.; Singh, D. C.; Singh, R. P.
Title: Studies on the spider's abundance in off-season rice(ratoon) ecosystem
Abstract Note: The abundance of predatory spiders in ratoon rice (off-season) was studied at ND. University of Agriculture & Technology, Faizabad, Uttar Pradesh with a view to utilize the importance of conservation & augmentation of such important fauna so that their population may flourish at their maximum level in next kharif rice. The observation reveled that population of wolf and crab spiders' were maximum (38.5 & 23.1%) under quadrate method and the population of crab, lynx and long jawed spiders were maximum (33.2, 19.8 & 18.2%) under net-sweeping method in off-season, which were prominent in kharif season. Thus, through this finding we can say that ratoon rice can be utilized as a prominent source of transmigration to the next kharif which can keep the pest population under check
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Chaudhry, M. S.; Acikgoz, N.
Title: Study of sowing date in six rice varieties and its effect on ratooning.
Abstract Note: Six varieties were sown at Menemen Izmir at 10-day intervals between 2 April and 1 June in 1980 and 1981. After transplanting, the varieties Krasnodarskii and Maratelli produced ratoon crops (about 20% of the first crop) after the first four sowings only, while the remaining varieties produced no ratoon crops. Observations on 13 characters indicated that the long-duration, high-yielding variety Calrose and the high-quality variety Basmati are suitable for the area when sown up to mid-May.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Lyubimova, V. F.; Poleva, L. V.
Title: Study of the development of new forms in wheat X wheatgrass hybrids involving Elytrigia elongata (Host) Nevski (2 n = 10 x = 70).
Abstract Note: Development of new forms was studied in the progenies of crosses of winter durum, winter bread and perennial [ Elymus X Triticum?] wheats with E. elongata [ Elymus elongatus], in backcrosses following controlled pollination of the F 1s with pollen from perennial wheat and in the F 1s under open pollination. Results are presented of the grain set and germination in the various crosses. Cytological observations revealed some aspects of the developmental process. The best ways of producing useful breeding forms are noted.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: JiChao, Yuan; XiaoHui, Sun; YianHua, Tian; Jun, Ma
Title: Study on nitrogen requirement and split application of nitrogen fertilizer in ratoon rice.
Abstract Note: Ratooned rice was given different rates of N fertilizer 15 d after full heading of the main crop (BF; bud fertilizer) and/or 1 d after harvest of the main crop (TF; tiller fertilizer). BF promoted carbohydrate and N metabolism during late growth of the main crop, enhancing bud growth and thus increasing numbers of tillers and effective panicles in the ratoon crop. TF promoted growth of the ratoon crop, increasing the percentage of filled spikelets and numbers of filled grains per panicle. It is suggested that N should be applied at both stages, and that the ratio of
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Ling, Q. H.; Su, Z. F.; Hou, K. P.; Guo, H. W.
Title: Study on the growth and panicle differentiation of resting buds in rice and their application.
Abstract Note: Observations on 7 rice cultivars in Yangzhou in 1986-87 showed that panicle differentiation in resting buds was initiated between the pistil and stamen differentiation stage and pollen mother cell differentiation in the main crop panicles. At heading of the main crop, the panicles of resting buds at middle or upper nodes showed spikelet primordia and those on lower nodes were less developed. Between heading and harvesting of the main crop, panicle differentiation in resting buds did not progress further. The cultivars differed in the percentage of buds regenerating from different nodes of the stem. Applying N 7-10 d before harvesting the 1st crop promoted regrowth from resting buds and improved grain number and wt/ear in the ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: FuXian, Xu; Hong, Xiong; GanLin, Zhao; Song, Hong
Title: Study on the mortality of axillary buds before harvest in hybrid mid-season rice and methods to reduce this.
Abstract Note: Studies in 1995-97 with rice cv. Keiyou 3, Keiyou 5 and Shanyou 63 showed that the mortality of axillary buds was very high before harvest of mid-season rice, especially at the 4th and 5th nodes from top. Among the dead buds, 95% of them were <3.5 cm long. Most of the photosynthates were transported to the panicles after full heading of the main crop, and little was distributed to the axillary buds. Improved light conditions and N application increased axillary bud growth. There were highly significant negative correlations between ratooning ability and the days from the date of N application for bud development (NABD) to full heading of the main crop. The best date for NABD was full heading of the main crop, but the effect of the date of NABD on increasing the grain yield of ratooned rice was related to the dry weight of the main stems. There was little effect when the dry weight of the main stems were very high or low.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Su, Z. F.; Zhang, H. C.; Hou, K. P.; Guo, H. W.
Title: Study on the role of panicle differentiation of ratooning rice and its application.
Abstract Note: Observations on 7 rice cultivars showed that 20 days before heading of the main crop, panicle initiation in resting buds was at the stage of differentiation of pistils and stamens or pollen mother cells. After the 1st crop was harvested, buds at the middle internodes of the ratooned plants differentiated earlier and more rapidly than those at the upper and lower position in some cultivars while in others all buds on the ratooned stems differentiated and developed in a downward sequential order of time and rate. It is concluded that when a ratoon crop is required, the cutting height for the 1st crop should be determined in accordance with the cultivar used.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: MaoLin, Ran; Hong, Xiong; Song, Hong; NaiHong, Zhang; YinPing, Chen; HuaZhong, Liu
Title: Study on the young ear differentiation character and the technology of sprouting for ratooning rice.
Publication Title: Southwest China Journal of Agricultural Sciences
Abstract Note: The factors affecting young ear differentiation, and sprouting technology in ratoon rice were studied. Sprouting of ratoon rice was affected synthetically by many factors such as rice stump nutrition, plant diseases and insect pests, seed characteristics, lodging, and drought. Young ear differentiation of ratoon rice occurred from low to high stems. Rates of differentiation had significantly differed for each stem. The highest differentiation happened at the fourth stage of the main crop. Young ear differentiation of ratoon rice synchronized with the growth of stem and leaf, heading and flowering of the main crop. Under good main crop cultivation conditions, and combined application of NPK with manure and chemical regulators to ratoon rice, balanced sprouting and stable, high yield can be obtained.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: RAMASWAMI, C.; HAWS, L. D.
Title: Successive cropping of IR8 paddy with notes on ratooning.
Abstract Note: In 4 successive crops of transplanted rice cv. IR8, part of the 3rd crop was ratooned and yielded 1400 kg paddy/ac in 69 days, compared with an average of 3012 kg/ac in 146 days for the 4 transplanted crops. AGGH.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: De la Cruz, C. G.; Litsinger, J. A.
Title: Suitability of ratoon rice as host to insects.
Abstract Note: All vegetative pests except Rivula atimeta had low survival on ratoon. Except for the yellow stemborer (YSB), reproductive stage pests were unaffected by ratoon. Developmental periods of rice pests were similar on ratoon and TPR [transplanted rice]. Ratoon was clearly less nutritious than TPR; surviving insects were smaller except for the whitebacked planthopper (WBPH). Vegetative stage pests - particularly whorl maggot, caseworm, and green semilooper - were least suited to ratoon. Reproductive stage pests were less affected. YSB actually survived better on ratoon, probably because of larger diameter stems, but the insects were smaller, WBPH developed equally on ratoon and TPR.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Title: Summary of ratoon rice cultivation in Zhejiang in 1986.
Abstract Note: The grain of a rice crop and its ratoon crop averaged 746.6 kg/mu, 16.9 kg/mu lower than that of double-cropped rice in a series of field experiments in 1986. As panicle number of the ratoon rice crop depends on the effective tillers of the previous crop and on the activity of axillary buds on mother culms, the optimum population is 350 000 effective tillers/mu at most. For a crop which is to be ratooned, it is essential to raise strong seedlings with 2 or more tillers/plant at a sowing rate of 10-20 kg/mu and to transplant the seedlings at the 7- to 8-leaf stage. It is recommended that fertilizer applications to the rice nursery be 20-30% higher than the usual rate. The optimum spacing is 23.1 * 13.2 to 20 * 20 cm with 2-3 seedlings/hill. In transplanted paddy fields, organic manure should be increased by 40%. Field management is very important for high yield of both the rice crop and its ratoon crop in the period from 1 month before to 1 month after harvest. Harvesting should be done at 90% maturity to stimulate growth of the axillary buds. The optimum cutting height is about 20 cm. Application of 5-8 kg urea/mu 5-7 days before harvest increased the yield of both rice crops. (1 mu = 0.067 ha).
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: DERZAVIN, A. I.
Title: Summary of work with perennial wheat in 1937.
Abstract Note: The perennial wheats are proving quite winter-hardy, and are superior to the standard Ukrainka in such qualities as vigour of growth, height and strength of straw, number of spikelets per ear and size of ear (twice that of Ukrainka in the second year of growth) and rust resistance. They were four days later in maturity than Ukrainka. Some individuals shattered rather badly when over-ripe and were therefore discarded; out of 300, 000 plants six were found with ears absolutely free from shattering, thereby removing one of the main defects of the perennial wheats. Many plants gave a second yield of grain later in the season.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: DER ZAVIN, A. I.
Title: Supplementary information on perennial rye, S ecale Kuprijanovi Grossh. and its agricultural value.
Publication Title: Trudy prikl. Bol. Genet i Selekcii. Ser.
Abstract Note: There is literature to indicate that 5. Kuprijanovi Grossh. segregated by A. A. Grossheim (1928) from S. montanum L. and primarily evaluated agriculturally by I. M. Kuprijanov (1922 to 1926) has long been cultivated in mountainous parts of North Caucasus and from here was evidently introduced into Turkey and Armenia by immigrating natives (1864). It is valued for its relative earliness among other perennial rye forms, and its compact and vigorously tillering bush of prostrate shape. It retains green stems and leaves at full grain maturity, thus being of particular value for forage and pasture. Low drought resistance, prolonged maturation, susceptibility to fungi and fragility of ear lower its quality as a grain crop. Winterhardiness is still to be ascertained. Individual selection has given good results, namely, forms with simultaneous maturation of grain, and spring and highly drought resistant forms. High self-fertility of S. Kuprijanovi makes it easy to split populations into sections. As it crosses readily with other annual and perennial ryes, further improvement of 5. Kuprijanovi is thought to be possible through hybridization. In F 1 generation perenniality is dominant, but this seems to be linked with winterness and fragility of ear.-M.A.O.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: Jia'nan, Xie; JianJun, Guo; DaoChao, Jin; QiRong, Liao; TianLei, Liu
Title: Survey on rice planthopper overwintering in southern Guizhou Province.
Abstract Note: To find out present overwintering situation of rice planthoppers in Guizhou Province, a survey research was taken in southern Guizhou Province during 2010-2012 by methods of nets, visual inspection and light trap. The results showed that in nowaday climate background, and in the south part of Guizhou Province, such as Chaoyang and Yongkang, Sogatella furcifera and Laodelphax striatellus succeeded in overwintering on ratooning rice, of which long-wing type was more than short-wing type, females were more than males. Those overwintering rice planthoppers had very little effect on breakout of the initial rice planthoppers in the next spring.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Han, Xiao; CunShan, Ying
Title: Survey on the variations of morphological characters within the natural population of Dongxiang wild rice.
Abstract Note: Dongxiang wild rice ( Oryza sativa f. spontanea) regenerates by ratooning from nodes of lodged and buried stems. Comparisons with O. rufipogon have suggested that it is an exclusively perennial type. Information is presented from a principal component analysis of plant characters within a natural population of Dongxiang wild rice. Differences are noted between the subpopulations Linchang and Shuitao Tree.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Vromant, N.; Nam, C.Q.; Chau, N.T.H.; Ollevier, F.
Title: Survival rate and growth performance of Cyprinus carpio L. in intensively cultivated rice fields
Abstract Note: In the freshwater area of Vietnam's Mekong Delta, Barbodes gonionotus (Bleeker), Cyprinus carpio L, and Oreochromis niloticus (L.) are often reared together in rice fields. The survival rate and specific growth rate (SGR) of C. carpio showed a large variance. To understand the underlying reasons for this variation, we used multiple regressions for the variables SGR and survival rate, using the results of eight experiments in such polycultures at the Co Do rice-fish experimental station. The SGR of C. carpio declined with increasing rice density. Interspecific competition with O. niloticus also had a negative effect on C. carpio SGR. When fertilizer or manure is added to the trench of the rice-fish field or when extra food can be given to the fish, O. niloticus seems more appropriate than C. carpio. The survival rate of C. carpio depended on season, C. carpio stocking weight and density and the biomass of wild fish species. To obtain higher survival rates, one should stock fewer fish but of a larger size, after thorough eradication of wild fish species.

Author: Cadle-Davidson, L.; Bergstrom, G. C.; Cox, T. S.
Title: Susceptibility of perennial small grains to Soilborne wheat mosaic virus and Wheat spindle streak mosaic virus.
Abstract Note: Preliminary experiments were conducted to assess whether 8 of the most promising, yet diverse, perennial wheat and rye breeding lines were susceptible to Soilborne wheat mosaic virus (SBWMV) and Wheat spindle streak mosaic virus (WSSMV), either individually or when co-inoculated. The lines included were: AT3425 (putatively Triticum aestivum * Thinopyrum ponticum [ Elymus elongatus]), BFPMC1 ( Thinopyrum intermedium [ Elymus hispidus]), Permontra ( Secale cereale * S. montanum), PI-368149, PI-368150 ( Triticum turgidum * S. montanum), Spitzer, TA12252 ( S. montanum) and Varimontra (reselection of Permontra). Two seeds were planted into one-inch balls of moistened soil collected from SBWMV- and WSSMV-infested fields or a mixture of both soils (for co-inoculation). Two dozen soil balls per genotype per soil inoculum were planted into microplots of previously non-infested soil confined by fibreglass barriers at Tailby field, Ithaca, New York, USA in October 2001. Plants were inspected for virus-like symptoms in May, September and October 2002. All genotypes, except Spitzer, were considered to be at least moderately susceptible to one or both viruses based on the observation of typical disease symptoms in some inoculated plants. ELISA was used to confirm visual symptoms observed in May 2002. For SBWMV, ELISA confirmed infection of AT3425, PI-368149, TA12252 and Varimontra. For WSSMV, ELISA confirmed infection of AT3425 and Permontra. ELISA also confirmed co-infection of AT3425, BFPMC1, Permontra, PI-368149, PI-368150, TA12252 and Varimontra by SBWMV and WSSMV. None of the singly inoculated plants were co-infected. Strikingly, co-inoculation resulted in increased infection by both viruses. No symptoms were observed during autumn 2002, even though autumn temperatures were similar to those that were conducive for symptom development in the spring. No plants, whether infected by virus or not, survived the following winter for unknown reasons. The results suggest that perennial small grains are at risk for infection by soilborne viruses and that resistant cultivars may be needed for management of these diseases.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; full text added; perennial N1 grain; relevant; search.grain; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science
Automatic Tags: disease resistance; Elytrigia intermedia subsp. intermedia; Elytrigia pontica; hybrids; intergeneric hybridization; lines; perennials; Secale strictum subsp. strictum; soil-borne diseases; Soil-borne wheat mosaic virus; Triticum aestivum; Triticum turgidum; wheat; Wheat spindle streak mosaic virus

Author: Michels Jr., G.J.; Jones, E.N.; Rush, C.M.
Title: Susceptibility of selected perennial small grain cultivars, to greenbug, schizaphis graminum (Rondani) (Hemiptera: Aphididae)
Abstract Note: Twelve perennial small grain cultivars were examined for eight characteristics favorable to management of greenbug, Schizaphis graminum (Rondani). A greenbug-susceptible variety of hard red winter wheat, Triticum aestivum L., and a greenbug-resistant hard red winter wheat variety were used as checks. Eight of the 12 perennial small grain cultivars (including * Triticosecale spp./ Thinopyrum intermedium II * Triticosecale spp., * Triticosecale spp./ Thinopyrum ponticum II * Triticosecale spp., Thinopyrum ponticum/Triticum aestivum var. Eltan, * Agrotriticum spp. (PI550715)/ Tripsacum dactyloides var. Spitzer, and Hordeum vulgare var. MT2/ Tripsacum dactyloides var. Spitzer) had at least one favorable greenbug management characteristic. Cultivars that included * Triticosecale spp. and either Thinopyrum intermedium (Host) Barkworth & D.R. Dewey or T. ponticum wheatgrass in their genetic background had the most favorable characteristics.
Manual Tags: ALL(perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE(ar); ALL(perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); relevant; Scopus; search.grain; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); Web of Science

Author: Washburn, Jacob D.; Murray, Seth C.; Burson, Byron L.; Klein, Robert R.; Jessup, Russell W.
Title: Targeted mapping of quantitative trait locus regions for rhizomatousness in chromosome SBI-01 and analysis of overwintering in a Sorghum bicolor x S. propinquum population
Abstract Note: While rhizome formation is intimately associated with perennialism and the derived benefit of sustainability, the introduction of this trait into temperate-zone adapted Sorghum cultivars requires precise knowledge of the genetics conditioning this trait in order to minimize the risk of weediness (e.g., Johnsongrass, S. halepense) while maximizing the productivity of perennial sorghum. As an incremental step towards dissecting the genetics of perennialism, a segregating F4 heterogeneous inbred family derived from a cross between S. bicolor and S. propinquum was phenotyped in both field and greenhouse environments for traits related to over-wintering and rhizome formation. An unseasonably cold winter in 2011 provided high selection pressure, and hence 74.8 % of the population did not survive. This severe selection pressure for cold tolerance allowed the resolution of two previously unidentified over-wintering quantitative trait locus (QTL) and more powerful correlation models than previously reported. Conflicting with previous reports, a maximum of 33 % of over-wintering variation could be explained by above-ground shoot formation from rhizomes; however, every over-wintering plant exhibited rhizome growth. Thus, while rhizome formation is required for over-wintering, other factors also determine survival in this interspecific population. The fine mapping of a previously reported rhizome QTL on sorghum chromosome SBI-01 was conducted by targeting this genomic region with additional simple sequence repeat markers. Fine mapping reduced the 2-LOD rhizome QTL interval from similar to 59 to similar to 14.5 Mb, which represents a 75 % reduction in physical distance and a 53 % reduction in the number of putative genes in the locus.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; ALL(perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE(ar); ALL(perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE(ar); ALL(perennial W/1 sorghum) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Perennialism; Perenniality; perennial N1 sorghum; relevant; Rhizomes; Scopus; search.grain; search.rice; search.sorghum; Sorghum; Sorghum bicolor; Sorghum halepense; Sorghum propinquum; Sorghum x almum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); Web of Science
