Author: SHARMA, S. D.; SHASTRY, S. V. S.
Title: Taxonomic studies in genus Oryza L. [Gramineae]. II. Some nomenclatural confusions
Abstract Note: Wild rices of Asia have been variously referred to by different workers as Oryza perennis, O. fatua, O. rufipogon, O. sativa var. fatua O. sativa L. f. spontanea, O. balunga, O. formosana etc. The validity of each of these names and their application to the taxa are discussed, and it is concluded that the name O. perennis is to be discarded: the valid name for perennial wild rice of Asia is O. rufipogon; and annual wild rice of Asia lacks a valid name.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: OSSENT, H. P.
Title: Ten years of rye-breeding is Mucheberg.
Abstract Note: Different varieties oi rye react differently to prolonged inbreeding; some show only a very slight degree of degeneration. It has also been observed that in individual progenies the expression of the degeneration may vary. Vegetative vigour may be affected in some cases, in others the fertility. By 1937, after continuous inbreeding and selection a whole series of strains resistant to the ill-effects of inbreeding had been produced and a large number of crosses between them were made representing the beginning oi a systematic combination breeding programme. One of the objects is the production of a, rye with good baking quality and another the production of a perennial cultivated rye. Crosses between S. cereals and S. montanum anatolicum have been made and the promising progenies are being studied.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: TSITSIN; CICIN], N. V.
Title: The 1954 U.S.S.R. agricultural exhibition.
Abstract Note: The director of the exhibition describes its chief features. Among the exhibits are some 2000 crop varieties, of which 354 represent the cereals, including high-yielding wheat-Agropyron hybrids highly resistant to lodging and plots of perennial wheat. A large "Micurin orchard" is also on display.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: SOUDNOV, P.
Title: The after-harvest growing of perennial wheat and perennial rye.
Abstract Note: Perennial wheat ( Triticum x Agropyron) and rye sprouted better after the first crop of grain when this was cut high than when cut low.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: HART, J.
Title: The agricultural potential of the Central Queensland Highlands
Abstract Note: The area was opened in 1870 and has been farmed spasmodically but with little success. Farmers from other areas are now slowly moving in and the area has high potential yields when the proper methods are followed. Tractors and modern machinery have made the development possible. The Highlands include 24,000,000 acres on the Tropic of Capricorn and 100 to 300 miles inland. The rainfall averages 26 inches with monsoon rains in summer and dry winters. The mean minimum temperaute is 58[degree]F. and the mean maximum 85[degree]. There are 310 frost-free days. The open downs country which requires practically no clearing is undulating (2[degree] to 5[degree] slopes) and potentially erosive, hence strip cropping is the ideal system. Cultivated crops include grain or sweet sorghum, wheat, linseed and sunflower. Oats are used for a winter grazing crop. Sorghum and wheat yield 60 bu. per acre when properly managed and sorghum is especially valuable because it may ratoon for 4 or 5 years. Stubble mulching on the fallow land is necessary. Land with soil less than two feet deep is risky, three and four feet are better so as to store plenty of water. Also it is necessary to avoid land with stone underlying the surface. The proper size of a living area seems to lie between 1500 and 5000 areas. At present three acres are required per sheep but this can be reduced to one acre by proper handling and 2500 to 3000 sheep afford a reasonable living.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: KHOLODNY, T.
Title: The birth of perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: An account is given of Cicin's investigations on crossing wheat with Agropyron. Reference is made to a meeting between Micurin and Cicin in 1927, at which Micurin made the suggestion of improving wheat by remote hybridization.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: CONRAD, JOHN P.
Title: The carbohydrate composition of corn and sorghum roots
Publication Title: Journal of the American Society of Agronomy
Abstract Note: With different types and varieties of sorghums at maturity, the total sugars as sucrose in the roots in preliminary tests in 1927 varied from about 15% to over 55% on the basis of dry organic matter; in corn roots they varied from much less than 1 to about 4.5%. In more extensive expts. in 1928, the sugars in corn (King Philip Hybrid) decreased from amts. varying from about 8.5 to nearly 18% at blossom stage down to amts., with one exception, below 2.5% at maturity. This suggests a movement of sugars to the ear during the maturing of the crop. Sugars in sorghum (White Durra) with but few exceptions remained about 16% from bloom to maturity, with many of the samples being over 30%. These and other data given are consistent with the view that corn is physiologically an annual, while sorghums are perennials.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; perennial N1 sorghum; relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); Web of Science
Automatic Tags: carbohydrates; chemical constituents of plants; roots; Zea mays

Author: HuiJie, Yang; JingSheng, Zheng; ZhaoWei, Jiang; YiZhen, Li; ChuanYing, Zhuo; ShangShou, Zhang
Title: The characters of sink structure of super high-yielding ratooning rice.
Abstract Note: The sink structure of ratooning rice with different yield potentials was investigated in 2000. The variety used in the study was Xianyouming 86, a super high-yielding rice. Results indicated that yield was most closely related to spikelet number per panicle in the first season, and this yield factor contributed most to yield. In the ratooning season, yield was most closely related to panicle number, which was the main contributor to yield. Super high-yielding ratooning rice had larger sinks [than lower yielding varieties?], not only in the first season but also in the ratooning season. The sink volume made a greater contribution to yield than did seed setting. The contribution of total spikelet number per unit area to yield was higher than that of grain weight. The contribution of spikelet number per panicle to total spikelet number per unit area was higher than panicle number per area in the first season, and in the ratooning season this was the other way round. It is concluded that larger panicles should be fostered in the first season to enlarge the sink volume in order to obtain higher yield, but panicle numbers should be fostered in the ratooning season.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: ISKENDEROV, S. G.
Title: The chemical composition of perennial hybrid gramineous plants, and of their mixtures with legumes, at various stages of growth.
Publication Title: Sbornik Trudov Aspirantov i Molodykh Nauchnykh Sotrudnihov. Vsesoyuznyi   Nauchno-Issledovaterskii Institut N.I. Vavilova
Abstract Note: Herbage of perennial hybrid wheat ( Secale kuprijanovii * Triticum durum), perennial hybrid rye ( S. kuprijanovii * S. segetale), cocksfoot and lucerne, grown in Azerbaidzhan was analysed for CP and carotene in the 1st and 2nd yr of growth. Wheat and rye hybrids contained 21.4 and 20.5% CP (DM basis), respectively, at full-flowering in the 1st yr and 17.5% (both hybrids) at the same stage in the 2nd yr; cocksfoot contained 13.5 and 12.9% CP in the 1st and 2nd yr, respectively. Mixtures of wheat and rye hybrids with cocksfoot, lucerne, vetches and fodder peas in various combinations were also analysed and recommendations are made for their cultivation for fodder. -A.V.B.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: KangJing, Liang; ShiLiao, Chen; KaiJian, Chen; JuSheng, Wang; WenMo, Fang; YuanXiang, Zhou; GuanHan, Xiao
Title: The comparison and correlation and path analysis of yield and its components between the first and ratooning crop of hybrid rice.
Abstract Note: Information on yield correlations is derived from data on several yield components in the hybrid varieties Shanyou 669 and Shanyou Douxi 1. Panicle number in the first and ratoon crop was considered to have the most effect on yield.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Y-I, CHU; R-F, LIOU
Title: THE COMPARISON OF FEEDING MARKS AND HONEYDEW EXCRETION OF GREEN RICE LEAFHOPPER NEPHOTETTIX-CINCTICEPS ON VARIOUS GRAMINACEOUS PLANTS DELTOCEPHALIDAE HOMOPTERA
Abstract Note: The relationship between the suitability of host plants and feeding amount of green rice leafhopper (N. cincticeps Uhler) was investigated. Feeding amount is evaluated by the number of feeding marks on each tested plant, and the sugar and amino acid content in the honeydew. The following 20 spp. of graminaceous plants were used: bermuda grass (Cynodon dactylon Pers.), torpelo grass (Panicum repens Linn.), goosegrass (Eleusine indica Gaerth), buffalo grass (Paspalum conjugatum Berg.), dillis grass (P. dilatum Poiret.), knot grass (P. distichum Linn.), water bamboo (Zizania aquatica Linn.), sugarcane (Saccharum officinarum Linn., F160), Setaria italica Kth. (Taidong no. 3), wheat (Triticum sativum Lam. var. vulgare. Taichung no. 31), corn (Zea mays Linn., Tainan no. 11), oat (Avena fatua Linn., NTU no. 1), sorghum (Andropogon sorghum Brot., Taihung no. 3), dent foxtail (Alopecurus aequalis Sobolewsky), barnyard grass (Echinochloa crus-galli Beauv.), Leersia hexandra, ratoon paddy (Oryza sativa Linn., Tainong no. 67), and paddy (O. sativa Luin., Tainan no. 5), Brachiaria mutica, Sporobolus fertilis. Then, ten 3rd- to 4th-instar nymphs or 3-5 day-old male and female adult leafhoppers were inoculated on each host plant and exposed for 48 h. The number of feeding marks on a host plant was not consistent with the suitability of the plant to the leafhopper. The occurrence of feeding marks on preferable host plants is arranged in the following order: ratoon paddy > paddy > leersia > grass > barnyard grass > dent foxtail. The combinations of probing stimulant, sucking stimulant, nutrients within the plant juice and the physical characters of the plant cuticles for feeding mark formation may result in this inconsistency. The honeydew from the most favorable host plants, including paddy ratoon paddy, barnyard grass, leersia grass and dent foxtail contains more carbohydrates and amino acids than the others. Estimation of carbohydrates and amino acid content in honeydew provides a simple and rapid bioassay method for the evaluation of suitability of plants to green rice leafhopper.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Hay, R.K.M.
Title: The contribution of crop physiology to strategies for new arable crops for cool wet regions : a case history from Scotland
Abstract Note: This paper reviews a range of arguments for the continued investment of research and development resources into the formulation of new crops and cropping systems for the Scottish arable area, laying particular emphasis on the high potential for dry-matter production of well-adapted crops in northwest Europe. This high potential arises out of the combination of cool temperatures and long photoperiods which favours the prolonged interception of solar radiation by extending the duration of the leaf canopy. In practice, realisation of this potential depends primarily on soil water conditions, which, in turn, determine dates of planting and harvesting, thereby delimiting the actual, as distinct from the potential, growing season. The fitting of the new crop to the actual growing season, or the development of strategies to avoid or tolerate the effects of wet soils in spring and autumn must therefore be primary aims in the selection of new varieties or species for Scotland. Four possible approaches, each of which has been used with success elsewhere, are reviewed, namely : the empirical approach, agrometeorological modelling, the adoption of perennial crops, and the use of crops yielding products of high value. Although at least three of these strategies have received attention over the last decade, only the empirical approach has had a significant influence on the proportions of species grown in Scotland (changes in areas of winter cereals, oilseeds and peas). It is concluded that, to date, crop physiology has contributed very little to the formulation of new cropping systems. However, crop physiology has made an important contribution in the interpretation of high yields at higher latitudes, pointing to a new set of arable energy crops for the next century, when supplies of fossil fuels will dwindle. In the meantime, investment in the development of such crops will depend upon policies for the pricing of fossil fuels and the use of surplus arable land in the EC.
Manual Tags: Alternative crops; crop physiology; daylength; full text unavailable; perennial W/1 grain; relevant; ScienceDirect; Scotland; search.grain; soil water relations; SPV; Temperature

Author: SOKOLOVA, S. M.
Title: The conversion of nitrogenous substances in perennial wheat
Publication Title: Byul Mosk Obshch Ispytat Prirody Otd Biol
Abstract Note: Triticum agropyrotriticum perenne, a hybrid derived from crossing Lutescens 329, a winter wheat, with Agropyron glaucum, was analyzed at various growth phases for total N, amine N, and protein N in leaves and grain. Data obtained by means of microanalysis, precipitation with trichloracetic acid, and paper chro-matography indicate that the hybrid leaves have the highest total N content in early phases and that N content decreases by 75% by the milk ripe stage. Protein N decreases at the same rate, while non-protein N decreases by 50%. A 50% drop in amino-acid N occurs at the time of flowering. In the grain total protein changes from 3.25% of absolute dry weight at the milk ripe stage to 2.94% at the wax ripe stage, to 2.97% at full ripeness; corresponding figures for non-protein N are 0.48%, 0.45%, and 0.32%, and for protein N, 2.77%, 2.49%, and 2.67%. In the process of ripening the amino-acid content changes in quality and quantity; the maximum occurs at the milk ripe stage. Perennial wheat contains more gliadin and glutelin and less globulin than other wheat hybrids. A bibliography of 12 titles is included.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Hill, R.D.
Title: The cultivation of perennial rice, an early phase in Southeast Asian agriculture?
Abstract Note: Domesticated rice, Oryza sativa L., though a perennial, is nowadays usually cultivated as an annual. This has led a number of commentators to misinterpret the historical record. The older view that rice was domesticated around the Bay of Bengal and in parts of mainland Southeast Asia has been replaced by competing views of earliest domestication in that region and in the Yangzi valley. Botanical considerations point clearly to the retention of perennial characteristics while archaeological and historical evidences point to cultivation with more than a single harvest from an initial planting – the practice of ratooning. Evidence is reviewed briefly for China and more extensively for Southeast Asia. Modern field evidence is used to support the notion that ratooning was probably more widespread in the past and that this practice may represent an early phase in the history of rice agriculture in Southeast Asia as it does in China.
Manual Tags: agricultural history; ALL(perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE(ar); ALL(perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE(ar); archaeological evidence; Asian prehistory; Bay of Bengal; China; Crop production; Cultivation; full text added; History of early agriculture; Indian Ocean; Oryza sativa; Perennial crops; perennial plant; perennial W/1 grain; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); prehistoric; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); relevant; Rice; Rice cultivation; ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.grain; search.rice; Southeast Asia; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: NengPu, Shi
Title: The development of ratooning rice and its utilization.
Abstract Note: The benefits of ratoon cultivation of rice and the increased use of the technique were considered. In trials in 1992-96 yields of the main crop of early rice were 7.60-9.46 t/ha and the ratoon crop yielded 3.10-6.24 t/ha. Ratoon cultivation of intermediate rice and of hybrid rice were also considered.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Anonymous
Title: The divisions of Plant Industry and Breeding and of Plant Protection.
Abstract Note: At a joint meeting of the two divisions of the All-Union Lenin Academy of Agricultural Sciences on 26-27 March, 1970, N. V. Turbin reported that over 11, 000 items had been added to the world collections in the past year; some of the most interesting were listed. The achievements mentioned included the selection of perennial wheat lines; tetraploid carrots with larger roots; useful mutants of a number of crops; and the production of unproved cultivars of wheat, barley, maize, rice, tomato and subtropical fruits and nuts, the best of which are listed. S. I. Ibragimov, reporting on the Cotton Research Institute, mentioned a number of new cultivars produced, which included Surhan, an Egyptian cotton resistant to Fusarium, and several other wilt-resistant cultivars. V. F. Peresypkin, reporting on advances in plant protection, referred to wheats resistant to rust and potatoes to wart and blight, for use in breeding resistant varieties. Wheat cultivars have been shown to be mixed in respect of resistance to Puccinia recondita', race 77 attacks all cultivars but Avrora, Kavkaz and Il'ioevka; no standard Egyptian cotton is resistant to Verticillium and Fusarium wilts, the least affected being 6249V.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: SKRIPCINSKII, V. V.
Title: The dying-off of vegetative organs of perennial and annual grasses at the time of seed ripening.
Abstract Note: The characteristic difference between annual and perennial plants, which is apparent at the time of seed ripening; is the complete dying-off of the vegetative organs in annuals and the preservation of these organs in perennials. In 1949, preliminary work was begun on the physiology of perishing in the vegetative organs in annual grasses. Two annuals (Hostianum 237 winter wheat, and Tarasanskaja winter rye), and 2 perennials (cultivated rye and wild rye, Secale anatolicum) were grown. The leaf lamina, leaf sheath and internodes were studied in regard to changes in vitality and water content (estimated, visually, by change in colour from green to yellow and by relative turgidity) at different stages of seed ripening, namely, 14 June (beginning of seed setting), 3 July (wax ripeness), 11 July (full ripeness), and 4 August (over-ripeness). For economy of space the data obtained are given (in tables) only for Hostianum 237 and wild rye. The figures are discussed in relation to the transfer of nutrient substances from the vegetative organs to the seeds, with special reference to the fact that the perennials are reproduced by seeds and by vegetative reproduction, whereas the annuals are reproduced by seeds only. Dying-off in perennials is characterized by two phases of perishing in the leaves. The first coincides with the onset of seed setting and takes place in the lowest leaves of the stem, proceeding (as in annuals) from the base upwards; the second coincides with seed filling and ripening, but starts in the upper leaves, and proceeds downwards. It is concluded that this characteristic of the perennials may be useful in selection studies.-M.H.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: Samson, B. T.; Zandstra, H. G.; Mabbayad, B. B.
Title: The effect of clipping portion of the rice panicles/leaves as a method of inducing ratoonability in rice.
Abstract Note: The sensitivity that ratooning showed to minor changes in harvest dates of the main crop and the response to lower temperatures led us to evaluate the effect of panicle and leaf clipping treatments to modify the source-sink ratio of the plant. In 1979 wet season, clipping experiments at IRRI using a randomized complete block design. Results showed that tillering increased from 10 to 14 per hill where half of each panicle was removed and reduced from 10 to 6 per hill where half of each leaf was removed. These effects were further confirmed in the following dry season trial, which also showed that late clipping of the panicles (at soft dough stage) may lessen the increase in ratooning. Plant analysis of the rice stubble (0 to 15 cm above ground level) and roots of the main crop at harvest showed that the number of ratoon tillers produced to significantly relate to % carbohydrate (anhydroglucose) content. These results indicate that ratooning ability is closely associated with the amount of carbohydrate left in the plant stubble at harvest.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Kirkegaard, J.A.; So, H.B.; Troedson, R.J.; Wallis, E.S.
Title: The effect of compaction on the growth of pigeonpea on clay soils. I. Mechanisms of crop response and seasonal effects on a vertisol in a sub-humid environment
Abstract Note: Field experiments were conducted on a vertisol at Dalby, southeast Queensland to investigate the effect of soil compaction on the growth and seed yield of pigeonpea (Cajanus cajan). Deep ripping and roller compaction were used to establish three compaction treatments which represented the range of conditions observed in commercial fields. Trials were conducted with and without irrigation over two growing seasons (1984/1985 and 1987/1988). Growth restrictions resulting from compaction were primarily related to reduced water uptake resulting from decreased infiltration and storage of water, and restricted root growth. Seasonal conditions, in particular the distribution of rainfall, exerted a strong influence on plant response. Yield reductions resulting from compaction varied from 100% in a very dry season to 0% in a wetter season. The reduced impact of compaction in the wetter season was associated with reduced levels of soil strength during early root growth and a decreased reliance on stored subsoil water for growth. The effects of seasonal conditions on plant response make it difficult to predict the yield reduction likely to result from compaction and to identify a critical level of compaction when ameliorative measures are required. A modelling approach is required to assist in the prediction of yield reductions resulting from compaction and to identify seasonal conditions under which yield losses are likely to be most severe.
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat); relevant; ScienceDirect; search.wheat; SPV

Author: Samson, B. T.; Zandstra, H. G.; Mabbayad, B. B.
Title: The effect of different temperature regimes on the ratoonability of two IRRI rice varieties.
Abstract Note: Experimental results in 1978 have shown that exceptionally good ratoon crop yields at the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI) reached 2.0 to 3.2 t/ha in replicated small plot trials using 13 rice varieties tested under three different water regimes. Further trials in 1979 dry season using the same varieties proved disappointing. High temperature (35°C daily maximum) and solar radiation (600 g-cal/cm 2/day) around harvest time appeared to be the cause of high percentage of missing hills (89%) thus, low yields. These trials also showed ratooning (tillers per hill) and ratoon yields to be unstable. To test the effects of temperature we placed two rice varieties inside the IRRI phytotron glasshouse rooms using a randomized complete block design. After the plant crop harvest, pots exposed to low temperature formed twice the number of ratoon tillers than those of normal and high temperature. Ratoon grain yields were very low in the 20/20°C regime because of sterility. These results indicate that ratooning ability may be associated with the amount of carbohydrate left in the stubble and roots of the main crop at harvest Plant analysis of the ratooned hills at harvest should be done to determine the total amount of % carbohydrate (anhydroglucose) content.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Mobasser, H. R.; Rostaei, K.; Alamdari, M. Q.
Title: The effect of main crop harvesting time on rice-ratoon and berseem clover ( Trifolium alexanderinum L.) yield as intercropping system.
Publication Title: International Journal of Agronomy and Plant Production
Abstract Note: To determine the effect of main crop harvesting time on rice ratoon and berseem clover yield as intercropping system, the experiment was conducted out as split plot in randomized complete block design with three replications in Northern Iran at 2010. Main crop harvesting time of rice has been chosen as main plot at four levels; 19 and 26 August, and 2 and 9 September. The kind of cultivation has been also chosen as sub-plot at three levels; berseem clover cultivation, ratooning, and intercropping berseem clover with rice ratoon. The results showed that the total number of tillers and effective tillers per hill, the total number of spikelet per panicle and percentage of filled spikelet were significantly decreased by delaying harvesting time. The maximum grain yield and harvesting index were attained by earlier harvesting time at
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Samson, B. T.; Zandstra, H. G.
Title: The effect of two temperature regimes on the ratoonability of some IRRI cultivars/experimental lines.
Abstract Note: Previous rice ratooning trials conducted at IRRI showed ratooning (tillers per hill) and ratoon yields to be unstable. High temperatures around harvest time appeared to be a possible cause for the high percentage of missing hills in the ratoon crops, thus low yields. In this experiment, we tested the effect of high temperature during flowering and maturation stages on rice ratoon yields. Eight IRRI cultivars and experimental lines were grown in the IRRI Phytotron under two temperature regimes 35/27C and 29/21C (day/night) using a randomized complete block design. While the number of tillers were greater in the high temperature regime, the sterility in the panicles were greater than for plants grown in the low temperature regime. Consequently, grain yields were approximately nine fold greater from plants grown in the cooler temperatures than for plants grown at the high temperatures. Plants were taller and maturity was earlier when grown in the hot room than the plants grown in the cooler room. The rice cultivars and experimental lines tested showed great yield differences to temperature both for the main crop and ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Mackenzie, DH; Basinski, JJ; Parbery, DB
Title: The effect of varieties, nitrogen and stubble treatments on successive cycles of grain and forage sorghums in the Ord River valley
Abstract Note: Two exploratory experiments with re-cycled (ratooned) grain sorghums (hybrid Texas R.S. 610 and standard variety Alpha) and forage sorghums (hybrid Sudax and standard variety Sugardrip) were carried out at Kimberley Research Station to provide data for the initial assessment of sorghum production possibilities in the Ord River area. Re-cycling of sorghum led to progressive reduction in grain and dry matter yields. Grain yield reduction was greater when stubble was cut at the header height (approximately 40 inches) than when it was cut at 6 to 8 inches above ground level and removed. Grain and dry matter yields were higher for Texas R.S. 610 than for Alpha, while dry matter yield of Sudax was also higher than that of Sugardrip. Nitrogen application at 50 lb N an acre and 100 lb N an acre increased grain yields of Texas R.S. 610 and Alpha. It also increased dry matter yields of these two varieties and of Sugardrip, while dry matter yield of Sudax did not respond above the 50 lb N an acre rate of application. Relative, but not absolute, reduction of grain and dry matter yields in successive cycles was diminished by nitrogen application.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: Ichii, M.
Title: The effect of water management on ratoon ability of rice plants.
Publication Title: Technical Bulletin of Faculty of Agriculture, Kagawa University
Abstract Note: In pot trials, ratoon production of rice cv. Yaeho cut at 10 days after heading to 5 cm ht. was similar (40-60%) to that of plants cut to ground level without flooding whereas there was little ratoon production in plants cut to ground level and flooded after cutting. In cv. Oseto, the number of ratoon tillers was >80% in plants cut to 5 cm ht. and was only slightly reduced by cutting to ground level without flooding, but was <10% in flooded plants cut to ground level. Ratoon ht. followed a similar trend. In a 2nd trial, ratoon number and ht. of rice cv. Koshihikari cut to 20 cm ht. on the 10th day after heading was not affected by irrigation or flooding treatments.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Huang, H. C.; Tsai, Y. F.; Huang, S. N.
Title: The effects of application of pig manure on the growth and yield of upland crops.
Publication Title: Bulletin of Taichung District Agricultural Improvement Station
Abstract Note: In field trials at Changhua (slightly alkaline slate alluvial soil) and Taichung (strong acidic red earth) in 1988-91, 10 or 20 t pig manure/ha or chemical fertilizers at rates recommended for the individual crops or both pig manure and chemical fertilizer were applied to a sorghum/ratooned sorghum/maize cropping sequence. Pig manure either alone or with chemical fertilizer increased plant height, spike weight, 1000-grain weight and grain yields. In some cases the higher rate of pig manure was more effective than chemical fertilizer alone. Maize gave the best response to 20 t pig manure + chemical fertilizer, while sorghum and ratooned sorghum responded best to 10 t pig manure + chemical fertilizer. Pig manure increased root density of maize at a depth of 30 cm.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: MURAV'EV, P. A.
Title: The grain quality of certain annual Triticum Agropyron hybrids of N. V. Tzitzin and of A. I. Derzavin's perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: The grain properties of a number of the annual hybrids are described. Some of them are of good quality, but their bread is not superior to that from the best standard wheat varieties. The perennial hybrid produced bread of inferior quality, though excellent in flavour.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: TlMOFEEVA-TJULINA, M. T.
Title: The hardiness of evergrowing (perennial) wheat.
Abstract Note: The difficulties of training perennial wheats 2 and 3 for hardiness are discussed; they prefer the foreign pollen of wheat or Agropyron to self pollen with the result that they lose the perennial habit or the desirable characters of wheat, respectively.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Chauhan, Y. S.; Venkataratnam, N.; Sheldrake, A. R.
Title: The high-yield potential of extra-early pigeonpeas in peninsular India.
Abstract Note: In field studies in 1982 the extra-early pigeonpea cv. ICPL 1, ICPL 81 and ICPL 87 were sown to give populations of 160 000, 260 000, 420 000 and 670 000 plants/ha on 15 June and 23 Aug. at the ICRISAT Center, peninsular India and on 18 June at Hissar, northern India. At the ICRISAT Center these cv. flowered and matured about 1 month earlier than at Hissar. 3 harvests could be taken with June sowing at ICRISAT, with cv. ICPL 4, ICPL 81 and ICPL 87 giving totals of 3060, 3870 and 5220 kg seed/ha, resp. 2 harvests were taken with Aug. sowing, giving totals of 1280, 1582 and 2270 kg/ha, resp. At Hissar only one harvest could be taken, giving 1970, 2350 and 2580 kg/ha, resp. Yields at ICRISAT were better than those usually obtained with medium-maturity cv. Substantial amounts of woody stalks were produced by the early cv., e.g. 4.5 t/ha by June-sown cv. ICPL 87. At Hissar the lower population densities of 160 000 and 260 000 plants/ha gave better yields than the higher ones. At ICRISAT Center, with Aug. sowing, the highest plant density gave the best yields. In the June sowing at ICRISAT, ICPL 4 and ICPL 81 gave more yield at the higher densities and ICPL 87 at the lower densities.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); Web of Science

Author: ARENS, L. E.
Title: The history of the discovery of perennial rye in the North Caucasus.
Abstract Note: Perennial rye ( Secale kuprijanovii) was first found in the mountains of the Kuban' Province in 1870 and it is thought to be an escape of an ancient cultivation. It is now considered to be a valuable fodder grass and it was used in the USSR for crossing with cultivated rye to obtain perennial forms of the latter.-A.B.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: BRAITHWAITE, D. P.
Title: The hydrocyanic acid content of perennial Kavirondo sorghum.
Abstract Note: B. determined the hydrocyanic acid content of young, maturing and mature perennial Kavirondo sorghum [a hybrid between Sorghum verticiflorum and S. niloticum] in Kenya, and of the aftermath resulting from cutting at various stages in the season. Mature sorghum was a safe feeding stuff, and young growth from seed, under moist conditions was unlikely to prove harmful. Young aftermath during the dry season, however, had a dangerously high HCN content, and the authors presumed that if young growth from seed were subjected to dry conditions it too might be dangerous, though they did not demonstrate this.-A.S.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: O, OLORODE; R, BAQUAR S.
Title: THE HYPARRHENIA-INVOLUCRATA HYPARRHENIA-SUBPLUMOSA GRAMINEAE COMPLEX IN NIGERIA MORPHOLOGICAL AND CYTOLOGICAL CHARACTERIZATION
Publication Title: Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society
Abstract Note: H. involucrata Stapf is an annual with diploid, aneuploid, tetraploid and hexaploid chromosome races on a base of x = 10, while H. subplumosa Stapf is known to be tetraploid and perennial. The 2 spp. overlap considerably in their vegetative and floral attributes. While the floral characteristics (such as number of awns and sex of imperfect flowers) are fairly constant within H. involucrata, they are quite variable in H. subplumosa: the evolutionary significance of some of these variations is discussed. Some of the observations on size, variability and fertility of pollen grains are interpreted using data from chromosome numbers and meiotic behavior. Preliminary observations on the hybrids between a diploid race of H. involucrata and H. subplumosa indicate that the genomes of the 2 spp. are highly homologous and that perennial habit is a dominant trait controlled by a single gene.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); Web of Science

Author: SKLJAR, V. N.
Title: The importance of grain colour in perennial rye.
Abstract Note: Yellow, green and brown grains occurred, sometimes all three in the same ear. Tabular data show 1000-grain weight and protein content to be highest in the green grains and lowest in the brown.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: CICIN, N. V.
Title: The importance of wide crossing in applied botany.
Abstract Note: Attention is called to the value of the wild species of fruit trees that occur on Soviet territory and the use that has been made of them as parents by Micurin and other Soviet breeders, some of the varieties produced in this way being named; these include hybrids of apple x pear, apple x quince, domestic pear x Pyrus ussuriensis, almond x peach, red x black currant and red currant x gooseberry in addition to the many Micurin varieties. Existing species have been resynthesized, for instance the domestic plum, and many new species created. By the use of suitable nutrient media it has been possible to raise mature plants from excised embryos of many cereal hybrids. Most of them give better sets of grain when pollinated with a distant species than with either of their parent species; thus the hybrid Triticum vulgare var. lutescens x Agropyron glaucum[Elymus hispidus] gave only 1.2% set with pollen of either parent but produced a large number of fertile hybrids when pollinated with Secale cereale. It is reported that Elymus giganteus and E. arenarius have now been crossed with wheat, barley and rye [cf. XXIX, 2419]. Some of the perennial Triticum x Agropyron hybrids give 3-4 cuts of hay, with a total yield of up to 100 c. hay per ha., per year, or, alternatively, a yield of grain plus 1-2 cuts of hay. Soft wheats with branched ears have also been produced.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Duncan, R. R.; Gardner, W. A.
Title: The influence of ratoon cropping on sweet sorghum yield, sugar production, and insect damage
Abstract Note: As multiple cropping practices continue to spread in the southeastern U.S.A., ratoon cropping (two harvests from a single planting) provides an additional double-cropping scheme for farmers. Fourteen sweet sorghum (Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench) cultivars were evaluated in a ratoon double-cropping system at two locations during 1980 and 1981. Significant cultivar × location interactions were detected both years. Environmental conditions (particularly air and soil temperatures) and genetic capability governed performance of cultivars in the ratoon cropping system. The Coastal Plain location provided a more stable environment for ratoon cropping of sorghum than the Piedmont location and this production dependability was attributed to warm temperatures during April–May and October–November coupled with at least 230+ frost-free days. Total whole-plant green weights were 36% higher in the Coastal Plain than in the Piedmont. Percent sugar concentration was 15% higher on the first crop and 9% higher on the ratoon crop in the Piedmont than in the Coastal Plain. Calculation of total sugar yield per hectare revealed that the cultivars produced 43% more sugar when grown in the Coastal Plain than in the Piedmont. Roma was the best cultivar in the Coastal Plain while Brandes, Wray, and Keller were the best cultivars in the Piedmont. MN 960 and Ramada should be avoided when ratoon cropping. Insect damage was significantly greater on the ratoon crop than on the first crop. Fall army worm (Spodoptera frugiperda (J. E. Smith)) larvae caused the major foliar damage on the ratoon crop. Genetic improvements are needed in sweet sorghum cultivars used in ratoon cropping to increase total plant weight productivity (especially on the ratoon crop), sugar accumulation in the stem (particularly on the first crop), tillering capability in the ratoon crop, germination and seedling vigor in cool soils, and disease and insect resistance.Key words: Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench, double cropping, cultivar by location interaction, Spodoptera frugiperda (J. E. Smith), Heliothis zea (Boddie)
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: Su, C. C.
Title: The introduction of ratoon cultivation of rice.
Abstract Note: In trials with ratooned rice, N, PK or NPK fertilizer was applied at the ratoon cut, 20 days later or at the young panicle stage. Grain yields with N were highest with the earliest application date and decreased with delay in application of N. With PK or NPK fertilizer the yields were the same with the 2 earlier application dates and decreased at the latest application date. The effects of herbicide applications were also investigated.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: DOBROHVA LOV, V. P.; CICIN, N. V.
Title: The methodological aspect of the hybridization theory.
Publication Title: Nauc. Dokl. vyss. Sk. : Philos. Nauk. (Sci. Rep. high. Sch. : Philos.   Sci.).
Abstract Note: After a discussion of the evolutionary significance of distant hybridization, its practical value is illustrated by Triticum-Agropyron hybrids such as the cultivar Vostok [East], combining earliness, resistance to loose smut, and freedom from lodging, shedding and sprouting with high yield; perennial wheats giving grain and forage yields in the first two years and having a survival of 60% in the third; and wheats that yield 400 c. and more of green matter per ha after the grain has been harvested.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: FORLANI, R.
Title: The most recent wheat varieties.
Abstract Note: The wheat varieties selected in Italy during the last few years are suitable for the plains and for low hill country. The highest yields in Lombardy are mostly obtained with the variety 0.10. Other high-yielding varieties are Mara, Funo and Fortunato. In a variety trial, which included 0.10, Funo was best with 71.35 q./ha. While 0.10 does well only in particular conditions, S. Pastore is adaptable to different conditions, including cold. Perennial wheat, obtained by crossing Triticum with Agropyron, is considered of no practical value.-E.B.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: KUPRIJANOV, S. I.; SUDNOV, P. E.
Title: The nature of aftermath formation in perennial wheats of A. I. Derzavin (perennial wheat-rye-hybrids).
Abstract Note: Aftermath growth depended on the number of green internodes left after mowing and the reserve substances in them. A better aftermath was formed in those plants which had a larger number of unvernalized buds. The buds which were vernalized during winter produced fertile tillers and deferred barren shoots. Unvernalized shoots winter much better, fully vernalized tillers perishing during winter. The number of fertile tillers was very small in the second cut and the use of the second cut for seed was hardly expedient; for forage the second cut should be mown at the time of sowing winter crops. Further improvement of hybrids should prevent the formation of fertile shoots in the second cut and vernalization of autumn-formed shoots.-M.A.O.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: YAKOVLEV, G. V.
Title: The number of primary roots in rye.
Publication Title: Sbornik Trudov Aspirantov i Molodykh Nauchnykh Sotrudnihov. Vsesoyuznyi   Nauchno-Issledovaterskii Institut N.I. Vavilova
Abstract Note: The number of primary roots in cultivated and in annual-weed rye varied from 1 to 10 and in species of wild perennial rye ( Secale kupriyanovi, S. anatolicum) from 1 to 6, the majority of grains developing 4-7 and 2-4 primary roots, respectively. Seedlings of wheat and barley were examined for comparison.-A.V.B.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: Gabrovska, Dana; Fiedlerova, Vlasta; Holasova, Marie; Maskova, Eva; Smrcinov, Hana; Rysova, Jana; Winterova, Renata; Michalova, Anna; Hutar, Martin
Title: The nutritional evaluation of underutilized cereals and buckwheat
Abstract Note: We evaluated the nutritional factors of underutilized cereals (spelt, emmer, einkorn, millet, foxtail millet, semiperennial rye, naked oat, and naked barley) and buckwheat. The basic food components as well as minor nutrients were determined. The analyses included dry matter, ash, protein, dietary fiber, fat, fatty acids, amino acids, minerals, and lipophilic and hydrophilic vitamins. Rutin was also determined in buckwheat. We hope to offer new recipes for the healthy food production and for special dietary use (diabetes, celiac disease, phenylketonuria diet, etc.). Use of the germinated seeds is also suggested. The examples of some healthy food products in the Czech Republic are mentioned.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: Xue-Qing, Zhao; Hui-Mei, Shen; Yan-Qiong, Yin; Xiang-Yong, Li; Jian-Ping, Lu; Ai-Dong, Chen
Title: The occurrence characteristics and population dynamics of Sogatella furcifera (Horvath) in Yunnan Province
Abstract Note: [Objectives] The objective of this study was to investigate the occurrence characteristics and damage caused by Sogatella furcifera (Horvath) in Yunnan Province to provide a basis for the effective control of this pest. [Methods] In 2010-2011, the population occurrence and dynamics of S. fuercifera were systematically studied in the field using light-trap collection in six major rice growing areas in Yunnan, including the west, southwest, south, southeast, east, and northeast. [Results] The results show that the size of the overwintering population was smaller than in other seasons and its distribution was different in six major rice farming areas of Yunnan; mostly concentrated on rice stubble, ratooning rice and rice seedlings in wet paddy fields at latitudes south of N 23 degrees 55'164 '' and altitudes below 1 369 m. Moreover, the overwintering population of S. furcifera in the south and southeast of Yinman was more abundant than that in the west and southwest. Light-trapping indicated that the beginning of the migration period of S. furcifera was from early March to late May in the west, early March in the southwest, and middle to late May in the northeast. The migration period of S. furcifera was progressively later from the west to the southwest, south, southeast, east, and northeast. Adult numbers captured by light-trapping were lower in the southwest than the southeast and the peak immigration dates were mainly in May, June and July. The return migration peak occurred from late September to middle October. Population peaks occurred in the southwest and south from the end of April to June, in the southeast and east from late May to early July, and in the northeast from late June to July. [Conclusion] S. furcifera mostly occurs in the south, southeast and southwest of Yunnan in May, June and July.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: IKEHASHI, Hiroshi
Title: The Origin of Flooded Rice Cultivation
Abstract Note: Rice cultivation has long been considered to have originated from seeding of annual types of wild rice somewhere in subtropics, tropics or in the Yangtze River basin. That idea, however, contains a fatally weak point, when we consider the tremendous difficulty for primitive human to seed any cereal crop in the warm and humid climate, where weed thrives all year round. Instead of the accepted theory, we have to see a reality that vegetative propagation of edible plants is a dominant form of agriculture in such regions. The possibility is discussed that Job's tears and rice, two cereal crops unique to the region, might have been developed via vegetative propagation to obtain materials for medicine or herb tea in backyard gardens prior to cereal production. This idea is supported by the fact that rice in temperate regions is still perennial in its growth habit and that such backyard gardens with transplanted taro can still be seen from Yunnan Province of China to Laos. Thanks to detailed survey of wild rice throughout China for 1970–1980, it is now confirmed that a set of clones of wild rice exist in shallow swamps in Jiangxi Province, an area with severe winter cold. In early summer ancient farmers may have divided the sprouting buds and spread them by transplanting into flooded shallow marsh. Such way of propagation might have faster improved less productive rice through a better genetic potential for response to human interference than quick fixation in seed propagation, because vegetative parts are heterogeneous. Obviously, such a primitive manner of rice cultivation did include the essential parts of rice farming, i.e., nursery bed, transplanting in flooded field of shallow marsh like. Transfer from the primitive nursery to true nursery by seed may have later allowed rice cultivation to be extended to northern regions. In thus devised flooded cultivation there were a series of unique advantages, i.e.; continuous cropping of rice in a same plot, no soil erosion, slow decline of soil fertility, availability of minerals, and resulting in high yield per unit area, which have collectively attained the highly productive cereal cultivation in the warm and humid region. Rice cultivation in marsh is also favorable to raise fish culture, both of which constituted a nutritionally balanced base. Development of irrigation technology to construct flooded farms gave strong bases for stable rice-cultivating society, which in the end formulated the rise of ancient kingdoms of Yue and Wu in China in BC 6th -5th centuries. They were direct descendents of those people who had developed the unique rice cultivation from the era of Hemudu culture, which is dated back to 5 000 BC. Their movement to the south is considered to have established rice-cultivating communities in South China and Southeast Asia, while to the north it transferred the rice-based technology to ancient Korea and Japan and had established there a base for a civilized society.
Manual Tags: ancient kingdom; full text unavailable; perennial habit; perennial W/1 grain; primitive agriculture; relevant; rice and fish farming; ScienceDirect; search.grain; spread of rice cultivation; SPV; sustainable cultivation; vegetative propagation

Author: SINSKAJA, E. N.; BORKOVSKAJA, V. A.
Title: The perennial Agropyron-Triticum hybrid of P. J. Bodovskij.
Abstract Note: The hybrid described, alleged to be a cross of A. repens * wheat, is intermediate between these two in habit; it is perennial but has proved winter hardy only in the milder parts of the southern USSR; it is also not tolerant of drought; however, under favourable conditions it gives higher yields of green fodder in the first and second cuts than those obtained from perennial grasses, Secale kuprijanovii or the perennial hybrids of N. V. Cicin. It has remained free from brown rust and almost free from yellow rust. It breeds true and is partially sterile; it has a chromosome number of 2n = 56.
