Author: GORSKOV, I.; JAKOVLEV, P.
Title: The possibilities revealed by the achievements of I. V. Michurin.
Publication Title: Sotsialisticeskaja Rekonstruktsija Sel'skogo Khozjaistva (Socialist   Reconstruction of Agriculture)
Abstract Note: Reference is made to the immense value to Soviet agriculture and breeding of the wild forms and species of many cultivated plants newly discovered by the Soviet expeditions to the centres of distribution. The provision of forms suitable to more northerly cultivation in particular is likely to be achieved by this means and special reference is made to the perennial wheat produced by hybridizing with rye-grass. The same is now being done for fruit trees. Twenty species of small bush fruits not hitherto used either as fruit or for crossing have been collected at Hibiny. In Siberia all possible kinds of temperate fruits are found and these are not damaged by the frost. Michurin has made use of all these forms, many of them for direct introduction and all of them for hybridization. Whole forests of interesting forms of common fruits, hitherto untouched by the breeder, exist in Transcaucasia and other countries. Many of these are resistant to frost or to drought. Similar forests of walnut, pistachio and other nuts occur in the Central Asiatic republics of the Soviet Union and these, as well as a number of subtropical fruits, are being used by Michurin, whose breeding work has made possible the cultivation in northern regions of all kinds of fruits that would not have been even considered previously. Michurin's method consists of crossing forms of widely different geographical origin-the wild vines, pears, almonds, etc., of the Far East were crossed with the high-quality varieties of Europe and America-or crossing forms of very different genetic constitution, i.e. interspecific and intergeneric hybridization. Species and genera that will not cross are first united vegetatively at as early an age as possible or else crossed by means of an intermediate form. By this means he has produced over two hundred new varieties of fruits and other plants. At present he is evolving frost-resistant peaches for the central area of the U.S.S.R. and the Crimea. In apples he has evolved sorts that not only grow in such regions as Voronesh but come into bearing at the end of 5-6 years and are of superior quality and flavour. In whole areas of central and northern U.S.S.R., Siberia and the Urals, fruit growing has been made possible as a result of this work. Attention is now being devoted also to the production of artificial mutation. In 1934 fifty thousand hybrid seedlings were growing at Michurin's station and 948 combinations were made, involving the pollination during that year of 205, 057 flowers artificially and 463, 942 by means of bees. Mass hybridizations were made at other places too, 150, 000 flowers being cross-pollinated at the Moscow station, 80, 000 at Leningrad, and 600, 000 at others. At present four thousand growers are using Michurin's varieties and sixteen thousand hectares will be under them in the second Five Year Plan.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: KOLESNIKOVA, P. D.
Title: The possibility of characterizing the water balance of plants by the parameter of the relative degree of saturation of the cells with water (H) Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1963, No. 6G88. (Translation)
Publication Title: Izvest Akad Nauk Tadzhiksk Ssr Otd Sel Skokhoz I Biol Nauk
Abstract Note: The purpose of the work was to confirm whether the index of the relative degree of saturation of the cells with water reflects the water balance of plants, and to establish the possibility of the practical use of the index. Pot and field experiments were carred out with perennial grasses 1 and 2 years old (alfalfa, Italian ryegrass, and orchardgrass) in pure sowings and in grass mixtures with different types of nutrition and water supply near Tashkent. To determine the cell water-saturation (H), the author used the formula suggested by Shardakov where [image] [center dot]100%, in which P is the osmotic pressure and S the suction. H reflects the state of the plant's supply of water and this value can be used in irrigation practice. With perennial grains the application of nitrogen fertilizers and the simultaneous growing of alfalfa improves the supply of water for the cells, as found by increased values of H. With alfalfa, fertilizer has little effect on H. In mixed sowings of grains with alfalfa the value of H is lower than with pure sowings.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); Web of Science

Author: DNEPROVSKII, I. F.
Title: The problem of perennial cereal crops in the farming system based on grass rotations.
Abstract Note: This article is devoted to discussing the advantages which would accrue to farmers when the fields allocated to the growing of perennials ( Medicago, Phleum, Trifolium, Agropyron cristatum, A. americanum etc., both as fodder crops and for maintaining the structure and increasing the fertility of soil for the subsequent field crops), be sown in addition with perennial wheat and rye. Field and plot trials showed that, when wheat or rye were sown in the autumn and lucerne in the spring, the first cutting of perennial cereals yielded grain, and the second (which was done simultaneously with the first cutting of lucerne) yielded good green feed and hay. On some individual collective farms where such procedure was adopted an additional 75 per cent (3, 000 centners) of grain was harvested; at the same time, since the period during which the perennials remain in the field is doubled or trebled, such a rotation, as instanced by the one given below, would inevitably lead to a considerable increase in the fertility of the soil and in yields. The following is a 12-course rotation used with success in the Kharkov Territory, on a farm with a cultivated area of 1, 800 ha. : (1) fallow; (2) perennial wheat (cover crop) + lucerne; (3) 1st year lucerne + perennial wheat; (4) 2nd year lucerne + perennial wheat; (5) 3rd year lucerne + perennial wheat; (6) annual cereals; (7) potatoes, etc. ; (8) spring cereals; (9) fallow; (10) winter cereals; (11) catch crops (cereals); (12) spring crops. In the above rotation the perennial grass stratum remained undisturbed for 4 instead of the usual 2 years with the consequent rise in yields.-H.F.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: DEMISEV, K. S.
Title: The problem of perennial graminaceous plants.
Abstract Note: Development of perennial forms of wheat and rye at the Kabarda State Breeding Station by environmental training, without wide hybridization, is reported. Some productive forms of rye of the perennial type were derived from the winter rye Kabardinka [Kabarda] and the hybrid Kabardinka x Stal [Steel]. They have borne normally developed grains with a 1000 kernel weight of 24-32 grm. and transmitted the perennial habit to 81-100% of the sexual progeny. The seed progeny of the perennial rye segregated in respect of many characters, including branched and other abnormal types of ear. Some progeny produced culms with several ears each, and others bore ears resembling panicles. The latter plants did not resemble rye or any other plant of the Hordeeae. The material investigated gave more types with branched ears and culms bearing several ears in the later generations, and is being multiplied in the hope that it will give a productive perennial rye adapted to the climate of the Caucasian foothills. References are made to an instance of conversion of rye into Bromus inermis and to a perennial wheat obtained by environmental training of a productive line of Lutescens 907. The perennial wheat had longer ears, bearing 35-38 large grains, than Lutescens 907. It produced grain two years in succession, but was incapable of surviving for a longer period. The experiments suggest that training wheat for the perennial habit is more arduous than with rye.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: DERZAVIN, A.
Title: The problem of perenniality in agricultural plants.
Abstract Note: Research on breeding perennial forms dates from 1930, when a perennial bulbous barley was found by the author in the Karabah highlands, Transcaucasia. For obtaining perennial wheat of a grain and hay type, wheat was crossed with perennial ryes, including Secale Kuprijanovi from North Caucasus. A perennial F 1 generation was easily obtained with a percentage success of 50 to 70, but the hybrids were sterile. Nevertheless, 2650 FI florets yielded thirty-seven grains in 1932, and in the following year 133 grains were obtained from 186, 824 florets. Five generations of perennial forms are now available. By crossing cultivated rye with the perennial type, a perennial and partially fertile F 1 generation was produced. Four generations of perennial forms of hay and grain type are now available. For hay, perennial rye should be sown with perennial vetch; breeding of perennial cultivated forms of vetch and Lathyrus is also in progress. Crosses of cultivated sorghum with the perennial type yielded 1, 700 grains of perennial forms for grain and hay use. In 1935, by crossing annual sunflowers with the perennial type and the perennial sunflowers with the tuberous type, 135 and ten grains were obtained respectively. The object is to obtain perennial forms producing seeds and tubers.-M.A.O.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.grain; search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: CICIN, N. V.
Title: The problem of perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: Agropyron caninum, A. tenerum, A. sibiricum and A. cristatum were found to be incompatible with wheat. A. glaucum, A. trichophorum, A. elongatum and A. junceum gave a high percentage of success in crossing with soft and hard wheat. A. repens in early experiments failed to cross with wheat, but later forms were found which cross readily. As the systematics of Agropyron are not yet complete, the forms in question may represent a new Agropyron species. In the F 1 generation, the characters of Agropyron are dominant; all the hybrids are perennial and show an equal tendency to generative and vegetative reproduction. Most of the F 1 plants are self-sterile, only individual groups being self-fertile. B. A. Vakar found that the number of chromosomes of the self-fertile hybrids equals the sum of the haploid number of the parental forms. Reduction division of wheat * A. elongatum is quite normal, twenty-eight bivalents being formed; reduction division in wheat * A. glaucum hybrids is associated with such serious meiotic disturbances that the extent of self-fertility is surprising (Vakar). Some F 1 plants segregate, whereas others remain constant. As the majority of F 1 generation was self-sterile, back crossing to one of the parents was required; the percentage of success did not exceed 3 to 4 per cent. Natural cross-pollination in mixed sowings of hybrids and wheat was more successful. From the F 2 generation onwards, segregation gave rise to various forms, some with characters not found in the parents. The percentage of perennial plants fell somewhat in the F 2 generation, and in subsequent generations varied according to the type of parent; the percentage of perenniality in F 4 plants varied from none to 60 or 70. In F 5 and subsequent generations a number of valuable annual and perennial forms could be selected. Some vigourous forms, for example, wheat * A. elongatum hybrids, with many tillers are of particular forage value; perennial wheats are for grain and forage purposes. The length of the vegetative period in F 1 plants is determined by the type of wheat: Agropyron * spring wheat yielded spring hybrids and Agropyron x winter wheat, winter hybrids. The vegetative period of forms intermediate between wheat and Agropyron varies with the year. In the first year three groups are found, namely, forms with long vegetative period (120 days or more), forms not fully earing in the first year and forms not earing in the first year. In the second year all the forms eared earlier than typical winter wheat.-M.A.O.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: CICIN, N. V.; LJUBIMOVA, V. F.
Title: The production of new forms of perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: The properties of the first perennial wheats such as M34085 and M2, arising from crosses of winter bread-wheat with Agroypron glaucum, are described; being insufficiently hardy, they are grown as annuals, giving a yield of grain and several cuts of hay in the same season. Crossing M2 with other hybrids gave rise to certain selections of the wheat type, which were crossed again with other hybrids, as a result of which several promising hybrids have arisen, three of which had 37.6, 48.6 and 62.0% survival after three years of cropping; in these forms, the tillers formed after the grain ripens remain short and the plants are only 30-35 cm. high at the end of September, when those of M2 are 50-60 cm. ; in the spring they grow to 80-115 cm. and form 40-45 ears, those of M458 being closest to the wheat type; grain size increases in the second and third years, the grain having 22-25% of protein and up to 45% of raw gluten. The new forms, in contrast to M2, are predominantly self pollinated. Their yield diminishes in the fourth and later years.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: SULE, E. P.
Title: The production of perennial forms of wheat
Publication Title: Trudy Zonal Inst Zernovovo Khoziaistva Nechernozemnoi Polosy Sssr
Abstract Note: F1 hybrids between Triticum vulgare var. lutescens 0.62 and Agropvron glaucum, A. elongatum, A. trichophorum, A. junceum, and A. repens are perennial, vigorous, and survive for 5-6 years in the field under Moscow conditions. Although they were highly sterile, a few seeds were obtained from cross pollination. After repeated backcrossing onto wheat, plants of the F4 generation are only 1% perennial. Better results were obtained by using winter wheat with high regenerative ability, and by crossing F1 hybrids with relatively fertile, perennial plants of later generations. Among the plants of the F2 generation, 30 to 35% are sterile, and with a few exceptions grains of the fertile plants have no commercial value. In the F3 generation, particularly after intercrossing between F2 hybrids, a relatively high proportion of perennial plants with wheat-like grains was obtained. In the F4 generation, only 30% of the plants were perennial, but grain quality was good enough so that agronomically valuable selections could be made. Var. no. 34085, obtained from spring wheat Lutescens 0.62 x A. glaucum backgrossed to winter wheat Koopera-torka, has spikes with a mean length of 9.5 cm., 15-16 spikelets per spike, 3-5 grains per spikelet. Mean absolute wt. of grains is 32g. The milling and baking qualities of the grain resemble wheat vars. Milturum 0321 and Caesium 0111. Yield tests over 3 years in the Kazakh and Kirghiz republics have shown that under optimum conditions the yield for a single harvest is 33-37 centners/hectare (1 cent./hect. = 0.74 bushels/acre) and in 4 harvests over 2 yrs. 55 cent./hect. were obtained. In many expt. stations perennial wheat did not realize its full potentialities because of poor agricultural technique and insufficient watering. Several other new vars. are now being tested.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.grain; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: TIUNOVA, N. A.
Title: The protein complex of wheat grains and changes produced in it by hybridization between wheat and another grass species Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1962, No. 18 G80. (Translation)
Publication Title: Tr Gl Bot Sada Akad Nauk Sssr
Abstract Note: Physical and chemical studies were made of the properties of the proteins of the grain of wheat variety Lutescens 329, quackgrass (Agropyron glaucum) and wheat-quackgrass hybrid M-2 (perennial wheat). The quackgrass grain showed a high (2:1) gliadine to gluteline ratio, as compared with a 1:1 gliadine: gluteline ratio in the wheat grain. The content of non-extractable N in the quackgrass flour was significantly higher than in the flour of grain from the wheat or the hybrid. The physical and chemical properties of the proteins of the wheat and quackgrass grains were quite similar. The only differences observed were in the quantitative relationships between the different fractions in the albumin and globulin preparations. No significant differences were found in the contents of the aromatic amino acids tyrosine and tryptophane or in the albumins, gliadines or glutelines of the wheat and quackgrass grains. In its content of different forms of N and in the properties of its proteins the wheat-quackgrass hybrid M-2 occupied an intermediate position between the parent forms, but more frequently showed a somewhat greater resemblance to wheat in its characteristics.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: MURAVIEV, P. A.
Title: The quality of the grain on the annual hybrid wheat Agropyrum of N. V. Tzitzin and the perennial wheat hybrid of A. I. Derjavin
Publication Title: Selektzia I Semenovodstvo [plant Breeding and Seed Growing]
Abstract Note: The grain of the Tzitzin annual wheat-Agropyrum hybrids, Nos. 22229, 22850, 23004, 23834, and 23823, is descr., with photographs of loaves and descriptions of the grain, flour, and bread-making quality. All hybrids gave good results, and the quality and volume of bread compared favorably with ordinary wheat bread. The test of the perennial hybrid of Derjavin was less conclusive; the bread was tasty, but of small volume and large pores and was inferior to that of the Ukrainka wheat.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Web of Science

Author: Runck, B.C.; Kantar, M.B.; Jordan, N.R.; Anderson, J.A.; Wyse, D.L.; Eckberg, J.O.; Barnes, R.J.; Lehman, C.L.; DeHaan, L.R.; Stupar, R.M.; Sheaffer, C.C.; Porter, P.M.
Title: The reflective plant breeding paradigm: A robust system of Germplasm development to support strategic Diversification of Agroecosystems
Abstract Note: Over the last half-century, crop breeding and agronomic advances have dramatically enhanced yields in temperate summer-annual cropping systems. Now, diversification of these cropping systems is emerging as a strategy for sustainable intensification, potentially increasing both crop production and resource conservation. In temperate zones, diversification is largely based on the introduction of winter-annual and perennial crops at spatial and temporal locations in annual-crop production systems that efficiently increase production and resource conservation. Germplasm development will be critical to this strategy, but we contend that to be feasible and efficient, germplasm improvement must be closely integrated with commercialization of these crops. To accomplish this integration, we propose a novel approach to germplasm development: the reflective plant breeding paradigm (RPBP). Our approach is enabled by developments in genomics, agroecosystem management, and innovation theory and practice. These developments and new plant-breeding technologies (e.g., low-cost sequencing, phenotyping, and spatial modeling of agroecosystems) now enable germplasm development to proceed on a time scale that enables close coordination of breeding and commercialization (i.e, development of cost-effective production systems and supply-value chains for end-use markets). The RPBP approach is based on close coordination of germplasm development with enterprise development. In addition to supporting strategic diversification of current annual-cropping systems, the RPBP may be useful in rapid adaptation of agriculture to climate change. Finally, the RPBP may offer a novel and distinctive pathway for future development of the public plant-breeding programs of land-grant universities with implications for graduate education for public-and private-sector plant breeders.
Manual Tags: ALL(perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE(ar); ALL(perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE(ar); ALL(perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); relevant; Scopus; search.grain; search.rice; search.wheat; SPV

Author: Thompson, T. N.; Rister, M. E.; Grant, W. R.; Klosterboer, A. D.; McCauley, G. N.; Stansel, J. W.; Krausz, J. P.; Drees, B. M.; Turner, F. T.; Bollich, C. N.; Marchetti, M. A.; Way, M. O.; Webb, B. D.; Whitney, N. G.; Pinson, S. R. M.; Schubert, C. R.
Title: The relationship between experimental plot research and Texas rice producers’ ratoon field results
Abstract Note: At several recent Texas (USA) rice industry meetings, rice consultants and producers mentioned observing input responses different from those reported by extension and research specialists. This study documents the correlation between scientists' recommendations based on existing theory drawn from rice plot research and actual results from commercial fields obtained from producers' surveys during 1987-89. Scientists' expert ex ante opinions on the effects of several predetermined, decision, and uncertain factors on ratoon crop rice (Oryza sativa L.) field yield and quality (milling yield, head yield, and grade) were documented. A modified Delphi procedure, whereby scientists come to a consensus agree- ment, was used to determine an exten- sive set of independent variables hypothesized to either positively or negatively affect ratoon crop yield and quality.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Sun, X. H.; Tian, Y. H.; Yang, H. L.; Zhang, Z. L.; Wang, H. X.; Ren, G. Z.; Zhang, M. R.
Title: The relationship between the height of the first cropped rice stubble and 32P utilization and economic characteristics of ratooning rice.
Publication Title: Application of Atomic Energy in Agriculture
Abstract Note: The relationship between the height of the 1st crop rice stubble of early cv. Shufeng No.1 ( Oryza sativa subsp. hsien Ting), the absorption and distribution of 32 P and the grain yield of ratooning rice were studied. Results indicated that as stubble height increased so absorption of 32 P increased yield of ratooning rice. Highest DW and radioactivity of the ratooning rice were obtained on the 3rd node in the treatments where the 1st (uppermost) or 2nd node were kept, while in the treatments where the 3rd or 4th node were kept, the max. value was obtained from the 4th node. Highest values for emergence rate, number of panicles and other characters of economic importance were obtained from the 3rd node in all treatments.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: KRUTIHOVSKII, V. K.
Title: The results of trials of Derzavin's perennial rye.
Abstract Note: Trials at the Dmitrovskii State Varietal Field, Moscow province, of a perennial rye bred by A. N. Derzavin suggest that this variety shows little promise north and east of Moscow.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: HASHIOKA, Y.
Title: The rice stem nematode Ditylenchus angustus in Thailand.
Abstract Note: Ditylenchus angustus was found in paddy near Phathalung, southern Thailand. It attacked rice more seriously than did either Radopholus oryzae or Meloidogyne spp. and caused crop losses from 20 to 90%. Of the 5 varieties of rice grown in Thailand, Khao Tah Oo was the most resistant and Khao Tah Haeng 17 the most susceptible. The optimum temperature for infection by the nematode was 28 to 30°C., but the range of 27 to 28°C. was also very favourable, indicating that in tropical countries D. angustus finds suitable conditions for infection throughout the year. The soil conditions of rice paddy fields during fallow were ideal for the growth of nematodes but laboratory tests and the ecto-and euparasitic nature of D. angustus showed that soil transmission was impossible but survival of the eggs in the soil cannot be disregarded. The disease is spread mainly by nematodes in irrigation water and control methods should concentrate on eliminating other Oryza spp. which are the alternate hosts of D. angustus. Where Oryza is absent, infection is spread by ratoon rice plants and the remains of diseased plants. It is recommended that the rice be cut low, all stubble buried, crop remains burnt and all ratoon plants eliminated. S.W.A.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: K-C, LO
Title: THE RICE TARSONEMID MITE STENEOTARSONEMUS-SPINKI
Abstract Note: In the laboratory, the rice tarsonemid mite S. spinki required .ltoreq. 3 and .gtoreq. 20 days to complete its development from egg to adult stage at 30.degree. and 20.degree. C, respectively. Each female laid 59.5 and 20.0 eggs at 30.degree. and 20.degree. C, respectively. S. spinki emerged during early May. Its population increased to a high level between Aug. and Oct., and declined until harvest. In the winter they survived in the stubbles and ratoon rices until late Feb. of the next year. The greater the planting density of rice, the higher the population of rice tarsonemid mite. The varieties of lower infestation were Chianung seen No. 11, Tainung No. 67, Kaohsiung sheuan No. 1 and Taichung sen No. 5; those of higher infestation were Kaohsiung sen No. 2, Taichung sen No. 2 and Tainan No. 5. Rice plants infested with S. spinki showed a significant increase in sterility rate and decrease in panicle neck. Rice tarsonemid mite was the main cause for the occurrence of empty head of rice plants. Predatory mites occurred all year. A protozoa parasitized each instar of the rice tarsonemid mite. The highest percentage of parasitism occurred in Oct. All recommended paddy field pesticides were highly toxic to the natural enemies of S. spinki, and had little effect on the S. spinki. This is probably why the rice tarsonemid mite has increased in recent years.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Zabrodina, M. V.; Shadenkov, A. A.; Khavkin, E. E.
Title: The search for isoenzyme and DNA markers of the resistance of perennial rye to fungal diseases.
Abstract Note: The isoenzyme spectra of aspartate aminotransferases and esterases, and also those of the DNA amplification products from polymerase chain reaction, differed substantially in wild material of perennial rye ( Secale montanum) and Immunnaya 1, Immunnaya 2, and Immunnaya 3 selected for their resistance to leaf and stem rust ( Puccinia recondita and P. graminis), and to snow mold ( Tilletia).
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (rye OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); Web of Science

Author: Shiou, D. C.; Wu, H. P.
Title: The sequential distribution of species in weed communities and the competition between ratoon rice and weeds.
Publication Title: Journal of Agricultural Research of China
Abstract Note: In a study of crop-weed competition in a ratoon rice crop, the sequential distribution of weed species was analysed statistically. Diversity indices of <0.6 derived from the Shannon equation suggested that the weed community of an abandoned rice field was still at an unstable stage. Further statistical analyses were preformed to characterize species dominance. Weeds belonging to the Gramineae and Rubiaceae predominated in the ratoon rice field. The 2 families were more competitive towards the ratoon rice and shattered rice populations, resp., as indicated by multiple regression analysis. The greater competitive influence on shattered rice than on ratoon rice is explained in terms of skewness of the distribution and the coeff. of variance.

Author: I, SEMENOV V.; V, SEMENOVA E.; I, VOSTRIKOVA T.
Title: THE STUDY OF CHROMOSOME NUMBER IN THE F-12 GENERATION OF HYBRIDS FROM CROSSING COMMON WHEAT AND ITS SOME TELOCENTRIC LINES WITH PERENNIAL WHEAT
Abstract Note: The numbers of chromosomes were analyzed in the F2 of hybrids of 2 genetically differing strains of disome hexaploid common wheat and 5 telocentric lines (var. Chinese Spring: 1AL, 1BL, 1DL; 6A.alpha., 5DL) with perennial wheat. The F1 hybrids of Triticum aestivum L. (2n = 42, AABBDD) with T. agropyrotriticum Cicin, var. perenne (2n = 56, AABBDDXX) are septaploids (2n = 7x = 49, AABBDDX) and have varying chromosome numbers in the F2 and successive generations. Author: Esmaili, M.; Mobsser, H.; Abad, H. H. S.; Roshan, N. A.; Eftekhari, A.
Title: The study on the effect of plant residue management methods, Azolla and duck on weed characteristics, yield and harvest index in integrated culture of rice ratoon ( Oryza sativa).
Abstract Note: A study was conducted in Iran to investigate the effects of plant residue management methods (base cutting, common regional harvest and lock-lodging), with and without Azolla and ducks, on weed density as well as on yield and harvest index of rice cv. Tarom ratoon. The lock-lodging and common regional harvest methods had the highest and lowest weed populations, respectively. The number, height and dry weight of weeds were also decreased with Azolla and ducks. The weeds Cyperus rotundus, Echinochloa crus-galli and Typha latifolia caused the highest damage to the ratoon crop. The highest yield and harvest index were obtained from lock-lodging due to increased total number of productive tillers, number of panicles/m 2 and total number of spikelets per spike. The ducks also increased the grain yield of rice due to increases in these parameters and high 1000-grain weight. The highest harvest index was recorded with the integration of the lock-lodging method with Azolla and the ducks.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: SZOKOLAY, G.
Title: The Swaziland Irrigation Scheme. 3. Ratooning of rice on the Swaziland Irrigation Scheme.
Abstract Note: An alternative to the ratooning system, which gives 2 rice crops per year, was investigated. In this, 2 good crops were obtained in 2 years from only one land preparation and planting operation. The main crop was planted in November, harvested in March, and the stubble left through the winter without irrigation. In the spring (September) the stubbles were irrigated and the subsequent ratoon crop harvested in January. In small-scale trials, yields from these ' spring ratoons ' were not much less than from their preceding planted crops. -M.P.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Gandilyan, P. A.
Title: The systematics of the genus Secale L. and its diversity in the Armenian SSR. I. Specific differentiation.
Abstract Note: A revised classification, with synonymy, is presented for the genus. The known natural forms are grouped in four species: S. sylvestre, S. vavilovii s. l., S. montanum s. l. and S. cereale. It is further considered that artificially produced perennial cultivated rye of hybrid origin should be assigned to a separate species, S. X derzhavinii.

Publication Title: Selektsiia I Semenovodstvo [plant Breeding and Seed Growing]
Abstract Note: Station workers displayed at the Fair improved wheats, including Kanred X Fulcaster and an Illini Chief selection, the 2 now grown on 3000 ha.; a perennial rye for hay and grain; perennial hybrids of wheat and sorghum; and a hybrid tuber-bearing sunflower for fodder, oil, and alcohol.

Author: CICIN, N. V.; KRYZANOVSKII, F. D.
Title: The winter Wheat- Agropyron Hybrid 1.
Abstract Note: At the Snigiri research station, the hardiness of Hybrid 1 (cf. PBA, Vol. XXIII, Abst. 2560) and its resistance to snow mould are being improved. Hybrid 1 was obtained from a cross between the perennial wheat 34085/34 and a Swedish winter type referred to as Chef-d'oeuvre, which is noted for its large grain, productive ears and resistance to lodging. The perennial form, which was selected from the progeny of a cross between an unspecified wheat variety and an Agropyron species, is described as winter hardy and immune from fungous diseases.

Author: SUDNOV, P. E.
Title: The work of the breeder A. I. Derzavin at the Exhibition.
Abstract Note: The best selections from the hybrids of wheat with perennial rye are now free from sterility and exceed Ukrainka in yield of good plump grain and produce a quantity of herbage which can be used for feeding stock. Forms free from shattering have now been selected. The hybrids are almost equal to Ukrainka in baking quality and excel it in protein content by 2.5 per cent. Reference is also made to hybrids between perennial rye and perennial sorghum.

Author: MIKHAILOVSKII, V.
Title: The work of the Voroshiiovsk official breeding station.
Abstract Note: The method of producing the seeds of varieties designed for each of the three climatic zones served by the Station in the zone itself, according to the principles of Lysenko, is being applied. The varieties are subjected to intravarietal crossing and rigorous selection under intensive conditions of cultivation. Crosses have also been made between the local wheats and imported American varieties, whereby forms of increased resistance to yellow and brown rust and of improved yield have been obtained. Experiments are also being made on the production of perennial wheats by crossing wheats with perennial rye, and of perennial forms of other crops.

Author: Li, Hongjie; Wang, Xiaoming
Title: Thinopyrum ponticum and Th. intermedium: the promising source of resistance to fungal and viral diseases of wheat
Abstract Note: Thinopyrum ponticum and Th. intermedium provide superior resistance against various diseases in wheat (Ttricum aestivum). Because of their readily crossing with wheat, many genes for disease resistance have been introduced from the wheatgrasses into wheat. Genes for resistance to leaf rust, stem rust, powdery mildew, Barley yellow dwarf virus, Wheat streak mosaic virus, and its vector, the wheat curl mite, have been transferred into wheat by producing chromosome translocations. These genes offer an opportunity to improve resistance of wheat to the diseases; some of them have been extensively used in protecting wheat from damage of the diseases. Moreover, new resistance to diseases is continuously detected in the progenies of wheat-Thinopyrum derivatives. The present article summaries characterization and application of the genes for fungal and viral disease-resistance derived from Th. ponticum and Th. intermedium.

Author: Escalada, R. G.
Title: Tillering and ratoon cropping of grain sorghum (Sorghum bicolor (Linn.) Moench).
Abstract Note: In trials in which 10 grain sorghum hybrids were ratooned several times by cutting to 3, 8 or 13 cm and were given 0, 100, 200 or 250 kg N/ha, plant height decreased with increasing plant density. The most uniform tiller production was given by cutting to 8 cm. Cutting to 3 cm gave the greatest number of basal tillers but disease organisms entered the short stubble easily. Cutting to 13 cm gave uneven tillering and adventitious roots did not always reach ground level. Grain yields increased with increased rate of applied N and during winter the highest yields were given by cutting to 13 cm and applying 200-250 kg N/ha, while in summer yields were highest with cutting to 3 or 8 cm with the same rates of N. The best cutting height was 8 cm in all plots given N. In trials with 6 hybrids grown at 8 plant densities, the highest grain and stover yields were given by 200 000 plants/ha. In trials with shading and in growth chambers, tillering was decreased by high temperatures, short days and low light intensity, and low light intensity decreased yields.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: Ong, C. K.; Daniel, J. N.
Title: Traditional crop sparks new interest as a multipurpose tree.
Abstract Note: An account of the use of perennial pigeon pea ( Cajanus cajan) as a multipurpose tree, suitable as a component of agroforestry systems in the tropics and subtropics. Notes are given on the characteristics and uses (as food, fodder, green manure, fuelwood, thatching and baskets) of the species, its contribution to soil improvement, studies on phenology and yield potential, spacing and fertilizer requirements, crop combinations and management, weed and pest control, harvesting and research.

Author: SOKOLOVA, S. M.
Title: Transformation of the nitrogenous substances of perennial wheat ( Tri-ticum agropyrotriticum perenne).

Author: Odhiambo, H.O.; Ong, C.K.; Wilson, J.; Deans, J.D.; Broadhead, J.; Black, C.
Title: Tree-crop Interactions for Below-ground Resources in Drylands: Root Structure and Function
Abstract Note: This paper describes recent advances in below-ground research in dryland areas, focusing mainly on studies in dryland Kenya, in which novel sap flow and allometric techniques for determining root structure and function were compared with simple, but labor-intensive methods involving soil coring and trenching. Studies using these approaches indicated that tree (Gliricidia sepium and Grevillea robusta) and crop (Zea mays) roots predominantly occupied the same soil volume, implying there was little spatial complementarity, and highlighted the existence of considerable variation in tree root density between seasons. The less labor-intensive approach of determining the "competitivity index", based on measurements of main roots, was not a reliable indicator of competition unless it was adjusted for tree size. Fractal relationships provided reasonable estimates of coarse root length, but seriously underestimated the length of fine roots. Sap flow studies showed the marked capacity of tree root activity to switch from one part of the root system to others in response to changes in soil moisture availability, and highlighted the importance of root function as opposed to structure in determining the severity of below-ground competition; such effects may provide both benefits and costs to neighboring plants. Thus, there is an urgent need to develop tree management regimes which promote effective sharing of below-ground resources.

Author: Bozzini, A.; Gallo, M. del
Title: Two strategic objectives for the development of sustainable food production: crops with a perennial habit and with N 2 fixation.
Abstract Note: This paper provides an overview of current cropping practices in terms of input utilization and environmental impact, and describes the potential of cultivating perennial crops and harnessing biological N fixation as more efficient strategies to sustainable food production. Progress in the development of perennial cereals, grain legumes and oilseed plants through breeding, and advances in research on N fixation by endogenous bacteria and other bacteria associated with perennial crops are briefly discussed.

Author: Sánchez, E.; Espinoza, A.M.
Title: Ultrastructure of Oryza glumaepatula, a wild rice species endemic of tropical America
Abstract Note: Oryza glumaepatula is a perennial wild rice species, endemic to tropical America, previously known as the Latin American race of Oryza rufipogon. In Costa Rica, it is found in the northern region of the country, mainly in the wetland of the Medio Queso River, Los Chiles, Alajuela. It is diploid, of AA type genome and because of its genetic relatedness to cultivated rice it is included in the O. sativa complex. We describe the ultrastructure of leaf blade, spikelet, ligule and auricles. Special emphasis is given to those traits of major taxonomic value for O. glumaepatula and to those characters that distinguish this species from O. rufipogon and O. sativa. O. glumaepatula has a leaf blade covered with tombstone-shaped, oblong and spheroid epicuticular wax papillae. It has diamond-shaped stomata surrounded by spherical papillae, rows of zipper-like silica cells, bulky prickle trichomes of ca. 40 μm in length and small hirsute trichomes of ca. 32 μm in length. The central vein is covered with large, globular papillae of ca. 146 μm in length, a characteristic that distinguishes this species from O. rufipogon and O. sativa. The border of the leaf blade exhibits a row of even-sized bulky prickle trichomes of ca. 42.5 μm in length. Auricles have attenuated trichomes of ca. 5.5 mm in length on the edges and small bicellular trichomes of 120 μm in length on the surface. The ligule has a large number of short attenuated trichomes on its surface of 100 μm in length. These latter two traits have important taxonomic value since they were found in O. glumaepatula but not found in O. sativa or in O. rufipogon. The spikelet has the typical morphology of the Oryza genus. Fertile lemmas have abundant spines, a trait shared with O. rufipogon but not with O. sativa. The sterile lemmas are wing-shaped with serrated borders, a characteristic that distinguishes this species from O. rufipogon and O. sativa. All the ultrastructure characters observed in O. glumaepatula from Costa Rica are also common to the specimens from Brazil.

Author: RAMIREZ, D. A.; DUMLAO, R. C.
Title: Uniformity in maturity of two rice varieties grown as transplanted ratoon
Abstract Note: Transplanted basal tillers of Peta and Tjere mas were as uniform in maturity as the seedling crop. The basal tillers matured 14 to 20 days earlier than the seedling crops. The transplanted runners were less uniform in maturity but were also earlier-maturing than the "dapog"-raised seedling crop by 12 to 17 days. With Tjere mas, both the transplanted basal tillers and runners gave higher yields than the seedling crops. With Peta, comparison of relative yields was duplicated by the differential effects of lodging at different stages of maturity. The asexually propagated plants were generally shorter than the seedling plants.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Arraudeau, M.A.
Title: Upland rice: Challenges and opportunities in a less favorable ecosystem
Abstract Note: IRRI's upland rice research has made progress in solving some of the dilemmas in the upland rice ecosystem, although many challenges remain. IRRI researchers are gaining a better understanding of the ecosystem's constraints, opportunities, and research approaches. Cultivar improvement, use of farmer participatory methods to reduce erosion, and weed management are areas where research advances are being made. Developing perennial upland rice and managing weeds using less herbicide are exciting new projects being pursued. Enhancing rice productivity is seen as an entry point to alleviating the interrelated problems of declining productivity, lack of sustainability, and poverty in the uplands. Delay can irreparably damage the uplands and gravely affect the people who depend on them for survival.
Manual Tags: agricultural research; ALL(perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE(ar); Asia; International Rice Research Institute; relevant; rice research; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; upland agriculture

Author: DeHaan, Lee R.; Van Tassel, David L.
Title: USEFUL INSIGHTS FROM EVOLUTIONARY BIOLOGY FOR DEVELOPING PERENNIAL GRAIN CROPS
Abstract Note: Annual grain crops dominate agricultural landscapes and provide the majority of calories consumed by humanity. Perennial grain crops could potentially ameliorate the land degradation and off-site impacts associated with annual grain cropping. However, herbaceous perennial plants with constitutively high allocation to harvestable seeds are rare to absent in nature. Recent trade-off theory models suggest that rugged fitness landscapes may explain the absence of this form better than sink competition models. Artificial selection for both grain production and multiyear lifespan can lead to more rapid progress in the face of fitness and genetic trade-offs than natural selection but is likely to result in plant types that differ substantially from all current domestic crops. Perennial grain domestication is also likely to require the development of selection strategies that differ from published crop breeding methods, despite their success in improving long-domesticated crops; for this purpose, we have reviewed literature in the areas of population and evolutionary genetics, domestication, and molecular biology. Rapid domestication will likely require genes with large effect that are expected to exhibit strong pleiotropy and epistasis. Cryptic genetic variation will need to be deliberately exposed both to purge mildly deleterious alleles and to generate novel agronomic phenotypes. We predict that perennial grain domestication programs will benefit from population subdivision followed by selection for simple traits in each subpopulation, the evaluation of very large populations, high selection intensity, rapid cycling through generations, and heterosis. The latter may be particularly beneficial in the development of varieties with stable yield and tolerance to crowding.

Author: Gwata, E.T.; Silim, S.N.
Title: Utilization of landraces for the genetic enhancement of pigeonpea in Eastern and Southern Africa
Publication Title: Journal of Food, Agriculture and Environment
Abstract Note: The eastern and southern Africa (ESA) region is considered as a centre of secondary diversity for pigeonpea. Accessions (297) of pigeonpea landraces were collected from major production areas in four countries in the region and evaluated for desirable agronomic traits, particularly resistance to fusarium wilt and market-preferred traits. Selected germplasm was utilized in the regional breeding program aimed at genetic enhancement of pigeonpea. Five improved long-duration (LD) cultivars that are highly resistant to fusarium wilt and have large (100-grain weight >15.0 g) grains were developed. Similarly, six early maturing medium-duration (MD) cultivars (averaging 2.5 t/ha) for production in the high latitude areas in the region and three MD cultivars that are able to ratoon, were developed. Seed of pre-released cultivars that are preferred by the farmers was distributed widely in the region in order to facilitate adoption. Consequently, the productivity of pigeonpea and food security in the region improved significantly.

Author: Seiler, Gerald J.
Title: Utilization of wild sunflower species for the improvement of cultivated sunflower
Abstract Note: The genus Helianthus is composed of 49 species and 19 subspecies with 12 annual and 37 perennial species. These diverse species represent considerable genetic variability which can be utilized for the improvement of cultivated sunflower. The taxonomy of Helianthus is somewhat confusing due to the complicated natural interspecific hybridization and different ploidy levels of several species. A germplasm collection of 2000 accessions, mostly annuals, has been assembled. Interspecific hybridization has become important as a means of introducing genetic variability into the cultivated sunflower. This has been facilitated by the use of embryo culture and chromosome doubling with colchicine to increase fertility. The wild species continue to serve as a source of cytoplasmic male sterility for cultivated sunflower. Molecular techniques of restriction endonucleases of mitochondrial DNA can be used to differentiate CMS sources. The greatest impact the wild species have made on cultivated sunflower has been in the area of genes for disease resistance and, to a lesser extent, resistance to insects. The recent discovery of genes for high tolerance to the disease Phomopsis/Diaporthe helianthi Munt. Cvet. is an excellent example. Considerable variability has been reported in oil content and fatty acid concentrations in the wild species as well as agronomic and morphologic traits of plant height, days to flowering and tolerances to stress, especially salt.
Manual Tags: full text added; perennial W/1 grain; perennial W/1 sorghum; relevant; ScienceDirect; search.grain; search.sorghum; SPV

Author: Gupta, S.; Das, S.; Patra, B.; Roy, S. K. B.
Title: Variability in bud number, bud length, and ratoon tillering in four rice varieties.
Abstract Note: Three photoperiod-sensitive (PS) varieties and a late, tall variety were assessed, following harvesting in May, for ratooning ability on the basis of viable buds/main tiller (VB), bud length on main tiller (BL) and ratoon tillers/plant (RT), measured for 3 cutting heights (CH) [height above ground at which panicle + culm was harvested]. CH caused a significant difference in VB; however, the interaction effect of variety and CH was not significant. The correlation between VB and RT over CHs was not significant, but showed a moderate positive relationship in FR13A, Patnai 23 (both PS) and IET5656 (tall). Average BL for different CHs did not differ among varieties, except in Patnai 23 where BL value was generally longer and showed a distinct trend toward lengthening with increase in CH. This is attributed to varietal and variety X CH interaction effects for BL. Varietal differences in RT were not significant, but CH effect and variety X CH interaction effects were significant. A higher CH value resulted in a higher RT.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Anamthawat-Jónsson, K.
Title: Variable genome composition in Triticun x Leymus amphiploids
Abstract Note: Three different amphiploid lines originated from crosses between wheat (Triticum L.) and lymegrass (Leymus Hochst.) were analysed by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) using total genomic DNA and 18S.26S ribosomal genes (rDNA). Based on the genomic probes, these lines were the same in that they all were allohexaploids (2n=6x=42) containing 30 wheat and 12 lymegrass chromosomes. The ribosomal gene mapping further identified species origin of the chromosomes, whereby the lymegrass parent was undoubtedly L. mollis and the wheat was likely to be a Triticum species having the AB genomes. This rDNA mapping was also able to reveal differences in the genome composition among these lines, and such differences were mainly in the wheat nucleolar organizing regions (Nor). The first line (M) had two Nor-B1 (1BS), the second line (G) had one Nor-B1 (1BS), two Nor-B2 (6BS) and two Nor-A1 (1AS), whereas the third line (U) had the same Nor loci as the second line but two sites each. The wheat ribosomal genes were variably expressed depending on the lines, but the lymegrass loci appeared inactive. All three lines had the same Nor loci belonging to L. mollis, two Nor-m1 and two Nor-m2. Analysis of restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) of the rDNA confirmed the identity of L. mollis parent in all three lines and verified the differences in the wheat ribosomal genes among them. These amphiploids were, however, similar in their restriction profiles, therefore indicating common origin. The molecular and cytogenetic evidence here suggested that these annual, fully fertile amphiploids that originated from the same crosses 40 years ago became genetically differentiated and fixed in stable forms.

Author: Kulakow, P.A.
Title: Variation in Illinois bundleflower (Desmanthus illinoensis (Michaux) MacMillan): A potential perennial grain legume
Abstract Note: Illinois bundleflower, Desmanthus illinoensis (Michaux) MacMillan, is an herbaceous perennial legume native to the central and southeastern USA. It has been identified as a potential perennial grain legume. To describe variation among natural populations for agriculturally desirable characteristics, 141 accessions of D. illinoensis and one of D. leptolobus were evaluated in common garden plantings established in 1988 and 1990. Characteristics showing diversity among populations included seed yield, plant height, growth habit, days to maturity, 100 seed weight, and shatter resistance. Eight characteristics were analyzed by principal components and cluster analysis. The resulting four clusters accounted for 56% of the variation among accessions. One cluster was distinctive in having plants with vigorous, prostrate first year growth, poor winter hardiness, and large seed. Three accessions also had indehiscent legumes useful for breeding shatter resistance. There appears to be sufficient variation to support genetic improvement of agricultural characteristics of Illinois bundle flower.
Manual Tags: ALL(perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE(ar); Desmanthus illinoensis; genetic improvement; Genetic resources; Legumes; New crops; Perennial grains; Plant breeding; plant genetics; relevant; Scopus; search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); Web of Science

Author: Davies, C.L.; Waugh, D.L.; Lefroy, E.C.
Title: Variation in seed yield and its components in the Australian native grass Microlaena stipoides as a guide to its potential as a perennial grain crop
Abstract Note: This research investigated the potential to domesticate an Australian native grass (Microlaena stipoides) to produce a perennial grain crop. Perennial grain crops offer a new solution to the long-standing problems of salinity and soil erosion associated with conventional cropping systems based on annual plants. Seed yield and its components (culm number, spikelet number per culm, seed set, seed weight) were measured in 46 accessions of Microlaena stipoides (microlaena, meadow or weeping rice grass) from Western Australia and New South Wales to quantify potentially useful variation in the species. A high degree of variability was found to exist, with a 20-fold range in seed yield (0.1-2.4 g/plant), 5-fold range in seed weight (129-666 mg per 100 seeds), 2-fold range in spikelet number (14-30 per culm), 8-fold range in seed set (12-98%), and a 5-fold range in culm number (11-59 per plant). Seed yield was positively and significantly (P<0.05) correlated with culm number, seed set, and seed weight (r>0.55 for all). No correlation was found between seed yield and spikelet number per culm (r=-0.14). The range in seed yield and its components suggests that there is sufficient variation within microlaena to make selections for higher yielding lines. This variation will enable breeders to exploit genetic diversity more efficiently and identify useful accessions for further work. High priority traits for future work include synchronous maturity and resistance to shattering.

Author: Joshi, P.; Jaimini, S. N.; Bhatnagar, S. K.
Title: Variation ratooning in sorghum.
Abstract Note: Tabulated data are presented on 62 strains with respect to (1) percentage ratooning 15 days after harvesting panicles and (2) percentage ratooning and vigour 30 days after harvesting panicles and 15 days after harvesting stalks.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); Web of Science

Author: Chang, L. Z.; Hsieh, S. C.; Pai, C.
Title: Variations in ratooning ability of rice.
Publication Title: Bulletin of Taichung District Agricultural Improvement Station
Abstract Note: In a study of 163 varieties, ratooning ability varied from 0% to 122.9%. The indica varieties had an overall ability (29.0%) higher than that of the japonica varieties (19.5%). Broad-sense heritability values estimated among varieties from the same broad geographical region were 11.18-60.17% for ratooning percentage and 0-81.81% for number of ratoon tillers; varieties from the USA had the highest heritability values for ratooning percentage and those from Central America the highest value for number of ratoon tillers. It is concluded that ratooning ability is heritable and can be selected for in breeding programmes.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Uga, Y.; Fukuta, Y.; Ohsawa, R.; Fujimura, T.
Title: Variations of Floral Traits in Asian Cultivated Rice (Oryza sativa L.) and its Wild Relatives (O. rufipogon Griff.)
Abstract Note: To clarify the inter- and intraspecific variations of floral traits in rice, we investigated eleven traits related to pistil, stamen and glume using 128 Asian cultivated rice (Oryza sativa L.) accessions including 72 Indica and 56 Japonica type accessions, and 53 wild rice (O. rufipogon Griff.) accessions including 32 perennial and 21 annual ecotype accessions. We examined the results from three specific levels: intraspecific variation between perennial and annual ecotypes of wild rice, interspecific variation between cultivated rice and wild rice, and intraspecific variation between Indica and Japonica type cultivars. The annual wild rice accessions exhibited a shorter stigma and anther than the perennial wild rice ones. The cultivated rice accessions showed a lower stigma exsertion, shorter stigma, shorter anther, and thicker and wider lemma and palea than the wild rice accessions. These floral traits of cultivated rice are considered to play an important role in selfing and high seed production. None of the floral traits showed distinct differences between the Indica and Japonica type accessions in cultivated rice, although the Indica type accessions tended to display a slenderer stigma and glume than the Japonica type accessions. It is suggested that the varietal differentiation into the Indica and Japonica types is not likely to be related to genetic variations of floral traits. We clarified the differences in floral traits between annual and perennial ecotypes of wild rice, between cultivated rice and wild rice, and between the Indica and Japonica type cultivars, and discussed the relationship between genetic variations of floral traits and domestication and varietal differentiation in rice.
Manual Tags: ALL(perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE(ar); Asian cultivated rice (Oryza. sativa L.); Floral trait; Indica and Japonica; japonica; Oryza rufipogon; Oryza sativa; Palea; Perennial and annual ecotypes; relevant; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science; Wild rice (O. rufipogon Griff.); Zizania

Author: Reddy, N.
Title: Varietal evaluation for ratooning ability in flood irrigated rice ( Oryza sativa L.).
Abstract Note: Evaluation was conducted in 2 separate experiments. In the first, 135 varieties and in the second, 6 high yielding (improved) varieties were evaluated. Yields ranged from 0 to 2.05 t/ha for the ratoon crop. Main crop yield and ratoon crop duration showed a significant positive correlation with ratoon yield. Ratoon crop duration ranged from 20 to 80 days. The highest ratoon yield was obtained in 66 days from cv. Acc. 19815. Plant crop yield was higher than ratoon yield in all varieties.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Mahiul Haque, M.; Coffman, W. R.
Title: Varietal variation and evaluation procedures for ratooning ability in rice.
Abstract Note: Analysis of variance was performed on grain yield data from the ratoon crop of two lines, one having good and the other poor ratooning, using nine combinations of three cutting heights (5, 15 and 25 cm) and three cutting dates (maturity and 5 days before and after). Cutting the main crop 25 cm above ground and 5 days before maturity caused the greatest ratooning response with both lines. This procedure was used for evaluating 34 lines from 12 different crosses. A range of variability in percentage ratooning from 0 to 84% was observed among lines and the difference between lines shown to be highly significant. The lines which ratooned best were IR2061-423-1 (84%), IR2145-20-4 (65%) and IR2145-13-3 (59%).
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Singh, A. K.
Title: Vegetable type pigeonpea germplasm identified and explored from Vaishali district of Bihar.
Abstract Note: Genetic resources are the basic material for any crop improvement programme, obviously because they contain some unique traits/gene. Exploration for collection of germplasm is the quickest and simplest method for acquiring the desired one. Indian is world's biggest home of vegetarian inhabitants and legumes are main source of protein in their diet, pods are consumed fresh, or processed as vegetable either dried seed are used as dal or variety of preparation. A vegetable type pigeon pea of perennial nature has been identified and explored from Vaishali district of Bihar. Such promising and unique germplasm could be utilized by pigeon pea workers in their respective crop improvement programme to reinforcement food and nutritional security of country by efficient utilization.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(("long duration" OR perennial) NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); Web of Science

Author: Dario, G. J. A.
Title: Viability of irrigated rice ratoons.
Abstract Note: Viability of irrigated rice rootstocks was evaluated in a study carried out during 1995-96, 1996-97 and 1997-98 in an irrigated rice farm in Sao Paulo, Brazil. Five cultivars of irrigated rice from several rice plantation areas in the country were studied, and to evaluate growth of the main crop and rootstock, leaf area index and dry matter per plant, plant height and number of culms and panicles per metre were analysed as well as grain yield. Results indicated that the rootstocks had appropriate vegetative development, with mean cycle reduction of 55% and grain yield varying from 1019 to 1831 kg/ha compared with the main plantation yield of 7017-7540 kg/ha.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Townsend, S. E.; Pearlstine, E. V.; Mazzotti, F. J.; Deren, C. W.
Title: Wading birds, shorebirds, and waterfowl in rice fields within the Everglades Agricultural Area
Abstract Note: Wetland reclamation and development have resulted in wildlife habitat loss and diminished habitat quality in south Florida. In response to these changes, waterbird numbers have declined or individuals have moved into modified or artificial habitats. Rice, a well-known artificial habitat for waterbirds in many rice-growing regions (Kushlan and Hafner 2000), is cultivated in the Everglades Agricultural Area (EAA) and provides habitat for waterbirds. During the 1998 rice-growing season, 300 surveys were conducted in 14 representative rice fields. Objectives included determining the number and relative abundance of waterbird species in rice fields, impacts of temporal and spatial field condition on waterbird richness and abundance, and characterization of waterbird activities in rice fields. Forty-one species of waterbirds were observed in rice fields. Species richness at survey sites ranged from 12-28 and density ranged from 4.6 to 72.6 birds/min/100 ha. Species richness and overall abundance fluctuated in response to rice growth or harvest phase and field water levels. Significantly more wading birds and shorebirds were present in rice fields during water drawdown. Shorebird abundance was negatively correlated to water level and rice height. Waterfowl abundance was negatively correlated with cloud cover. Primary activity of all birds was foraging (63%), followed by resting (33%), walking or running (4%), and nesting (< 1%). Rice fields harvested twice (ratooned) provided additional water drawdown phases. Waterbird abundance may increase in the EAA with greater area devoted to rice fields and increased ratooning of existing fields. Effects of rice farming practices on waterbirds, including chemical use and harvesting methods, should be further evaluated.
Manual Tags: relevant; search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); Web of Science

Author: Fuller, Dorian Q.; Qin, Ling
Title: Water management and labour in the origins and dispersal of Asian rice
Abstract Note: Asian rice occurs in two wild types with differing ecologies that would have necessitated rather different systems of exploitation among early hunter-gatherers and cultivators. The monsoon-adapted ancestors of indica-like rice were readily gathered, whether unmanaged or managed through simple burning regimes, and as such might be expected to have long been gathered or cultivated without domestication. By contrast the perennial wetland rice that was ancestral to japonica necessitated more intensive forms of management, especially in terms of water regimes, for its productivity to be increased. This encouraged water-management systems that increased in complexity and labour requirements over time and can be linked to the evolution of domestication traits in Yangzte rice between 6000 and 4000 bc. The spread of rice from its Yangzte core seems to have occurred after the development of paddy-field cultivation systems. Meanwhile in India the spread of rice out of the Ganges towards South India, mainly after 1000 bc, may also have occurred only after more intensive irrigated systems of cultivation had developed. These are inferred from the archaeological weed flora of north India to have developed during the Chalcolithic to Iron Age (after 1400 bc). We suggest that the spread of rice, which has played an important role in models of Neolithic population dispersal in Southeast Asia, may have been triggered by the development of more intensive management systems and thus have required certain social changes towards hierarchical societies rather than just rice cultivation per se.
